Assume the working fluid in the heat engine is an ideal gas, and the ratio of its specific heat at constant pressure to its specific heat at constant volume is $\gamma$. The gas flow rate through the heat engine per unit time is $\dot{N}$ moles. Furthermore, assume the highest temperature $T_C$ of the gas is determined by the maximum temperature the high-temperature part of the heat engine can withstand, and the lowest temperature $T_A$ of the gas is determined by the ambient air temperature.

Calculate the change in entropy of the gas, $\Delta S$.

Two volumes are separated by a stopcock. At time $t=0$, the stopcock is opened. $V_2 = 2V_1$ as shown in figure. After a long time, for the following case $V_1$ contains 1 mole of nitrogen gas, and $V_2$ contains 2 moles of nitrogen gas.

Calculate the frequency of the sound wave, ν.

The construction of a simple musical instrument is as follows: A string of negligible mass is tightly stretched between two fixed points. A mass $m$ is attached at a distance $x$ from one end, as shown in Figure. The object is pulled away from its equilibrium position by a small distance A ($A \ll x, A \ll l-x$), and then vibrates.

How many independent modes of vibration are there?

As shown in Figure, six sliders, each of mass $m$, are connected by identical springs and are confined to move within a linear air track.

What is the time interval $\Delta t$ between the maximum pulses heard by A and B?

Two sound sources S₁ and S₂ are separated, as shown in figure. There are two observers at points A and B, which are on the same line as the sound sources. S₁ emits a stable plane wave, whose excess pressure is given by $p_e = A \cos(200t)$; the excess pressure of the stable plane wave emitted by S₂ is given by $p_e = A \cos(210t)$. $\overline{S_1S_2} = \overline{S_2A} = \overline{AB} = 10 \text{ cm}$. The speed of sound is taken as 340 m s⁻¹.

How many modes of vibration are there?

Two identical cylinders, each with moment of inertia $I$, are suspended by identical steel wires with torsional constant $K$, as shown in Figure. No swinging is allowed.

How many normal modes. are there?

Two identical objects of mass $m$ are hung on two identical springs; the spring constant of the springs is $k$, as shown in Figure. No swinging is allowed.

Calculate the amplitudes of the third harmonics, A₃ (relative to the amplitude of the fundamental mode A₀).

As shown in Figure, a guitar string is pulled up from the middle of its length.

Find the amplitude A₂ of the second harmonic component of the output voltage.

A full-wave rectifier is an instrument that can convert a sine wave with amplitude V₀ into the waveform shown in Figure.

Find the magnitude of the magnetic field.

In a certain region of space, there is a uniform electric field E with magnitude 10,000 V cm⁻¹ along the positive x-axis. In the same region, there is also a uniform magnetic field B along the y-axis. A beam of muons with velocity $v = c/3$ passes straight through this region along the positive z-axis, as shown in Figure. It is known that the mass of a muon is 207 times that of an electron, and its charge magnitude is the same as that of an electron.

Find the electric potential $\phi$ at point $P$.

Refer to Figure. There is a line charge of length $(l_1 + l_2)\text{m}$ with charge density $\lambda \text{ C/m}$. The distance from point $P$ to the line is $r$.

Find the electric field E at point P.

As shown in Figure, a thin circular disk of radius R has a uniform surface charge density σ. Point P is on the axis of the disk, at a distance r from the center of the disk

Find the potential $\phi$ on the surface of the inner sphere.

As shown in Figure, there are two concentric metal spheres. The inner sphere has a charge $q'$, and the outer sphere has a charge $q$.

Calculate the electric field $\vec{E}_1$ near the upper plate.

Two large metal plates are placed parallel to each other, with a distance $d$ between them. One end of the two plates is connected by a metallic strip. A thin plastic sheet with a surface charge density $\sigma$ is placed between the two plates, at a distance $d/3$ from the upper plate, as shown in Figure.

For $0 < x < d$, what is the volume charge density $\rho(x)$?

In an electron tube, electrons are emitted from a hot metal plate (emitter) and collected by a metal plate (collector) parallel to the emitter. The two metal plates are separated by a distance $d$. As shown in Figure. (Compared to the lateral dimensions of the metal plates, the distance $d$ is very small.) The potential between the two plates is given by $\phi = kx^{4/3}$, where $x$ is the distance from the emitter.

Find the electric potential $\phi$ of the sphere.

As shown in Figure, there is a charge $+q$ at a distance $b$ from an uncharged conducting sphere of radius $a$.

Find the potential $\phi$ at point $P=(x, 0, 0)$.

As shown in Figure, a charge $+q$ is uniformly distributed on a thin circular ring of radius $a$. The ring is located in the $yz$ plane with its center at the origin, and a charge $-q$ is placed at the center of the ring.

After what time (t₁ in the figure) does the potential difference between the two plates become zero?

A parallel-plate capacitor has a capacitance of 100 pF (1 pF = 10⁻¹² F). The separation between the plates is 1 cm. It is charged by a battery to a potential difference of 10 V. Then the capacitor is disconnected. The lower plate is illuminated with blue light, causing electrons with kinetic energy from 0 to 1.5 eV to be emitted. The potential difference attracts these electrons to the upper plate. The total current as a function of time is shown in Figure.

At positions inside the capacitor (thus edge effects can be neglected), what is the dipole moment per unit volume, P, of the dielectric?

The plates of a parallel-plate capacitor are squares with side length 20 cm. The separation between the plates is 1 cm. The capacitor is charged to a potential difference of 10V and then disconnected from the battery. As shown in Figure, a large square dielectric plate with thickness slightly less than 1 cm is inserted between the two plates, so that an area of 10 cm × 20 cm within the capacitor is filled by the dielectric. The dielectric constant of the dielectric is 4.0.

Find the electric field inside and outside the sphere.

Consider a dielectric sphere of radius a, which is uniformly polarized with polarization vector P, as shown in Figure.

Find the temperature Tp at point P(x = 100d, y = 100d). Let T₀ = 20°C, d = 50 cm, K = 0.03 W cm⁻¹K, W = 200 W, t = 10 cm. Make appropriate approximations in the calculation.

Two pipes are separated by a distance d, entering perpendicularly and passing through a large wall of thickness t, as shown in Figure. The thermal conductivity of the wall is K, and the temperature far from the pipes is T₀. At x = +d/2, hot water flows in the pipe, transferring heat to the wall at a rate of W Watts. At x = -d/2, cold water flows in the pipe, absorbing heat from the wall at a rate of W Watts. Consider this as a two-dimensional problem, neglecting the finite size effects of the pipes.

What are the magnitude and direction of the force F per meter experienced by the bottom-left wire?

Four parallel copper wires of size 10 are arranged such that their cross-sections form a square with side length 20 cm. Each wire carries a current of 20 A, as shown in Figure.

Find B at a radial distance r where b < r < c.

A long coaxial cable consists of two concentric conductors, as shown in Figure. The currents in the two conductors have the same magnitude I but opposite directions. It can be assumed that the current is uniformly distributed within the conductors.

Find the force on the wire, $F_{\text{wire}}$.

A long straight wire carries a current $I_1$. A rectangular loop has length $l$ and width $w$, and carries a current $I_2$. The wire is in the plane of the loop and is parallel to the long sides of the loop, as shown in Figure.

At maximum deflection, estimate the magnitude of the magnetic field B.

The scanning function of a television picture tube is achieved by deflecting the electron beam using a magnetic field. The magnetic field comes from a set of deflection coils placed around the neck of the picture tube. The electron beam is emitted from the electron gun, with an energy of approximately 3.0 keV (before deflection). After deflection, the electrons are further accelerated. The dimensions of each part are shown in Figure.

What is the magnitude of the magnetic field $\boldsymbol{B}$ at a location on the axis of the hole far from the ends?

A very long conducting rod of radius $a$ has a hole of radius $b$ inside it. The axis of the hole is parallel to the axis of the rod and separated by a distance $d$, as shown in Figure. A uniform current density $j$ flows through the conductor.

Find the magnetic field $\mathbf{B}$ in the same region.

In a plastic film factory, a thin plastic wide belt moves at a speed $v$ between two adjacent rollers, as shown in Figure. During the manufacturing process, the thin film accumulates a uniform surface charge $\sigma$.

What are the magnetic field B contributions from he semicircle of radius $r$.

In the wire shown in Figure, the current is $I$. At the center of the semicircle.

Find the instantaneous acceleration of electrons located at P₁. Assume $a$ is 5.0 cm.

Figure shows a uniform magnetic field B confined within a cylindrical volume of radius $r$. The magnitude of the magnetic field decreases at a constant rate of 100 gauss s⁻¹.

Find the amplitude $I_0$ of the induced current.

A rigid wire is bent into a semicircle of radius $r$, and it rotates with frequency $f$ in a uniform magnetic field, as shown in Figure. If the internal resistance of the instrument M is $M_R$, and other resistances are negligible.

Find the induced electromotive force $\epsilon$.

A small circular loop (1) of radius $a$ carries a steady current $I$. Another circular loop (2), also of radius $a$, is coaxial with (1). The distance between the two loops is $R$, and $R \gg a$. The planes of the two loops are parallel. As shown in Figure. Loop (2) now rotates about one of its diameters with angular velocity $\omega$. Loop (2) is broken (open circuit), so no current flows through it.
options: A: \( \frac{\pi a^4 I \omega}{7 \epsilon_0 c^2 R^3} \sin \omega t \)
B: \( \frac{\pi a^4 I \omega}{3 \epsilon_0 c^2 R^3} \sin \omega t \)
C: \( \frac{\pi a^4 I \omega}{2 \epsilon_0 c^2 R^3} \sin \omega t \)
D: \( \frac{\pi a^4 I \omega}{6 \epsilon_0 c^2 R^3} \sin \omega t \)

text:
A constant current $I$ flows from generator G into the rails and back along the other rail. Find the velocity of the wire as a function of time $v(t)$. (At $t=0$, the wire is at rest.)

As shown in Figure, a metal wire of mass $m$ slides frictionlessly on two rails separated by a distance $d$. The rails are located in a vertical uniform magnetic field B.

Calculate the average number of photons that will be found between planes $AB$ and $PP'$. Assume $\lambda = 6 \times 10^{-5}$ cm and the distance between planes $AB$ and $PQ$ is 30 cm.

A 1 W laser beam (of diameter 2 cm) falls normally on two circular holes each of diameter 0.05 cm, as shown in figure.

Find the period of the oscillator

Two light springs have spring constants $k_1$ and $k_2$ respectively. If they are connected in series, and then hung vertically with a mass $m$ attached to the bottom, they form a spring oscillator that can oscillate vertically, as shown in the figure.

Find the period of the oscillator

Two light springs have spring constants $k_1$ and $k_2$ respectively. If they are connected in parallel, and then hung vertically with a mass $m$ attached to the bottom, they form a spring oscillator that can oscillate vertically, as shown in the figure.

Find the angular frequency $\omega$ of the oscillation of the two balls thereafter.

On a horizontal table, two small balls A and B, both with mass $m$, are connected by a light spring with spring constant $k$, as shown in the figure. The two balls are pulled apart in opposite directions along the axis of the spring and then released.

Find the period $T$ for small oscillations of this ring.

A ring with mass $m$ and radius $R$ is placed on a knife edge. The ring can oscillate in its own plane, forming a physical pendulum, as shown in Figure.

Find the period $T_2$ for small oscillations of this ring.

Assume a ring with mass $m$ and radius $R$ is fixed on an axis PP' which is coplanar with it and tangent to its circumference. The ring can oscillate freely in and out of the plane of the paper, as shown in Figure.

Find the refractive index n of the air.

The figure shows a Rayleigh interferometer used to measure the refractive index of air. Two identical glass tubes T₁ and T₂ are placed behind the double slits. Initially, tube T₁ is evacuated, and tube T₂ is filled with the air to be measured. After the experiment begins, air is slowly introduced into tube T₁ until the pressure in both tubes is equal. During the entire process, the intensity at point P was observed to change 98 times. The wavelength of the incident light is 589.3 nm, and the length of the tubes is 20 cm.

Find the position of the zero-order bright fringe.

As shown in the figure, parallel monochromatic light with wavelength $\lambda$ is obliquely incident at a small angle $\alpha$ on a double slit with separation $d$. The distance from the double slit to the receiving screen is $D$.

Find by what factor the fringe spacing changes.

As shown in the figure, two coherent point sources S₁ and S₂ produce interference fringes on a receiving screen 2 m away. Now, a convex lens L with a focal length of 50 cm is placed between the sources and the screen, and S₁ and S₂ are on the focal plane of L.

Find The distance from the 1st bright fringe to the center of the screen.

As shown in the figure, in a Lloyd's mirror experiment, the vertical distance from the light source to the receiving screen is 1.5 m, and the vertical distance from the light source to the Lloyd's mirror surface is 2 mm. If the wavelength of light is $\lambda$=500 nm.

Find the thickness of the transparent thin film, $e$.

As shown in the figure, to measure the thickness of a certain transparent thin film coated on silicon nitride, a part of it is etched away to form a wedge. It is known that the refractive index of the transparent thin film is 1.76, the refractive index of silicon nitride is 2.35, and the wavelength of the incident light is 589 nm. 6 dark fringes are observed.

Find the angle of refraction $i_2$.

As shown in the figure, monochromatic light ($\lambda_0 = 550$ nm) emitted from point S is incident from air ($n_1=1$) into a certain transparent medium ($n_2=1.55$), and then refracted back into air. If the upper and lower surfaces of the transparent medium are parallel to each other, with thickness $e=1.0$ cm, the angle of incidence is $i_1=30^\circ$, and $|SA|=|BC|=5$ cm.

How many complete dark rings can be seen in the entire oil film?

As shown in the figure, a drop of oil falls on a flat glass plate, forming an oil film whose upper surface is approximately spherical. It is known that the refractive index of the oil film is $n_2 = 1.2$, the thickness of the oil film at the center is $e_{\text{m}} = 1.2\ \mu\text{m}$, and the refractive index of the glass is $n_3 = 1.5$. If monochromatic parallel light with wavelength $\lambda = 550\ \text{nm}$ is incident perpendicularly on the oil film.

Find the minimum thickness $e_0$ of the anti-reflection coating.

As shown in the figure, this is a GaAs light-emitting diode. To increase the output optical power, a layer of anti-reflection coating with a refractive index of $n_2=1.38$ is coated on its hemispherical inner surface. It is known that the wavelength of light emitted by GaAs is $\lambda=930 \text{ nm}$ and its refractive index is $n_1=3.4$.

Find the time required to reach the position corresponding to point P from the start of the vibration.

The vibration curve of a vibrating particle is shown in the figure.

Find the maximum tension in the steel cable caused by the vibration of the heavy object.

As shown in the figure, for the lifting equipment, the mass of the heavy object is $1.5 \times 10^4$ kg. When the heavy object is lowering uniformly at a speed of $v = 15$ m/min, the machine malfunctions, and the steel cable is suddenly stopped. At this time, the steel cable is equivalent to a spring with a stiffness coefficient $k = 5.78 \times 10^6$ N/m.

Find the equation of motion of the plate. (Take the equilibrium position after the object lands on the plate as the origin of the coordinate system, with downward displacement being positive.)

A plate of mass M is attached to the lower end of a vertically suspended light spring with spring constant k (as shown in the figure). An object of mass m falls freely from a height h above the plate and lands on the plate without rebounding. Taking the instant the object lands on the plate as the origin of time.

If it undergoes simple harmonic motion, what is its period?

As shown in the figure, two rollers with parallel axes are placed a distance 2d apart. They rotate at the same speed in opposite directions. A uniform wooden plank of mass m is placed on the two rollers. The coefficient of friction between the plank and both rollers is μ.

When the pendulum undergo small oscillations, find the periods

A pendulums are made of a light rod of length $l$ and a uniform circular disk of radius $r$.  The disk is rigidly connected to the rod as shown in figure.

When the pendulum undergo small oscillations, find the periods

A pendulums are made of a light rod of length $l$ and a uniform circular disk of radius $r$. The disk is mounted on a smooth pivot at the end of the rod, allowing it to rotate freely relative to it as shown in figure.

Find the period of oscillation of the object.

As shown in the figure, one end of a light spring is fixed, and the other end is attached to a light string. The light string passes over a pulley and is connected to an object of mass $m$. The string does not slip on the pulley, allowing the object to oscillate freely up and down. The spring constant is known to be $k$, the radius of the pulley is $R$, and its moment of inertia is $J$.

Find the distance of point P from point O.

Given a plane cosine wave propagating along the positive x-axis, its waveform at $t = \frac{1}{3} s$ is shown in the figure, and the period is $T = 2 s$.

Write the equation for this wave.

A plane simple harmonic wave has its waveform at $t=0$ shown in the figure, and the wave speed $u=0.08 \text{ m/s}$.

Write the wave equation with point $a$ as the coordinate origin.

A plane wave propagates in a medium with velocity $u = 20 \text{ m/s}$ along the negative x-axis direction. The oscillation equation for point $a$ is known to be $y_a = 3\cos 4\pi t$, where the unit of $t$ is s and the unit of $y$ is m.

Find the oscillation equation for point P.

A simple harmonic wave propagates along the positive x-axis. The waveform at $t_1 = 0$ and $t_2 = 0.25 \text{ s}$ is shown in the figure.

Find the wavelength of the wave emitted by the wave source S.

The distance between the wave source S on the ground and the high-frequency wave detector D is $d$. The wave directly emitted from S and the wave emitted from S and reflected by a horizontal layer at height H interfere constructively at D. The angle of reflection and the angle of incidence with the horizontal layer are the same. When the horizontal layer is gradually raised by a distance $h$, no signal is detected at D. Neglect atmospheric absorption.

If $S_2P = 4\lambda$, $S_1P = S_3P = 5\lambda$ (where $\lambda$ is the wavelength), find the equation for the combined oscillation at point P (Assume the amplitude of each wave does not change during propagation).

As shown in the figure, three simple harmonic waves with the same frequency and the same oscillation direction (perpendicular to the plane of the paper) meet at point P during propagation. The oscillation equations for the three simple harmonic waves alone at S1, S2, and S3 are respectively:$y_1 = A \cos(\omega t + \frac{\pi}{2})$ $y_2 = A \cos(\omega t)$ $y_3 = A \cos(\omega t - \frac{\pi}{2})$

Find the frequency of the sound wave emitted by the source.

The figure shows a sound interferometer used to demonstrate sound wave interference. S is a loudspeaker, and D is a sound detector, such as an ear or microphone. The length of path SBD can be varied, but the path SAD is fixed. There is air in the interferometer, and it is known that the sound intensity at the first position of B is a minimum value of 100 units. When B is gradually moved to the second position, 0.0165 m away from the first position, the intensity is a maximum value of 900 units.

Find the equation for the combined oscillation of the particle at point Q, which is at a distance of $\frac{\lambda}{6}$ from the reflection surface.

A plane harmonic wave propagates along the positive x-axis. At $t=0$, the oscillation of the particle at the origin O is moving towards the negative direction after passing the equilibrium position. There is a reflection surface from a denser medium at a distance $x_0 = \frac{11}{4}\lambda$ from the origin O, and the wave is reflected perpendicularly by the interface. Assume the amplitudes of both the incident wave and the reflected wave are A, and the frequency is $\nu$.

Find the velocity $v_s$ of the sound source. Assume the speed of sound is 340 m/s.

A sound source S (with an emitted frequency of 2040 Hz) approaches a reflecting surface with velocity $v_s$ (see figure). An observer at point A hears a beat frequency of $\Delta\nu = 3$ Hz.

If light rays are to propagate within the fiber, what is the maximum acceptance angle?

Let the refractive index of the core material of the optical fiber be $n_1$, the refractive index of the cladding material be $n_2 (n_1 > n_2)$, and the refractive index of the external medium outside the fiber be $n_0$.

Find the distance between the image of object PQ and the object (the surrounding medium of the slab is air).

There is a glass slab with a refractive index of 1.5 between the eye E and the object PQ, as shown in the figure. The thickness $d$ of the slab is 30 cm.

Calculate the position of the final image in air. (The refractive index of water is 1.33.)

A symmetric biconvex lens has radii of curvature of 3 cm for both surfaces, a central thickness of 2 cm as shown in figure, and is made of glass with a refractive index of 1.50. The lens is placed on the surface of water. An object Q is located 4 cm below the lens.

Find the angular position $\theta$ of the star when the antenna detects the first interference maximum.

A radio telescope antenna is set up on the shore of a lake at a height $h$ above the lake surface. A star is just rising above the horizon on the opposite shore. The star emits electromagnetic waves with wavelength $\lambda$.

Find the thickness of the $\text{SiO}_2$ thin film.

When manufacturing semiconductor devices, it is often necessary to accurately measure the thickness of the silicon dioxide ($\text{SiO}_2$) thin film on a silicon wafer. At this point, a portion of the silicon dioxide thin film can be etched away to form a wedge, and its thickness can be measured using interference fringes of equal thickness. It is known that the refractive index of Si is 3.42, and the refractive index of $\text{SiO}_2$ is 1.5. When illuminated perpendicularly with a helium-neon laser ($\lambda = 632.8 \text{ nm}$), 8 dark fringes are observed in the etched region in the reflected light.

How many bright fringes can be observed in total?

A cylindrical plano-concave lens A with radius of curvature R is placed on a flat glass plate B, as shown in the figure. Monochromatic parallel light with wavelength λ is incident perpendicularly from above to observe the interference fringes of reflected light from the air film between A and B. Assume the maximum thickness of the air film is d = 2λ.

Assume the wavelength of the normally incident light is λ = 589.3 nm, the separation between G₁ and G₂ is d = 5 cm, and the spacing of the interference fringes formed between T and G₁ and between T and G₂ is both 0.5 mm. Find the length difference between G₁ and G₂.

As shown in the figure, G₁ and G₂ are two gauge blocks (a gauge block is a steel rectangular block with two end faces ground and polished flat to be mutually parallel). G₁ has a standard length, and G₂ is a replicate of the same specification to be calibrated (the length difference between the two is exaggerated in the figure). G₁ and G₂ are placed on a platform and pressed down by a master flat glass plate T.

When the highest point at the center of the oil film is at a distance h = 1.2 μm from the upper surface of the glass plate (i.e., the thickness at the center is 1.2 μm), describe the observed fringe pattern. How many bright fringes can be seen?

An experimental setup is shown in the figure. An oil drop is placed on a flat glass plate. When the oil drop spreads into an oil film, the interference fringes formed by the oil film are observed in the reflected light under normal incidence of monochromatic light (wavelength λ = 600 nm) (observed with a reading microscope). The refractive index of the glass is known to be n₁ = 1.50, and the refractive index of the oil film is n₂ = 1.20.

Find the refractive index of this gas under standard conditions.

A Mach-Zehnder interferometer is commonly used to measure the refractive index of gases under various temperatures and pressures. The optical path of the interferometer is shown in the figure. S is the light source, L is the converging lens, G₁ and G₂ are two parallel glass plates of equal thickness, and T₁ and T₂ are two glass tubes of equal length, of length l.When performing the measurement, first evacuate T₁ and T₂, and then slowly introduce the gas to be measured into one tube. By observing the change in interference fringes at point E, the refractive index of the gas to be measured can be determined. For example, in a measurement of a certain gas, the gas is slowly introduced into tube T₂, and when the gas reaches standard conditions, a total of 98 interference fringes are observed to move at point E. The wavelength of the yellow light used is 589.3 nm (in vacuum), and l = 20 cm.

If the reflected light from the surface of the glass is also to be completely polarized, what should be the angle θ between the glass surface and the horizontal plane (water surface)?

As shown in the figure, a plane glass plate with refractive index n = 1.50 is immersed in water. It is known that when a beam of light is incident on the water surface, the reflected light is completely polarized.

Find the angle of incidence i. Given ne = 1.49 and no = 1.66.

A 60° equilateral triangular prism is cut from calcite, with its optical axis perpendicular to the equilateral triangular cross-section of the prism. Assume the angle of incidence of unpolarized light is i, and the refracted ray of the e-ray inside the prism is parallel to the base edge of the prism as shown in the figure.

For incident natural light, find the angle between the two emergent beams. Given no = 1.66 and ne = 1.49.

The Wollaston prism shown in the figure is composed of two 45° calcite prisms. The direction of the optical axis is as shown in the figure.

Write out the expression for the relationship between the initial angle of incidence θi and α.

As shown in Figure, a light ray is incident between mirrors and reflects n times, finally returning along its original path of incidence.

After $m$ reflections of the light ray within the tube, what is the incident angle?

As shown in Figure, a conical tube is given, with openings at both ends. The diameters of the openings are $R_1$ and $R_2$ respectively. The apex angle of the cone is $2\delta$. Light can be reflected between its inner walls. A ray of light enters from the larger opening, forming an angle of $\theta$ with the axis.

Calculate the minimum deviation angle.

Given the apex angle of the prism is $\alpha$, and the refractive index is $n$.

If the length of the large-headed pin exposed outside the wooden plug is measured as $h$, and the diameter of the wooden plug is $d$, find the refractive index of water.

A large-headed pin is vertically inserted into the center of a circular wooden plug. Then, it is placed upside down on the water surface, and the length of the large-headed pin exposed is adjusted. The observer cannot see the large-headed pin under the water surface from any angle on the water surface, as shown in Figure.

What is the incident angle $i$ when the deviation angle $\delta$ is at its minimum?

As shown in Figure, a ray of light enters a spherical water droplet with an incident angle $i$ and a refractive index of $n$.

By how much does it move?

As shown in Figure, a beam of light originally converging towards point $P$ passes through a glass plate before reaching point $P$. The glass plate is perpendicular to the beam's axis.

Determine the relationship between the optical path length $P_1O + OP_2$ and an arbitrary angle $\theta$.

Within a reflective sphere of radius $R$, points $P_1$ and $P_2$ are symmetrical with respect to the center of the sphere, and the distance from each point to the center of the sphere is $b$. Assume a light ray is emitted from $P_1$, reflected by the sphere's surface at point $O$, and then passes through point $P_2$, as shown in Figure.

Quantitatively derive the function $n(r)$, assuming the on-axis refractive index is $n_0$.

As shown in Figure, a microlens made of variable refractive index material is used to focus a parallel beam of light. Its refractive index is distributed symmetrically with respect to the radius. It is known that its focal length $f$ is much greater than the lens aperture $a$, and $a$ is also much greater than the thickness $d$.

The thickness $d$ of the glass.

As shown in Figure, the relationship between the refractive index and the height $y$ of a glass block with thickness $d$ is:$n(y) = \frac{n_0}{1 - \frac{y}{r_0}}$where $n_0 = 1.2$, $r_0 = 13 \text{ cm}$. A light ray enters along the x-axis from the origin. The angle of emergence at point A on the other side is $30^\circ$.

Find the refractive index of the transparent sphere material.

A point light source is located behind a transparent sphere. The paraxial light rays emitted from the front surface of the sphere are parallel as shown in figure.

Determine the the refractive index $n$ of water

A cylindrical glass beaker contains a metal cylindrical rod as shown in figure.  When observed from the outside of the beaker, the diameter of the rod is $D_1$ when there is no water in the beaker, and the diameter is $D_2$ when the beaker is filled with water.

If the shell is filled with water with a refractive index of $4/3$, what is the value of $L$ for which a clear image of the pinhole can be obtained on the white screen?

Two identical spherical thin-shell glass hemispheres are glued together, with air in between. One hemisphere's surface is silvered to act as a spherical mirror, as shown in Figure. Using the "pinhole method", the light from the light bulb passes through the pinhole on the white screen. Adjusting $L$, a clear image of the pinhole is obtained on the white screen, and it is measured that $L = 20 \text{ cm}$.

Determine the refractive index of the material of the sphere.

A retroreflector is an optical device that can reflect an incident light ray back along its original path. A retroreflector of the Sugden sphere type is made by silvering the rear hemisphere of a transparent spherical medium to create a reflective surface. By selecting an appropriate refractive index $n$, the incident light ray can be reflected back along its original path as shown in figure.

Calculate the position and real or virtual nature of the image formed by the combined eyepiece.

The structure of a modern binocular telescope is shown in Figure, which includes a pair of orthoscopic eyepieces, called a "Ramsden eyepiece". The image of a distant object formed by the objective lens is located a distance $s$ from the first eyepiece. The distance between the two opposite faces of the eyepiece is $\Delta$.

What is the distance from $L_2$ to the screen?

As shown in Figure, a converging lens $L_1$ and a diverging lens $L_2$ are used to construct a camera lens. It is known that the focal length of the converging lens is $f_1 = 10 \text{ cm}$. The distance from the image screen $P$ to $L_1$ is $d = 40 \text{ cm}$, and the distance from an object along the optical axis to $L_1$ is $s_1 = 30 \text{ cm}$. It is required to form a 3 times magnified image on $P$.

If a paraxial object is located $60 \text{ cm}$ to the left of $L_1$, determine the image's  lateral magnification.

As shown in Figure, a lens system is composed of a converging lens $L_1$ with a focal length of $20 \text{ cm}$ and a diverging lens $L_2$ with a focal length of $-10 \text{ cm}$. The distance between the two lenses is $15 \text{ cm}$, and the entire optical system satisfies the paraxial approximation.

If the observer above the lens (looking through the lens) sees the coin still at its original position, where should the lens be placed, relative to the water surface? (Given that the refractive index of water is 4/3, and neglect the thickness of the coin).

A beaker contains water with a depth of $4 \text{ cm}$ as shown in figure. There is a coin at the bottom of the beaker, and a thin lens with a focal length of $30 \text{ cm}$ is placed on the water surface. The center of the coin is on the optical axis of the lens.

Calculate the focal length of the concave lens.

he focal length of a concave lens can be measured using a converging lens and a plane mirror. The method is as follows: First, let a point light source $Q$ form a real image at point $Q'$ through the concave lens, and measure the image distance $s'$. Then, place the concave lens to be measured between the concave lens and $Q'$. The concave lens and the concave lens are coaxial, and a plane mirror is placed on the right side of the concave lens, along the optical axis, as shown in Figure. Move the concave lens to a suitable position, so that $Q$ is superimposed on its own image formed by the entire optical system. Measure the distance $d$ between the concave lens and the concave lens.

Use the given data to calculate the refractive index $n$ of the glass hemisphere (only paraxial rays are considered in the calculation).

A glass hemisphere with a radius of $R = 0.128 \text{ m}$ is given. The straight line passing through the center $O$ of the sphere and perpendicular to the flat surface is its principal axis. A thin, luminous bar $AB$ (with $B$ closer to the center $O$) with length $l = 0.020 \text{ m}$ is placed along the principal axis. If an eye is placed near the principal axis and looks towards the flat surface of the hemisphere (as shown in Figure), two dim images of the luminous bar can be seen (in addition, there may be weaker images that need not be considered). When the luminous bar moves along the principal axis, these two images also move along the principal axis. Now adjust the position of the luminous bar to make its two images coincide. At this time, the distance from the near end $B$ of the luminous bar to the center $O$ is $a_2 = 0.020 \text{ m}$.

To ensure the image is once again sharply focused on the photographic plate, by what distance must the plate be moved?

An object at $2.28 \text{ m}$ in front of the camera lens $L$ is sharply imaged on the photographic plate $P$, which is $12.0 \text{ cm}$ behind the lens. Now, a parallel glass plate with a refractive index of 1.50 and a thickness of $AB = 0.90 \text{ cm}$ is inserted between the lens and the photographic plate, and the glass plate is perpendicular to the optical axis, as shown in Figure. Assume that the camera lens can be regarded as a simple thin convex lens, and the light rays are paraxial rays.

If $\overline{PO_2} = \overline{O_2Q}$, then what is the distance between the object $P$ and lens $L_1$?

Three thin lenses $L_1$, $L_2$, and $L_3$ with the same focal length $f$ are, in order, a convex lens, a concave lens, and a convex lens. They form a coaxial optical system. The distance between adjacent lenses is $d$. The optical centers of each lens are $O_1$, $O_2$, and $O_3$, respectively, as shown in Figure.  A point object $P$ is located to the left of lens $L_1$ on the principal axis.  The final image of the object through this optical system is at point $Q$ to the right of lens $L_2$.

Now, keep the positions of $Q$, $L_1$, $L_4$, and $P$ unchanged, and translate $L_2$ and $L_3$ along the optical axis. The height of the inverted real image on the screen is 1.82 cm. Find the distance between $L_1$ and $L_2$.

As shown in Figure, $L_1$ is a thin convex lens, and $Q$ is a 2.00 cm tall linear object placed perpendicular to the optical axis. It is known that $Q$ forms an image through $L_1$, and the image distance is 40.0 cm. Now, in order from right to left of $L_1$, thin convex lenses $L_2$, $L_3$, $L_4$ and screen $P$ are placed, and the distances between them are as shown in the figure. All lenses are coaxial, and the screen is perpendicular to the optical axis. The magnitude of the focal length of $L_2$ and $L_3$ is 15.0 cm. It is known that the final image of $Q$ through the above four lenses is an inverted real image on the screen, and the image height is 0.500 cm.

Calculate the focal length of this lens.

The thin lens shown in Figure has surface radii of 15.00 cm (left) and 10.00 cm (right). The refractive index of the glass is known to be 1.5.

What is the magnification if an object with its tip pointing upwards, located 20 cm to the left of $L_1$, after passing through this system?

In the optical system shown in Figure, the focal length of the concave lens $L_1$ is $f_1 = -20$ cm, and the focal length of the convex lens $L_2$ is $f_2 = 30$ cm. The plane mirror $M$ makes an angle of $45^\circ$ with the optical axis of the two lenses, and their relative positions are marked in the figure.

Keeping the object and $L_1$ stationary, a thin concave lens $L_2$ with a focal length $f_2 = -20$ cm can be inserted after $L_1$ so that an image that is magnified by a factor of 2 is finally formed on the screen. What is the distance from $L_2$ to $L_1$?

As shown in Figure, a thin convex lens $L_1$ with a focal length $f_1 = 10$ cm has an image screen 15 cm to its right.

In the field of view of the telescope, the vertical length of the image of the target seen on the reticle is 12.0 mm. What is the actual height of the target?

Two thin lenses: the focal length of the convex lens is $f_1 = 10.00$ cm, and the focal length of the concave lens is $f_2 = -12.00$ cm. Each of the two lenses has a spherical surface with the same curvature and is cemented together with a transparent resin adhesive, used as the objective lens of a telescope. The focal length of the eyepiece of this telescope is $f_e = 4.00$ cm. Each lens barrel consists of a Wollaston prism combination composed of a pair of isosceles right-angled prisms. The length of the right-angle side is $a = 2.00$ cm, the refractive index is $n = 1.55$, the vertex angles of the prisms are in the correct direction, and the inclined surfaces are parallel to each other as shown in figure. The distance $\Delta = 2.18$ cm.

Use $n_g$ and $i'$ from the problem to represent the refractive index $n$ of the liquid.

The setup for measuring the refractive index of a liquid by the limit method is shown in Figure. ABC is a right-angled prism. Its refractive index $n_g$ is known. A thin layer of the liquid to be measured is coated on its upper surface AB, and a piece of frosted glass (light above the glass) is covered on the liquid. Use an extended light source to illuminate in the direction of incidence, and the refracted angle of the light emitted from the AC surface of the prism will have a lower limit $i'$. If observed with a telescope, a semi-bright and semi-dark area with an obvious dividing line will appear in the field of view.

What is the angle between the optical axis of the telescope and the horizontal plane at this time?

As shown in Figure, the optical system is composed of a collimator, a stage, and a telescope. It is known that the focal length of the telescope objective $L_o$ is 16.00 cm. A reticle with a crosshair and a bright cross is placed at the focal plane P of $L_o$, as shown in Figure 2.111. A double-sided parallel plane mirror M is placed on the stage. When observed through the eyepiece $L_e$ of the telescope, the crosshair on the reticle and the cross object can be seen clearly after refraction by $L_o$ and reflection by M, and then refraction again by $L_o$. The cross image is located at point A, and the distance from the crosshair is 5.2 mm. Rotate the stage (along the vertical direction) and rotate the plane mirror by 180°. At this time, the cross image is located at point B, and the distance from the crosshair is 18.8 mm.

Try to find the focal length.

As shown in Figure, the focal lengths of a biconvex thick lens for the front and rear refracting spherical surfaces are $f_1$, $f'_1$ and $f_2$, $f'_2$ respectively, and the thickness is $d$.
options: A: \( \frac{nn_L}{n_L - n} \cdot \frac{r_1 r_2}{(n_L - n)d - n_L r_1 - n_L r_2} \)
B: \( \frac{nn_L}{n_L - n} \cdot \frac{r_1 r_2}{(n_L - n)d - n_L r_1 + n_L r_2} \)
C: \( \frac{nn_L}{n_L + n} \cdot \frac{r_1 r_2}{(n_L - n)d - n_L r_1 + n_L r_2} \)
D: \( \frac{nn_L}{n_L - n} \cdot \frac{r_1 r_2}{(n_L - n)d + n_L r_1 + n_L r_2} \)

Given that the wavelength of light is 589.3 nm, the tube length is 20 cm, and 98 fringes have shifted, find the refractive index of air.

The structure and working principle of a Rayleigh interferometer are as follows (as shown in Figure): A sodium vapor lamp is used as the light source, placed in front of lens $L_1$. The changes in interference fringes are observed on the focal plane of lens $L_2$. Two identical glass tubes, $T_1$ and $T_2$, are placed between the two lenses. At the beginning of the experiment, $T_2$ is filled with air, and $T_1$ is evacuated to a vacuum. At this time, the interference fringes are observed. Then, air is gradually introduced into tube $T_1$ until the air pressure in $T_1$ and $T_2$ is the same. The number of fringes that have shifted during this process is recorded.

Find the fringe spacing $\Delta x$ on the screen

A monochromatic point source with a wavelength of 600.0 nm is placed on the left axis of this lens, and an observation screen is placed on the other side. During the observation of the interference fringes, it is found that the fringe spacing $\Delta x$ remains constant when the observation screen is moved along the axis.

The most efficient way to send a spacecraft from the earth to another planet is to use a \textit{Hohmann transfer orbit} . The diver thinks he sees something moving in the murky depths and jerks the end of the cable back and forth to send transverse waves up the cable as a signal to his companions in the boat.

What is the distance (labeled “?”) from the horn to the diver?

A submerged scuba diver hears the sound of a boat horn directly above her on the surface of the lake. At the same time, a friend on dry land \( 22.0\,\text{m} \) from the boat also hears the horn (\textbf{figure}). The horn is \( 1.2\,\text{m} \) above the surface of the water. Both air and water are at \( 20^{\circ}\text{C} \).

At what distance \( d \) will the sound from the speakers first produce destructive interference at the listener’s location?

Small speakers \( A \) and \( B \) are driven in phase at \( 725\,\text{Hz} \) by the same audio oscillator. Both speakers start out \( 4.50\,\text{m} \) from the listener, but speaker \( A \) is slowly moved away (\textbf{figure}).

What is the lowest frequency for which \textit{destructive} interference occurs at point \( Q \)?

Two loudspeakers, \( A \) and \( B \) (\textbf{figure}), are driven by the same amplifier and emit sinusoidal waves in phase. Speaker \( B \) is \( 2.00\,\text{m} \) to the right of speaker \( A \). Consider point \( Q \) along the extension of the line connecting the speakers, \( 1.00\,\text{m} \) to the right of speaker \( B \). Both speakers emit sound waves that travel directly from the speaker to point \( Q \).

What is the frequency from \( A \) as heard by the listener?

Two train whistles, \( A \) and \( B \), each have a frequency of \( 392\,\text{Hz} \). \( A \) is stationary and \( B \) is moving toward the right (away from \( A \)) at a speed of \( 35.0\,\text{m/s} \). A listener is between the two whistles and is moving toward the right with a speed of \( 15.0\,\text{m/s} \) (\textbf{figure}). No wind is blowing.

If both of them are simultaneously plucked at the center, what is the frequency of the beats that they will produce when vibrating in their fundamental?

A uniform \( 165\,\text{N} \) bar is supported horizontally by two identical wires \( A \) and \( B \) (\textbf{figure}). A small \( 185\,\text{N} \) cube of lead is placed three-fourths of the way from \( A \) to \( B \). The wires are each \( 75.0\,\text{cm} \) long and have a mass of \( 5.50\,\text{g} \).

If the frequency is made low enough, there will be no positions along the line \( BC \) at which destructive interference occurs. How low must the frequency be for this to be the case?

Two identical loudspeakers are located at points \( A \) and \( B \), \( 2.00\,\text{m} \) apart. The loudspeakers are driven by the same amplifier and produce sound waves with a frequency of \( 784\,\text{Hz} \). Take the speed of sound in air to be \( 344\,\text{m/s} \). A small microphone is moved out from point \( B \) along a line perpendicular to the line connecting \( A \) and \( B \) (line \( BC \) in \textbf{figure}).

What is the length \( L_2 \) of the steel section?

A long rod, insulated to prevent heat loss along its sides, is in perfect thermal contact with boiling water (at atmospheric pressure) at one end and with an ice–water mixture at the other (	extbf{figure}). The rod consists of a \( 1.00\,\text{m} \) section of copper (one end in boiling water) joined end to end to a length \( L_2 \) of steel (one end in the ice–water mixture). Both sections of the rod have cross-sectional areas of \( 4.00\,\text{cm}^2 \). The temperature of the copper–steel junction is \( 65.0^{\circ}\text{C} \) after a steady state has been set up.

Calculate the heat of reaction of the two chemicals (in J/kg).

The African bombardier beetle (\textit{Stenaptinus insignis}) can emit a jet of defensive spray from the movable tip of its abdomen. The beetle’s body has reservoirs containing two chemicals; when the beetle is disturbed, these chemicals combine in a reaction chamber, producing a compound that is warmed from 20\,^{\circ}\text{C} to 100\,^{\circ}\text{C} by the heat of reaction. The high pressure produced allows the compound to be sprayed out at speeds up to 19\,\text{m/s} (68\,\text{km/h}), scaring away predators of all kinds. (The beetle shown in \textbf{figure} is 2\,\text{cm} long.) Assume that the specific heat of the chemicals and of the spray is the same as that of water, 4.19 \times 10^3\,\text{J/kg·K}, and that the initial temperature of the chemicals is 20\,^{\circ}\text{C}.

If the temperature of the gas is kept constant and no gas escapes from the tank, what distance above the bottom of the tank is the disk when it again comes to rest?

In an evacuated enclosure, a vertical cylindrical tank of diameter $D$ is sealed by a 3.00\,kg circular disk that can move up and down without friction. Beneath the disk is a quantity of ideal gas at temperature $T$ in the cylinder (\textbf{figure}). Initially the disk is at rest at a distance of $h = 4.00$\,m above the bottom of the tank. When a lead brick of mass 9.00\,kg is gently placed on the disk, the disk moves downward.

At what value of $h$ does the flow stop?

A large tank of water has a hose connected to it. The tank is sealed at the top and has compressed air between the water surface and the top. When the water height $h$ has the value 3.50\,m, the absolute pressure $p$ of the compressed air is $4.20 \times 10^5$\,Pa. Assume that the air above the water expands at constant temperature, and take the atmospheric pressure to be $1.00 \times 10^5$\,Pa. As water flows out of the tank, $h$ decreases.

If the air pressure is 0.1 MPa in the cylinder as the bullet leaves the gun

Find the heat transfer when T2 = −20\circ\text{C}.

A piston/cylinder contains 0.5 m^3 of R-410a at 2 MPa, 150\circ\text{C}. The piston mass and atmosphere give a pressure of 450 kPa that will float the piston. The whole setup cools in a freezer maintained at−20\circ\text{C}.

Find the heat transfer.

Ten kilograms of water in a piston/cylinder arrangement exists as saturated liquid/vapor at 100 kPa,with a quality of 50%. The system is now heated so that the volume triples. The mass of the piston is such that a cylinder pressure of 200 kPa will float it.

A vertical cylinder fitted with a piston contains 5 kg of R-410a at 10\circ\text{C}. Heat is transferred to the system, causing the piston to rise until it reaches a set of stops, at which point the volume has doubled. Additional heat is transferred until the temperature inside reaches 50\circ\text{C}, at which point the pressure inside the cylinder is 1.4 MPa.

Find the heat transfer.

Water in a piston/cylinder is at 101 kPa, 25\circ\text{C}, and mass 0.5 kg. The piston rests on some stops, and the pressure should be 1000 kPa to float the piston. We now heat the water, so the piston just reaches the end of the cylinder.

Find the heat transfer.

The piston/cylinder contains 0.1 kg R-410a at 600 kPa, 60\circ\text{C}. It is now cooled, so the volume is reduced to half of the initial volume. The piston has upper stops mounted, and the piston mass and gravitation are such that a floating pressure is 400 kPa.

The piston/cylinder arrangement contains 10 g ammonia at 20\circ\text{C} with a volume of 1 L. There are some stops, so if the piston is at the stops, the volume is 1.4 L. The ammonia is now heated to 200\circ\text{C}. The piston and cylinder are made of 0.5 kg aluminum. Assume that the mass has the same temperature as the ammonia at any time.

Find the heat transfer.

Air in a piston/cylinder assembly at 200 kPa and 600 K is expanded in a constant-pressure process to twice the initial volume, state 2. The piston is then locked with a pin, and heat is transferred to a final temperature of 600 K.

Find the heat transfer.

A piston/cylinder has 0.5 kg of air at 2000 kPa, 1000 K. The cylinder has stops, so Vmin =0.03 m^3. The air now cools to 400 K by heat transfer to the ambient.

Neglect the rubber mass and find the surface tension near the ring.

Find the heat transfer.

A rigid tank is divided into two rooms, both containing water, by a membrane. Room A is at 200 kPa, v = 0.5 m^3/kg, VA = 1 m^3, and room B contains 3.5 kg at 0.5 MPa, 400\circ\text{C}. Find the heat transfer.

Find the heat transfer.

Find the heat transfer.

Find the heat transfer.

what is the exit temperature?

If the total waste energy is 5 MW, find the rate of energy delivered at the high temperature.

Determine the fraction of steam that has escaped when the final state inside is saturated vapor.

Thermal storage is made with a rock (granite) bed of 2 m^3 that is heated to 400 K using solar energy. A heat engine receives a Q_H from the bed and rejects heat to the ambient at 290 K. The rock bed therefore cools down, and as it reaches 290 K the process stops.

If the pressure should be 120 kPa as the bullet leaves the cylinder, find the work done by the air.

Consider a small air pistol with a cylinder volume of 1 cm3 at 250 kPa, 27\circ\text{C}. The bullet acts as a piston initially held by a trigger. The bullet is released, so the air expands in an adiabatic process.

Find the final temperature.

If the cylinder is insulated, how much work is done by the air inside?

A piston/cylinder contains air at 1380 K, 15 MPa, with V_1 =10 cm^3, A_cyl = 5 cm2. The piston is released, and just before the piston exits the end of the cylinder, the pressure inside is 200 kPa.

Find the work input to the heat pump, assuming constant heat capacities.

Two rigid tanks, each contains 10 kg N2 gas at 1000 K, 500 kPa. They are now thermally connected to a reversible heat pump, which heats one tank and cools the other, with no heat transfer to the surroundings. When one tank is heated to 1500 K, the process stops.

Find the work output of the heat engine.

A rigid tank contains 4 kg air at 300\circ\text{C}, 4 MPa that acts as the hot energy reservoir for a heat engine with its cold side at 20\circ\text{C}. Heat transfer to the heat engine cools the air down in a reversible process to a final 20\circ\text{C} and then stops.

Calculate the heat transfer for the process.

The power stroke in an internal combustion engine can be approximated with a polytropic expansion. Consider air in a cylinder volume of 0.2 L at 7 MPa, 1800 K. It now expands in a reversible polytropic process with exponent n = 1.5 through a volume ratio of 10:1.

Determine the entropy generation in CV2.

Consider a heat transfer of 100 kJ from 1500 K hot gases to a steel container at 750 K that has a heat transfer of the 100 kJ out to some air at 375 K.

Find the entropy generation for the process.

A piston/cylinder device keeping a constant pressure has 1 kg water at 20\circ\text{C} and 1 kg of water at 100\circ\text{C}, both at 500 kPa separated by a thin membrane. The membrane is broken and the water comes to a uniform state, with no external heat transfer.

Find the entropy generation for the process.

A piston/cylinder has ammonia at 2000 kPa, 80\circ\text{C} with a volume of 0.1 m3. The piston is loaded with a linear spring and outside ambient is at 20\circ\text{C}. The ammonia now cools down to 20\circ\text{C}, at which point it has a quality of 15%.

Find the entropy generation for the process.

A piston/cylinder of total 1 kg steel contains 0.5 kg ammonia at 1600 kPa, both masses at 120\circ\text{C}. Some stops are placed that so a minimum volume is 0.02 m^3. Now the whole system is cooled down to 30\circ\text{C} by heat transfer to the ambient at 20\circ\text{C}, and during the process the steel keeps the same temperature as the ammonia.

Find the entropy generation for the process.

A cylinder/piston arrangement contains 10 g ammonia at 20\circ\text{C} with a volume of 1 L. There are some stops, so if the piston is at the stops, the volume is 1.4 L. The ammonia is now heated to 200\circ\text{C} by a 240◦C source. The piston and cylinder are made of 0.5 kg aluminum, and assume that the mass has the same temperature as the ammonia at any time.

Find the entropy generation for the process.

A rigid container with volume 200 L is divided into two equal volumes by a partition. Both sides contain nitrogen; one side is at 2 MPa, 200\circ\text{C} and the other at 200 kPa, 100\circ\text{C}. The partition ruptures, and the nitrogen comes to a uniform state at 70\circ\text{C}. Assume the temperature of the surroundings is 20\circ\text{C}.

Find the entropy generation this process causes.

Nitrogen at 600 kPa, 127\circ\text{C} is in a 0.5-m^3 insulated tank connected to a pipe with a valve to a second insulated initially empty tank of volume 0.25 m^3. The valve is opened, and the nitrogen fills both tanks at a uniform state.

Find the rate(s) of entropy generation.

Room air at 23\circ\text{C} is heated by a 2000-W space heater with a surface filament temperature of 700 K. The room at steady state loses the power to the outside which is at 7\circ\text{C}.

Find the total entropy generated in the process.

Water in a piston/cylinder is at 1 MPa, 500\circ\text{C}. There are two stops, a lower one at which Vmin = 1 m^3 and an upper one at Vmax = 3 m^3. The piston is loaded with a mass and outside atmosphere such that it floats when the pressure is 500 kPa. This setup is now cooled to 100\circ\text{C} by rejecting heat to the surrounding at 20\circ\text{C}.

Find the total entropy generation, assuming no heat transfer.

Two tanks contain steam and they are both connected to a piston/cylinder. Initially the piston is at the bottom, and the mass of the piston is such that a pressure of 1.4 MPa below it will be able to lift it. Stream in A is 4 kg at 7 MPa, 700\circ\text{C} and B has 2 kg at 3 MPa, 350\circ\text{C}. The two valves are opened, and the water comes to a uniform state.

Find the work output of the heat engine.

A rigid tank with 0.5 kg ammonia at 1600 kPa, 160\circ\text{C} is cooled in a reversible process by giving heat to a reversible heat engine that has its cold side at ambient temperature, 20\circ\text{C}. The ammonia eventually reaches 20\circ\text{C} and the process stops.

Find the maximum pressure possible.

Atmospheric air at−45\circ\text{C}, 60 kPa enters the front diffuser of a jet engine with a velocity of 900 km/h and a frontal area of 1 m^2. After adiabatic diffuser process, the velocity is 20 m/s.

Assume everything is reversible and find the rate of work input.

A flow of 2 kg/s saturated vapor R-410a at 500 kPa is heated at constant pressure to 60\circ\text{C}. The heat is supplied by a heat pump that receives heat from the ambient at 300 K and work input.

Find the rate of work produced.

A reversible steady-state device receives a flow of 1 kg/s air at 400 K, 450 kPa and the air leaves at 600 K, 100 kPa. Heat transfer of 900 kW is added from a 1000 K reservoir, 50 kW is rejected at 350 K, and some heat transfer takes place at 500 K.

Assuming the expansion inside the turbine is reversible and adiabatic, determine the specific turbine work (part-load) if it is throttled to 500 kPa.

One technique for operating a steam turbine in part load power output is to throttle the steam to a lower pressure before it enters the turbine. The steamline conditions are 2 MPa, 400\circ\text{C}, and the turbine exhaust pressure is fixed at 10 kPa.

Find the compressor exit pressure.

A turbocharger boosts the inlet air pressure to an automobile engine. It consists of an exhaust gasdriven turbine directly connected to an air compressor. For a certain engine load the conditions are given in the figure. Assume that both the turbine and the compressor are reversible and adiabatic, having also the same mass flow rate.

If this pressure is required to be 200 kPa, what must the temperature be at the exit of the heater?

A heat-powered portable air compressor consists of three components: (a) an adiabatic compressor, (b) a constant-pressure heater (heat supplied from an outside source), and (c) an adiabatic turbine. Ambient air enters the compressor at 100 kPa, 300 K and is compressed to 600 kPa. All of the power from the turbine goes into the compressor, and the turbine exhaust is the supply of compressed air.

Calculate the required steam inlet pressure, assuming that both the turbine and the compressor are reversible and adiabatic.

A certain industrial process requires a steady supply of saturated vapor steam at 200 kPa at a rate of 0.5 kg/s. Also required is a steady supply of compressed air at 500 kPa at a rate of 0.1 kg/s. Both are to be supplied by the process shown in figure. Steam is expanded in a turbine to supply the power needed to drive the air compressor, and the exhaust steam exits the turbine at the desired state. Air into the compressor is at the ambient condition, 100 kPa, 20\circ\text{C}.

Using a reversible compressor, determine the rate of heat rejection in the aftercooler.

A certain industrial process requires a steady 0.75 kg/s supply of compressed air at 500 kPa at a maximum temperature of 30\circ\text{C}. This air is to be supplied by installing a compressor and an aftercooler. Local ambient conditions are 100 kPa, 20\circ\text{C}.

Calculate the thermal efficiency of the cycle.

Consider a steam turbine power plant operating near critical pressure. As a first approximation, it may be assumed that the turbine and the pump processes are reversible and adiabatic. Neglecting any changes in kinetic and potential energies.

Find the spray velocity.

A small pump is driven by a 2-kW motor with liquid water at 150 kPa, 10\circ\text{C} entering. The exit flow goes through a small hole in a spray nozzle out to the atmosphere at 100 kPa.

If the turbine exhausts to 100 kPa with negligible kinetic energy, what is the rate of work?

A pipe in a small dam, of 0.5 m diameter, carries liquid water at 150 kPa, 20\circ\text{C} with a flow rate of 2000 kg/s. The pipe runs to the bottom of the dam 15 m lower into a turbine with a pipe diameter of 0.35 m. Assume no friction or heat transfer in the pipe and find the pressure of the turbine inlet.

Find the stagnation pressure

Air flow at 100 kPa, 290 K, 100 m/s is directed toward a wall. At the wall the flow stagnates (comes to zero velocity) without any heat transfer.

Find the rate of entropy generation in the flash evaporator.

A geothermal supply of hot water at 500 kPa, 150\circ\text{C} is fed to an insulated flash evaporator at the rate of 1.5 kg/s. A stream of saturated liquid at 200 kPa is drained from the bottom of the chamber and a stream of saturated vapor at 200 kPa is drawn from the top and fed to a turbine.

What is the total entropy generation in the process?

A mixing chamber receives 5 kg/min ammonia as saturated liquid at−20\circ\text{C} from one line and ammonia at 40\circ\text{C}, 250 kPa from another line through a valve. The chamber also receives 325 kJ/min energy as heat transferred from a 40\circ\text{C} reservoir. This should produce saturated ammonia vapor at−20\circ\text{C} in the exit line.

Find the total rate of entropy generation when the condenser exit is saturated liquid.

A condenser in a power plant receives 5 kg/s steam at 15 kPa, quality 90% and rejects the heat to cooling water with an average temperature of 17\circ\text{C}.

Find the exit velocity of the nozzle.

A large supply line has a steady flow of R-410a at 1000 kPa, 60\circ\text{C}. It is used in three different adiabatic devices: a throttle flow, an ideal nozzle, and an ideal turbine. All the exit flows are at 300 kPa.

What is the total rate of entropy generation?

A counterflowing heat exchanger has one line with 2 kg/s at 125 kPa, 1000 K entering, and the air is leaving at 100 kPa, 400 K. The other line has 0.5 kg/s water coming in at 200 kPa, 20\circ\text{C} and leaving at 200 kPa.

What is the ratio of the mass flow rate to the turbine to the total exit flow?

In a heat-driven refrigerator with ammonia as the working fluid, a turbine with inlet conditions of 2.0 MPa, 70\circ\text{C} is used to drive a compressor with inlet saturated vapor at−20\circ\text{C}. The exhausts, both at 1.2 MPa, are then mixed together.

Calculate the rate of net entropy increase for the process, assuming the process to be steady flow and adiabatic.

One type of feedwater heater for preheating the water before entering a boiler operates on the principle of mixing the water with steam that has been bled from the turbine.

Use constant heat capacities and find the total rate of entropy generation.

A coflowing (same direction) heat exchanger has one line with 0.5 kg/s oxygen at 17\circ\text{C}, 200 kPa entering, and the other line has 0.6 kg/s nitrogen at 150 kPa, 500 K entering. The heat exchanger is very long, so the two flows exit at the same temperature.

Calculate the total entropy generation in the process.

A 1-m^3 rigid tank contains 100 kg R-410a at a temperature of 15\circ\text{C}. A valve on top of the tank is opened, and saturated vapor is throttled to ambient pressure, 100 kPa and flows to a collector system. During the process, the temperature inside the tank remains at 15\circ\text{C} by heat transfer from the 20\circ\text{C} ambient. The valve is closed when no more liquid remains inside.

How much power is needed to drive the pump?

An emergency drain pump should be able to pump 0.1 m^3/s liquid water at 15\circ\text{C}, 10 m vertically up, delivering it with a velocity of 20 m/s. It is estimated that the pump, pipe, and nozzle have a combined isentropic efficiency expressed for the pump as 60%.

Find T_5 (x5 if in two-phase region) if the turbine and the compressor are reversible and adiabatic.

In a heat-powered refrigerator, a turbine is used to drive the compressor using the same working fluid. Consider the combination where the turbine produces just enough power to drive the compressor and the two exit flows are mixed together.

Find the total rate of entropy generation.

A flow of nitrogen, 0.1 kg/s, comes out of a compressor stage at 500 kPa, 500 K and is now cooled to 310 K in a counterflowing intercooler by liquid water at 125 kPa, 15\circ\text{C} that leaves at 22\circ\text{C}.

Determine q_H.

The conditions are as shown in the figure. Assume that the properties of salt water are the same as those of pure water, and that the pump is reversible and adiabatic.

Determine the discharge temperature of the jet pump if its efficiency is 10%.

A jet-ejector pump is a device in which a low-pressure (secondary) fluid is compressed by entrainment in a high-velocity (primary) fluid stream. The compression results from the deceleration in a diffuser. For purposes of analysis, this can be considered as equivalent to the turbine-compressor unit. Consider a steam jet pump with state 1 as saturated vapor at 35 kPa; state 3 is 300 kPa, 150◦C; and the discharge pressure, P_5, is 100 kPa.

Use constant heat capacity to verify that the final temperature is 645 K, and find the total entropy generation.

A horizontal insulated cylinder has a frictionless piston held against stops by an external force of 500 kN. The piston crosssectional area is 0.5 m^2, and the initial volume is 0.25 m^3. Argon gas in the cylinder is at 200 kPa, 100\circ\text{C}. A valve is now opened to a line flowing argon at 1.2 MPa, 200\circ\text{C}, and gas flows in until the cylinder pressure just balances the external force, at which point the valve is closed.

Assuming constant specific heat, solve the exit temperature by iterations.

Air flows through a constant-pressure heating device. It is heated up in a reversible process with a work input of 200 kJ/kg air flowing. The device exchanges heat with the ambient at 300 K. The air enters at 300 K, 400 kPa.

Find the power the engine can produce.

An air flow of 5 kg/min at 1500 K, 125 kPa goes through a constant-pressure heat exchanger, giving energy to a heat engine. The air exits at 500 K, and the ambient is at 298 K, 100 kPa.

How fast the basement can be emptied?

A basement is flooded with 16 m^3 of water at 15\circ\text{C}. It is pumped out with a small pump driven by a 0.75 kW electric motor. The hose can reach 8 m vertically up, and to ensure that the water can flow over the edge of a dike, it should have a velocity of 20 m/s at that point generated by a nozzle.

Determine the temperature of the air entering the engine.

Air enters the turbocharger compressor of an automotive engine at 100 kPa, 30\circ\text{C} and exits at 200 kPa. The air is cooled by 50\circ\text{C} in an intercooler before entering the engine. The isentropic efficiency of the compressor is 75%.

Find the irreversibility rate.

A geothermal source provides 10 kg/s of hot water at 500 kPa, 145\circ\text{C} flowing into a flash evaporator that separates vapor and liquid at 200 kPa.

If the heat pump receives 40 kW of work, find the increase in specific exergy of the water.

Water as saturated liquid at 200 kPa goes through a constant-pressure heat exchanger. The heat input is supplied from a reversible heat pump extracting heat from the surroundings at 17\circ\text{C}. The water flow rate is 2 kg/min and the whole process is reversible; that is, there is no overall net entropy change.

What is the exergy destruction in the wall?

Evaluate the steady-state exergy fluxes due to a heat transfer of 50 W through a wall with 600 K on one side and 400 K on the other side.

Find the second-law efficiencies.

Air flows into a heat engine at ambient conditions of 100 kPa, 300 K. Energy is supplied as 1200 kJ per kilogram of air from a 1500 K source, and in some part of the process a heat transfer loss of 300 kJ/kg air occurs at 750 K. The air leaves the engine at 100 kPa, 800 K.

Calculate the thermal efficiency of the heat engine.

The high-temperature heat source for a cyclic heat engine is a steady-flow heat exchanger where R-134a enters at 80\circ\text{C}, saturated vapor, and exits at 80\circ\text{C}, saturated liquid, at a flow rate of 5 kg/s. Heat is rejected from the heat engine to a steady-flow heat exchanger, where air enters at 150 kPa and ambient temperature 20\circ\text{C} and exits at 125 kPa, 70\circ\text{C}. The rate of irreversibility for the overall process is 175 kW.

Find the total irreversibility in the process, assuming the surroundings are at 20\circ\text{C}.

Air in a piston/cylinder arrangement is at 200 kPa, 300 K with a volume of 0.5 m^3. If the piston is at the stops, the volume is 1 m^3 and a pressure of 400 kPa is required. The air is then heated from the initial state to 1500 K by a 1700 K reservoir.

Find the stagnation pressure.

A jet of air at 200 m/s flows at 25\circ\text{C}, 100 kPa toward a wall, where the jet flow stagnates and leaves at very low velocity. Consider the process to be adiabatic and reversible.

String 1 has linear density 2.0 g/m and string 2 has linear density 4.0 g/m. A student sends pulses in both directions by quickly pulling up on the knot, then releasing it.

At this instant, what is the velocity of points 1 on the string?

The figure shows a snapshot graph of a wave traveling to the right along a string at 45 m/s.

What is mass m?

The figure shows two masses hanging from a steel wire. The mass of the wire is 60.0 g. A wave pulse travels along the wire from point 1 to point 2 in 24.0 ms.

How many wavelengths (complete cycles) of the wave are in this 2.00-m-long section of the wire?

A wire is made by welding together two metals having different densities. The figure shows a 2.00-m-long section of wire centered on the junction, but the wire extends much farther in both directions. The wire is placed under 2250 N tension, then a 1500 Hz wave with an amplitude of 3.00 mm is sent down the wire.

At what time was the snapshot graph (b) taken?

Graph (a) is a snapshot graph at t = 0 s of two waves approaching each other at 1.0 m/s.

What is the speed of sound in this gas?
