What is the fundamental frequency of the steel wire?

What Microwaves frequencies between 10 GHz and 12 GHz will create standing waves in the cavity?

Microwaves pass through a small hole into the “microwave cavity”.

What is the frequency of the tuning fork?

The 40-cm-long tube has a 40-cm-long insert that can be pulled in and out. A vibrating tuning fork is held next to the tube. As the insert is slowly pulled out, the sound from the tuning fork creates standing waves in the tube when the total length L is 42.5 cm, 56.7 cm, and 70.9 cm. Assume \v_{sound}\ = 343 m/s.

As you begin to walk directly away from the speaker, what is the smallest distances from the speaker do you hear a minimum sound intensity?

You are standing 2.5 m directly in front of one of the two loudspeakers. They are 3.0 m apart and both are playing a 686 Hz tone in phase.  The room temperature is 20 \circ\text{C}.

When the amplitude is maximum, by what factor is the sound intensity greater than the sound intensity from a single speaker?

The three identical loudspeakers play a 170 Hz tone in a room where the speed of sound is 340 m/s. You are standing 4.0 m in front of the middle speaker. At this point, the amplitude of the wave from each speaker is \text{a}.

What is the smallest slide extensions \text{s} that will make the microphone detect a maximum of sound intensity?

A 280 Hz sound wave is directed into one end of the trombone slide. A microphone is placed at the other end to record the intensity of sound waves that are transmitted through the tube. The straight sides of the slide are 80 cm in length and 10 cm apart with a semicircular bend at the end.

What is the spacing (in mm) between the slits?

Light of 600 nm wavelength illuminates a double slit. The intensity pattern is seen on a screen 2.0 m behind the slits.

What is the width (in mm) of the slit?

Light of 600 nm wavelength illuminates a single slit. The intensity pattern is seen on a screen 2.0 m behind the slits.

If the aperture is a double slit, what is the spacing between the slits?

The figure shows the light intensity on a screen 2.5 m behind an aperture. The aperture is illuminated with light of wave length 600 nm.

What is the speed of the wave?

Figure A shows the waveform of a sinusoidal transverse wave at \( t = 0.20\,\mathrm{s} \). Point \( P \) is a particle whose equilibrium position is at \( x = 1.0\,\mathrm{m} \), point \( Q \) is at \( x = 4.0\,\mathrm{m} \), and point \( M \) is at \( x = 8.0\,\mathrm{m} \). Figure B shows the vibration graph of particle \( M \).

What is the distance from the slits to the screen?

The figure shows the light intensity on a screen behind a double slit. The slit spacing is 0.20 mm and the wavelength of the light is 600 nm.

What is the wavelength (in nm) of the light?

The figure shows the interference pattern on a screen 1.0 m behind an 800 line/mm diffraction grating.

If the melanin lines on the wing are spaced 2.0 mm apart, what is the first-order diffraction angle for green light (l= 550 nm)?

The wings of some beetles have closely spaced parallel lines of melanin, causing the wing to act as a reflection grating. Suppose sunlight shines straight onto a beetle wing.

What is the wavelength (in nm) of the light?

The figure shows the light intensity on a screen behind a single slit. The slit width is 0.20 mm and the screen is 1.5 m behind the slit.

What is the diameter of the laser beam after it travels 1.0 km?

A helium-neon laser (l= 633 nm) is built with a glass tube of inside diameter 1.0 mm. One mirror is partially transmitting to allow the laser beam out. An electrical discharge in the tube causes it to glow like a neon light. From an optical perspective, the laser beam is a light wave that diffracts out through a 1.0-mm-diameter circular opening.

Ordinary hydrogen atoms emit red light with a wavelength of 656.45 nm. In deuterium, which is a “heavy” isotope of hydrogen, the wavelength is 656.27 nm. What is the minimum number of slits in a diffraction grating that can barely resolve these two wavelengths in the first-order diffraction pattern?

The figure shows two nearly overlapped intensity peaks of the sort you might produce with a diffraction grating. As a practical matter, two peaks can just barely be resolved if their spacing $\delta y$ equals the width w of each peak, where w is measured at half of the peak’s height. Two peaks closer together than w will merge into a single peak. We can use this idea to understand the resolution of a diffraction grating.

Find the distance d shown in the figure, if the strength of the electric field is E = 510 kV $m^{−1}$

An electron, moving with 60 % of the speed of light c, enters a homogeneous electric field that is perpendicular to its velocity. When the electron leaves the field, its velocity makes an angle of 45\circ with its initial direction.

What is the recoil velocity of ^{12}C as a result of pair production?

If a photon travels in an electric field， usually produced by a nucleus, such as \^{12}C, it can spontaneously disintegrate into an electron and a positron which is the “anti-particle” of the electron. Both electron and positron have mass m = 9.11 \times 10^{-31} kg. This process is called pair production.

Find the angle \theta [away from the forward direction], where the first order diffraction peak is found!

Neutrons are contained in a “bottle” kept at the temperature T = 1200 K. Use m = 1 u for the mass of a neutron. The neutrons are traveling towards a copper lattice that acts as a diffraction grating. The lattice constant of the $Cu$ lattice is b = 0.361 nm.

For what distance must you set the focus of the camera lens in order to snap a sharp picture of the bird’s image?

You are trying to photograph a bird sitting on a tree branch, but a tall hedge is blocking your view. However, as the drawing shows, a plane mirror reflects light from the bird into your camera.

If a ray strikes mirror M_1 at a 65\circ angle of incidence, at what angle does it leave mirror M_2?

Two plane mirrors are separated by 120\circ , as the drawing illustrates.

After reflection, how far from the base of the mirror does the beam strike the floor?

The drawing shows a laser beam shining on a plane mirror that is perpendicular to the floor. The beam’s angle of incidence is 33.0\circ. The beam emerges from the laser at a point that is 1.10 m from the mirror and 1.80 m above the floor.

What is the angle between the incident and outgoing rays?

The drawing shows two plane mirrors that intersect at an angle of 50\circ. An incident light ray reflects from one mirror and then the other.

What is the smallest angle of incidence with respect to the top mirror, such that the laser beam hits each mirror only once?

Two plane mirrors are facing each other. They are parallel, 3.00 cm apart, and 17.0 cm in length, as the drawing indicates. A laser beam is directed at the top mirror from the left edge of the bottom mirror.

At what angle of incidence must the light strike the right-hand wall so that, after being reflected, the light hits the left corner of the back wall?

The drawing shows a top view of a square room. One wall is missing, and the wall on the right is a mirror. From point P in the center of the open side, a laser is pointed at the mirrored wall.

What is the velocity of your image relative to you (magnitude)?

You walk at an angle of 50.0\circ toward a plane mirror, as in the drawing. Your walking velocity has a magnitude of 0.90 m/s.

Find the indices of refraction in c material.

The drawing shows a ray of light traveling through three materials whose surfaces are parallel to each other. The refracted rays (but not the reflected rays) are shown as the light passes through each material. A ray of light strikes the a–b interface at a 50.0\circ angle of incidence. The index of refraction of material a is n_a 1.20. The angles of refraction in materials b and c are, respectively, 45.0\circ and 56.7\circ.

At what angle of refraction does the ray leave the glass at point B?

The drawing shows a rectangular block of glass surrounded by liquid carbon disulfide (n = 1.63). A ray of light is incident on the glass at point A with a 30.0\circ angle of incidence.

Find the indices of refraction in c material.

The drawing shows three materials, a, b, and c. A ray of light strikes the a–b interface at an angle that just barely exceeds its critical angle of 40.0\circ. The reflected ray then strikes the a–c interface at an angle of incidence that just barely exceeds its critical angle (which is not 40.0\circ). The index of refraction of material a is na = 1.80.

What is the maximum value of n for which total internal reflection occurs at point P?

The drawing shows a crystalline quartz slab with a rectangular cross section. A ray of light strikes the slab at an incident angle of 34\circ , enters the quartz, and travels to point P. This slab is surrounded by a fluid with a refractive index n.

How much time does it take for the light to travel from A to B?

The drawing shows a ray of light traveling from point A to point B, a distance of 4.60 m in a material that has an index of refraction $n_1$. At point B, the light encounters a different substance whose index of refraction is $n_2$ 1.63. The light strikes the interface at the critical angle of \theta_c = 48.1\circ .

Determine the distance d between the edge of the pane and the point at which the laser beam is reflected.

A laser is mounted in air, at a distance of 0.476 m above the edge of a large, horizontal pane of crown glass, as shown in the drawing. The laser is aimed at the glass in such a way that the reflected beam is 100% polarized.

Find the required index of refraction of the surrounding material so that all colors except violet emerge from the slanted face.

The drawing shows a horizontal ray of white light incident perpendicularly on the vertical face of a prism (crown glass). The light enters the prism, and part of it undergoes refraction at the slanted face and emerges into the surrounding material. The rest of it is totally internally reflected and exits through the horizontal base of the prism. The colors of light that emerge from the slanted face may be chosen by altering the index of refraction of the material surrounding the prism.

Determine the final image distance for the second system, measured with respect to lens 2.

Two systems are formed from a converging lens and a diverging lens, as shown in parts a and b of the drawing. (The point labeled “F_{converging}” is the focal point of the converging lens.) An object is placed inside the focal point of lens 1 at a distance of 10.00 cm to the left of lens 1. The focal lengths of the converging and diverging lenses are 15.00 and -20 cm, respectively. The distance between the lenses is 50.0 cm.

What is the minimum thickness of the plastic?

A sheet that is made of plastic (n = 1.60) covers one slit of a double slit. When the double slit is illuminated by monochromatic light (vacuum 586 nm), the center of the screen appears dark rather than bright.

How many bright rings are there?

The drawing shows a cross section of a planoconcave lens resting on a flat glass plate. (A planoconcave lens has one surface that is a plane and the other that is concave spherical.) The thickness t is 1.37 \times 10^5 m. The lens is illuminated with monochromatic light ( vacuum 550 nm), and a series of concentric bright and dark rings is formed, much like Newton’s rings.

If the entire apparatus is submerged in water (n_water = 1.33), what is the distance y?

Light of wavelength 410 nm (in vacuum) is incident on a diffraction grating that has a slit separation of 1.2 \times 10^5 m. The distance between the grating and the viewing screen is 0.15 m. A diffraction pattern is produced on the screen that consists of a central bright fringe and higher-order bright fringes.

Using the fringe pattern shown in the drawing, determine the thickness of the air wedge at B.

A beam of light is sent directly down onto a glass plate (n = 1.5) and a plastic plate (n = 1.2) that form a thin wedge of air. An observer looking down through the glass plate sees the fringe pattern shown in the lower part of the drawing, with the dark fringes at the ends A and B. The wavelength of the light is 520 nm.

What is the time interval \delta t that an earth observer measures between “ticks” of the astronaut’s clock?

The spacecraft in figure is moving past the earth at a constant speed v that is 0.92 times the speed of light. The astronaut measures the time interval between successive “ticks” of the spacecraft clock to be \delta t_0 = 1.0 s.

The three-terminal device circled is an NPN transistor. It works using three simple rules: I. The net current into the device is the same as the net current out of the device, so \( I_C + I_B = I_E \). II. The potential at point \( e \) is always \( 0.60\,\text{V} \) less than the potential at point \( b \), thus \( V_{\text{in}} - V_e = 0.60\,\text{V} \). III. The current into point \( c \) is always a fixed multiple of the current into point \( b \), so \( I_C =  eta I_B \), where \(  eta \gg 1 \) is a parameter characteristic of the transistor. Use these rules to answer the question.

Determine the gyromagnetic ratio \( \gamma \).

When a rigid charge distribution with charge \( Q \) and mass \( M \) rotates about an axis, its magnetic moment \( \vec{\mu} \) is linearly proportional to its angular momentum \( \vec{L} \), with \( \vec{\mu} = \gamma \vec{L} \). The constant of proportionality \( \gamma \) is called the gyromagnetic ratio of the object. We can write \( \gamma = g\\left(\frac{Q}{2M}\right) \), where \( g \) is a dimensionless number called the \( g \)-factor of the object. Consider a spherical shell with mass \( M \) and uniformly distributed charge \( Q \) centered on the origin \( O \) and rotating about the \( z \)-axis with angular speed \( \omega \).

What was the energy difference \( E\_2 - E\_1 \) for that emission?

Comet stimulated emission. When a comet approaches the Sun, the increased warmth evaporates water from the ice on the surface of the comet nucleus, producing a thin atmosphere of water vapor around the nucleus. Sunlight can then dissociate H\_2O molecules in the vapor to H atoms and OH molecules. The sunlight can also excite the OH molecules to higher energy levels. When the comet is still relatively far from the Sun, the sunlight causes equal excitation to the \( E\_2 \) and \( E\_1 \) levels. Hence, there is no population inversion between the two levels. However, as the comet approaches the Sun, the excitation to the \( E\_1 \) level decreases and population inversion occurs. The reason has to do with Fraunhofer lines. As a comet approaches the Sun, the Doppler effect due to the comet's speed relative to the Sun shifts the Fraunhofer lines in wavelength, overlapping one of them with the wavelength required for excitation to the \( E\_1 \) level in OH molecules. Population inversion occurs in those molecules, and they radiate stimulated emission at about \( 1666\text\{ MHz \} \).

Construct the $S$-matrix for scattering from a delta-function well

The Scattering Matrix. The theory of scattering generalizes in a pretty obvious way to arbitrary localized potentials. To the left (Region I), $V(x) = 0$, so $$\psi(x) = Ae^{ikx} + Be^{-ikx}, \quad \text{where } k = \sqrt{\frac{2mE}{\hbar}}.$$ To the right (Region III), $V(x)$ is again zero, so $$\psi(x) = Fe^{ikx} + Ge^{-ikx}.$$ In between (Region II), of course, I can't tell you what $\psi$ is until you specify the potential, but because the Schrödinger equation is a linear, second-order differential equation, the general solution has got to be of the form $$\psi(x) = Cf(x) + Dg(x),$$ where $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are two linearly independent particular solutions. There will be four boundary conditions (two joining Regions I and II, and two joining Regions II and III). Two of these can be used to eliminate $C$ and $D$, and the other two can be "solved" for $B$ and $F$ in terms of $A$ and $G$: $$B = S_{11}A + S_{12}G, \quad F = S_{21}A + S_{22}G.$$ The four coefficients $S_{ij}$, which depend on $k$ (and hence on $E$), constitute a $2 \times 2$ matrix $\mathbf{S}$, called the scattering matrix (or $S$-matrix, for short). The $S$-matrix tells you the outgoing amplitudes ($B$ and $F$) in terms of the incoming amplitudes ($A$ and $G$): $$ egin{pmatrix} B \ F \end{pmatrix} =  egin{pmatrix} S_{11} & S_{12} \ S_{21} & S_{22} \end{pmatrix}  egin{pmatrix} A \ G \end{pmatrix}.$$ In the typical case of scattering from the left, $G = 0$, so the reflection and transmission coefficients are $$R_L = \left| \frac{B}{A} ight|_{G=0}^2 = |S_{11}|^2, \quad T_L = \left| \frac{F}{A} ight|_{G=0}^2 = |S_{21}|^2.$$ For scattering from the right, $A = 0$, and $$R_R = \left| \frac{F}{G} ight|_{A=0}^2 = |S_{22}|^2, \quad T_R = \left| \frac{B}{G} ight|_{A=0}^2 = |S_{12}|^2.$$

Find the $M$-matrix for scattering from the double delta-function $$V(x) = -\alpha [\delta(x+a) + \delta(x-a)].$$ What is the transmission coefficient for this potential?

For some purposes it is more convenient to work with the transfer matrix, $\mathbf{M}$, which gives you the amplitudes to the right of the potential ($F$ and $G$) in terms of those to the left ($A$ and $B$): $$ egin{pmatrix} F \ G \end{pmatrix} =  egin{pmatrix} M_{11} & M_{12} \ M_{21} & M_{22} \end{pmatrix}  egin{pmatrix} A \ B \end{pmatrix}.$$

When these atoms come together to form a metal, we get $N$ electrons in a much larger infinite square well of width $Na$. Because of the Pauli exclusion principle (which we will discuss in Chapter 5) there can only be one electron (two, if you include spin, but let's ignore that) in each allowed state. What is the lowest energy for this system?

In a monovalent metal, one electron per atom is free to roam throughout the object. Evidently the energy of the composite structure must be less than the energy of the isolated atoms. This problem offers a crude but illuminating explanation for the cohesiveness of metals.

A crystal consisting of $N$ atoms can be thought of as a collection of $3N$ oscillators (each atom is attached by springs to its 6 nearest neighbors, along the $x, y$, and $z$ directions, but those springs are shared by the atoms at the two ends). The heat capacity of the crystal (per atom) will therefore be $$C = 3 \frac{d ar{E}}{dT}.$$ Show that (in this model) $$C = 3k_B \left( \frac{\Theta_E}{T} ight)^2 \frac{e^{\Theta_E/T}}{(e^{\Theta_E/T} - 1)^2},$$ where $\Theta_E \equiv \hbar \omega / k_B$ is the so-called Einstein temperature. The same reasoning using the classical expression for $ ar{E}$ yields $C_{\text{classical}} = 3k_B$, independent of temperature.

The Boltzmann equation $$P(n) = \frac{1}{Z} e^{- eta E_n}, \quad Z = \sum_n e^{- eta E_n}, \quad  eta = \frac{1}{k_B T},$$ gives the probability of finding a system in the state $n$ (with energy $E_n$), at temperature $T$ ($k_B$ is Boltzmann's constant). Note: The probability here refers to the random thermal distribution, and has nothing to do with quantum indeterminacy. Quantum mechanics will only enter this problem through quantization of the energies $E_n$.

Consider three spin-1/2 particles arranged on the corners of a triangle and interacting via the Hamiltonian $$H = J (\mathbf{S}_1 \cdot \mathbf{S}_2 + \mathbf{S}_2 \cdot \mathbf{S}_3 + \mathbf{S}_3 \cdot \mathbf{S}_1),$$ where $J$ is a positive constant. This interaction favors opposite alignment of neighboring spins (\textbf{antiferromagnetism}, if they are magnetic dipoles), but the triangular arrangement means that this condition cannot be satisfied simultaneously for all three pairs. This is known as geometrical 'frustration'.

Use the adiabatic connection between $T_1$ and $T_2$ and also between $T_3$ and $T_4$ to show that the thermal efficiency of the Otto cycle is $\eta = 1 - \frac{1}{r^{(\gamma - 1)}}$ where $r = V_{	ext{max}} / V_{	ext{min}}$ is the engine's compression ratio.

The gasoline engine in your car can be modeled as the Otto cycle shown in figure. A fuel-air mixture is sprayed into the cylinder at point 1, where the piston is at its farthest distance from the spark plug. This mixture is compressed as the piston moves toward the spark plug during the adiabatic compression stroke. The spark plug fires at point 2, releasing heat energy that had been stored in the gasoline. The fuel burns so quickly that the piston doesn't have time to move, so the heating is an isochoric process. The hot, high-pressure gas then pushes the piston outward during the power stroke. Finally, an exhaust valve opens to allow the gas temperature and pressure to drop back to their initial values before starting the cycle over again.

What is the power output in $\text{kW}$ and horsepower ($1 \, \text{hp} = 746 \, \text{W}$) of an eight-cylinder diesel engine running at $2400 \, \text{rpm}$?

Figure shows the Diesel cycle. It is similar to the Otto cycle (see Problem CP19.71), but there are two important differences. First, the fuel is not admitted until the air is fully compressed at point 2. Because of the high temperature at the end of an adiabatic compression, the fuel begins to burn spontaneously. (There are no spark plugs in a diesel engine!) Second, combustion takes place more slowly, with fuel continuing to be injected. This makes the ignition stage a constant-pressure process. The cycle shown, for one cylinder of a diesel engine, has a displacement $V_{\text{max}} - V_{	ext{min}}$ of $1000 \, \text{cm}^3$ and a compression ratio $r = V_{\text{max}} / V_{\text{min}} = 21$. These are typical values for a diesel truck. The engine operates with intake air ($\gamma = 1.40$) at $25 \, ^{\circ}\text{C}$ and $1.0 \, \text{atm}$ pressure. The quantity of fuel injected into the cylinder has a heat of combustion of $1000 \, \text{J}$.

Evaluate  $\Delta t$ for the realistic AM radio frequency of $1000 \, \text{kHz}$.

The broadcast antenna of an AM radio station is located at the edge of town. The station owners would like to beam all of the energy into town and none into the countryside, but a single antenna radiates energy equally in all directions. Figure shows two parallel antennas separated by distance $L$. Both antennas broadcast a signal at wavelength $\lambda$, but antenna 2 can delay its broadcast relative to antenna 1 by a time interval $\Delta t$ in order to create a phase difference $\Delta \phi_0$ between the sources. Your task is to find values of $L$ and $\Delta t$ such that the waves interfere constructively on the town side and destructively on the country side. Let antenna 1 be at $x = 0$. The wave that travels to the right is $a \sin[2\pi (x/\lambda - t/T)]$. The left wave is $a \sin[2\pi (-x/\lambda - t/T)]$. (It must be this, rather than $a \sin[2\pi (x/\lambda + t/T)]$, so that the two waves match at $x = 0$.) Antenna 2 is at $x = L$. It broadcasts wave $a \sin[2\pi ((x - L)/\lambda - t/T) + \phi_{20}]$ to the right and wave $a \sin[2\pi (-(x - L)/\lambda - t/T) + \phi_{20}]$ to the left.

How many survive to reach sea level?

Cosmic rays are energetic particles—mostly protons—that enter Earth's upper atmosphere from space. The particles collide with atoms or molecules in the upper atmosphere and produce showers of particles. One of the particles produced is the muon, which is something like a heavy electron. The muon is unstable. Half of the muons present at any particular instant of time still exist 1.5\,\mu	ext{s} later; the other half decay into an electron plus two other particles. In a shower of muons streaming toward Earth's surface, some decay before reaching the ground.Assume that 1 million muons are moving toward the ground at speed 0.995\,c at an altitude of 4500\,	ext{m} above sea level.

If the intensity of the incident wave is denoted as \( I_1 \), what is the energy incident on the interface per unit area per second?

Consider point \( P \), which is \( 1\,\text{m} \) away from the aperture (with line \( SP \) passing through the center of the ring and perpendicular to the ring plane).

Find the distribution of the resultant amplitude and the spatial frequency on the \( xy \)-plane.

Two monochromatic plane waves with the same vibration direction and the same wavelength of \( 500\,\text{nm} \) are incident on the \( xy \)-plane. Their amplitudes are both \( A \), and their propagation directions lie in the \( xz \)-plane, forming angles of \( 30^\circ \) and \( -30^\circ \) with the \( z \)-axis, respectively.

Determine the Fraunhofer diffraction intensity distribution on this screen.

A monochromatic plane wave is incident perpendicularly onto a screen located in the \( (x_1, y_1) \)-plane, which contains two parallel narrow slits. The distance between the two slits is \( d \), and the slit width is very small.

Determine the intensity distribution of the Fraunhofer diffraction pattern on the screen shown in figure.

Assume that the screen is illuminated perpendicularly by a monochromatic plane wave with unit amplitude.
options: A: \left( \frac{1}{\lambda z_1} \right)^2 \left[ L^2 \cdot \text{sinc} \left( \frac{Lx}{\lambda z_1} \right) \cdot \text{sinc} \left( \frac{Ly}{\lambda z_1} \right) + l^2 \cdot \text{sinc} \left( \frac{lx}{\lambda z_1} \right) \cdot \text{sinc} \left( \frac{ly}{\lambda z_1} \right) \right]^2
B: \left( \frac{1}{\lambda z_1} \right)^2 \left[ l^2 \cdot \text{sinc}^2\left( \frac{lx}{\lambda z_1} \right) \cdot 	ext{sinc}^2\left( \frac{ly}{\lambda z_1} \right) \right]

text:
Determine the angle between the ordinary ray \( o \) and the extraordinary ray \( e \) after the light emerges from the prism.

Figure shows a Sénarmont prism made of calcite crystals, where each prism block has an apex angle of \( 20^\circ \), and the light is incident normally.

What is the duration of each light pulse, as measured by the observer on earth?

A spaceship flies past earth with a speed of $0.990c$ (about $2.97 \times 10^8$ m/s) relative to earth. A high-intensity signal light (perhaps a pulsed laser) blinks on and off; each pulse lasts $2.20 \mu s$ ($=2.20 \times 10^{-6}$ s), as measured on the spaceship. At a certain instant, the ship is directly above an observer on earth and is traveling perpendicular to the line of sight.

How much time does the trip take, as measured by an observer in the plane?

An airplane flies from San Francisco to New York (about $4800 \text{ km}$, or $4.80 \times 10^6 \text{ m}$) at a steady speed of $300 \text{ m/s}$ (about $670 \text{ mi/h}$).

What is the length measured by observers on earth?

Suppose a crew member on the spaceship measures its length, obtaining the value $400 	ext{ m}$.

What is the probe's speed relative to the earth?

A spaceship moving away from the earth with speed $0.90c$ fires a robot space probe in the same direction as its motion, with speed $0.70c$ relative to the spaceship.

If all three particles are at rest after the collision, find its kinetic energy.

Two protons, each with rest mass $M = 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \text{ kg}$, have equal speeds in opposite directions. They collide head-on, producing a $\pi^0$ meson (also called a neutral pion) with mass $m = 2.40 \times 10^{-28} \text{ kg}$.

Determine the value of Planck's constant, as obtained from these data.

For a certain cathode material used in a photoelectric-effect experiment, a stopping potential of $3.0 \text{ V}$ was required for light of wavelength $300 \text{ nm}$, $2.0 \text{ V}$ for $400 \text{ nm}$, and $1.0 \text{ V}$ for $600 \text{ nm}$.

How much energy (in electron volts) does it take to ionize an electron from the ground level?

The energy-level scheme for the hypothetical one-electron element searsium is shown in figure. The potential energy is taken to be zero for an electron at an infinite distance from he nucleus.

If an electron made a transition from the $n = 4$ to the $n = 2$ level, what wavelength of light would it emit?

In a set of experiments on a hypothetical one-electron atom, you measure the wavelengths of the photons emitted from transitions ending in the ground state ($n = 1$), as shown in the energy-level diagram in figure. You also observe that it takes $17.50 \,\mathrm{eV}$ to ionize this atom.

What is the wavelength of the light from the $3p$-to-$3s$ transition in neon?

Information as shown in figure.

What is the magnitude of the velocity of one particle relative to the other?

Two particles in a high-energy accelerator experiment are approaching each other head-on, each with a speed of $0.9520c$ as measured in the laboratory.

What is the speed of the second particle, as measured in the laboratory?

Two particles are created in a high-energy accelerator and move off in opposite directions. The speed of one particle, as measured in the laboratory, is $0.650c$, and the speed of each particle relative to the other is $0.950c$.

What speed does one proton measure for the other proton?

In an experiment, two protons are shot directly toward each other, each moving at half the speed of light relative to the laboratory.

Where is the plane at this instant? Speed of sound in air = $340 \,\mathrm{m/s}$.

An aeroplane is going towards east at a speed of $510 \,\mathrm{km/h}$ at a height of $2000 \,\mathrm{m}$. At a certain instant, the sound of the plane heard by a ground observer appears to be coming from a point vertically above him.

Find the distance between the two rows of buildings.

A rod runs midway between two parallel rows of buildings. A motorist moving with a speed of $36 \,\mathrm{kilometers \, per \, hour}$ sounds the horn. He hears the echo one second after he has sounded the horn. Velocity of sound in air is $330 \,\mathrm{m/s}$.

If the speed of sound in air is $330 \,\mathrm{m/s}$, calculate the speed of the engine.

An engine approaches a hill with a constant speed. When it is at a distance of $0.9 \,\mathrm{km}$ it blows a whistle, whose echo is heard by the driver after $5 \,\mathrm{s}$.

Find the speed of a transverse wave pulse produced in $CD$.

Two blocks each having a mass of $3.2 \,\mathrm{kg}$ are connected by a wire $CD$ and the system is suspended from the ceiling by another wire $AB$ (figure-6.16). The linear mass density of the wire $AB$ is $10 \,\mathrm{g/m}$ and that of $CD$ is $8 \,\mathrm{g/m}$.

If the rope is given a sudden sideways jerk at the bottom, how long will it take for the pulse to reach the ceiling ?

A heavy but uniform rope of length \( L \) is suspended from a ceiling.

Calculate the amplitude of the resultant motion of the particle co-linear with $S_1$ and $S_2$ and located at a point in the middle of $S_1$ and $S_2$.

Two sources $S_1$ and $S_2$, separated by $2.0 \,\mathrm{m}$, vibrate according to equation $y_1=0.03 \sin \pi t$ and $y_2=0.02 \sin \pi t$ where $y_1, y_2$ and $t$ are in M.K.S. units. They send out waves of velocity $1.5 \,\mathrm{m/s}$.

Calculate the speed of the sound waves in air.

Two small loudspeakers $A, B$ ($1 \,\mathrm{m}$ apart) are connected to the same oscillator so that both emit coherent sound waves of frequency $1700 \,\mathrm{Hz}$ in phase. A sensitive detector, moving parallel to the line $AB$ along $LQ$, $2.4 \,\mathrm{m}$ away, detects a maximum wave at $P$ on the perpendicular bisector $MP$ of $AB$ and another maximum wave when it first reaches a point $Q$ directly opposite to $B$ as shown in figure.

Find the minimum distance between the source and the detector for which the detector detects a maximum of sound.

A source emitting sound of frequency $180 \,\mathrm{Hz}$ is placed in front of a wall at distance of $2 \,\mathrm{m}$ from it. A detector is also placed in front of the wall at the same distance from it. Speed of sound in air = $360 \,\mathrm{m/s}$.

Find the distance $x$ such that the intensity at $P$ is equal to the intensity at $O$.

Two coherent narrow slits emitting of wavelength $\lambda$ in the same phase are placed parallel to each other at a small separation of $2\lambda$. the sound is detected by moving a detector on the screen $S$ at a distance $D (\gg \lambda)$ from the slit $S_1$ as shown in figure.

What is the wavelength of the pulse when it reaches the top of the rope?

A uniform rope of length $12 \,\mathrm{m}$ and mass $6 \,\mathrm{kg}$ hangs vertically from a rigid support. A block of mass $2 \,\mathrm{kg}$ is attached to the free end of the rope. A transverse pulse of wavelength $0.06 \,\mathrm{m}$ is produced at the lower end of the rope.

Find the frequency of vibration with which the wire vibrates in two loops leaving the middle point of the wire between the pulleys at rest.

The length of the wire shown in figure between the pulleys is $1.5 \,\mathrm{m}$ and its mass is $12.0 \,\mathrm{g}$. Take $g=10 \,\mathrm{m/s^2}$.

Calculate Young's modulus of the material of the rod. Velocity of sound in the gas used is $400 \,\mathrm{m/s}$.

Clamped at the middle, a metal rod of length $1 \,\mathrm{metre}$ and density $7.5 \,\mathrm{gm/cm^3}$ gives dust heaps at intervals of $8 \,\mathrm{cm}$.

What is the minimum frequency of these vibrations for which the diaphragm $C$ is a node?

$AB$ is a cylinder of length $1.0 \,\mathrm{m}$ filled with a thin flexible diaphragm $C$ at the middle and two other thin flexible diaphragms $A$ and $B$ at the ends. The portions $AC$ and $BC$ contain hydrogen and oxygen gases respectively. The diaphragms $A$ and $B$ are set into vibrations of same frequency. Under the conditions of the experiment, the velocity of sound in hydrogen is $1100 \,\mathrm{m/s}$ and in oxygen is $300 \,\mathrm{m/s}$.

Assuming that the initial distance between the cork and the piston was $25 \,\mathrm{cm}$ and that there is no leakage of air, calculate the force required to eject the cork.

A pop-gun consists of a cylindrical barrel $3 \,\mathrm{cm^3}$ in cross-section closed at one end by a cork and having a well fitting piston at the other. If the piston is pushed slowly in, the cork is finally ejected, giving a pop, the frequency of which is found to be $512 \,\mathrm{Hz}$. Atmospheric pressure = $1 \,\mathrm{kg \, wt/cm^2}$, $v = 340 \,\mathrm{m/s}$.

Find the beat frequency registered by the receiver.

A sources of sonic oscillations with frequency $n=1700 \,\mathrm{Hz}$ and a receiver are located on the same normal to a wall. Both the source and receiver are stationary, and the wall recedes from the source with velocity $u=6.0 \,\mathrm{cm/s}$. The velocity of sound is equal to $v=340 \,\mathrm{m/s}$.

If one of them were to approach and the other to recede from a stationary observer each with a velocity of $1/100^{\mathrm{th}}$ the velocity of sound, calculate the number of beats per second heard by the observer.

Two distant sources situated together emit sound each of frequency $300 \,\mathrm{cycles \, per \, second}$.

Assuming the velocity of sound to be equal to $v=340 \,\mathrm{m/s}$, find the oscillation frequency registered by the stationary receiver $t = 10.0 \,\mathrm{s}$ after the start of motion.

A sources of sonic oscillations with frequency $n=1700 \,\mathrm{Hz}$ and a receiver are located at the same point. At the moment $t=0$, the source starts receding from the receiver with constant acceleration $a = 10.0 \,\mathrm{m/s^2}$.

Find the distance between the source and the observer at the moment when the observer receives a frequency $n_{ap}=n$.

A source of sound with natural frequency $n = 1.8 \,\mathrm{kHz}$ moves uniformly along a straight line separated from a stationary observer by a distance $l = 250 \,\mathrm{m}$. The velocity of the source is equal to $\eta=0.80$ fraction of the velocity of sound.

What frequency is heard by an observer $0.60 \,\mathrm{miles}$ from the crossing on the straight road which crosses the railroad at right angles?

A locomotive approaching a crossing at a speed of $80 \,\mathrm{miles/hr}$, sounds a whistle of frequency $400 \,\mathrm{Hz}$ when $1 \,\mathrm{mile}$ from the crossing. There is no wind, and the speed of sound in air is $0.200 \,\mathrm{mile/s}$.

If velocity of sound in air is $330 \,\mathrm{m/s}$, calculate the frequency of the pulse heard by driver of train $B$.

A train $A$ crosses a station with a speed of $40 \,\mathrm{m/s}$ and whistles a short pulse of natural frequency $596 \,\mathrm{Hz}$. Another train $B$ is approaching towards the same station with the same speed along a parallel track. Two tracks are $99 \,\mathrm{m}$ apart. When train $A$ whistles train $B$ is $152 \,\mathrm{m}$ away from the station as shown in figure.

If the source emits a continuous sound wave of frequency $340 \,\mathrm{Hz}$, find the minimum frequencies recorded by the detector.

A source of sound is moving along circular orbit of radius $3 \,\mathrm{meters}$ with an angular velocity of $10 \,\mathrm{rad/s}$. A sound detector located far away from the source is executing linear simple harmonic motion along the line $BD$ (see figure-6.112) with an amplitude $BC=CD=6 \,\mathrm{meters}$. The frequency of oscillation of the detector is $5/\pi \,\mathrm{per \, second}$. The source is at the point $A$ when the detector is at the point $B$.

If the movable support is pushed to the right by $10 \,\mathrm{cm}$ so that the joint is placed on the pulley,what will be the minimum frequency at which the heavy string can resonate?

A heavy string is tied at one end to a movable support and to a light thread at the other end as shown in figure. The thread goes over a fixed pulley and supports a weight to produce a tension. The lowest frequency with which the heavy string resonates is $120 \,\mathrm{Hz}$.

What is the work function of sodium?

The graph above is the experimental curve of the stopping potential $U_c$ versus the incident light frequency $\nu$ for the photoelectric effect on sodium metal, published by Millikan in 1916. This experiment provided direct verification of Einstein's photoelectric equation and, for the first time, used photoelectric measurements to determine Planck's constant $h$.

How much energy must be absorbed to make a transition from the $n = 3$ energy level to the $n = 4$ energy level?

The energy-level diagram of a hydrogen atom is shown. A large number of hydrogen atoms are in the $n = 3$ energy level.

To ensure that a hydrogen atom initially in the ground state ($n = 1$), after being excited, can emit a visible-light photon, what is the minimum energy that must be supplied to the hydrogen atom?

The energy-level diagram of a hydrogen atom is shown. Photons with energies between 1.63 eV and 3.10 eV are visible light.

The magnitude of particle a's momentum, $p_a$

A cloud chamber can be used to determine the properties of charged particles. As shown in the figure, a uniform magnetic field of induction $B$ exists in the chamber. At point $A$, a neutral particle of mass $m$ and speed $v$ splits into two particles $a$ and $b$, which carry equal but opposite charges. In the magnetic field their paths are two tangent circular arcs. Over the same time interval, the lengths of these arcs are in the ratio $$l_a : l_b = 3 : 1,$$ and the radii of curvature are in the ratio $$r_a : r_b = 6 : 1.$$ Neglecting gravity and any interaction forces between the particles.

If a hydrogen atom in the ground state is excited so that it can emit blue light but not violet light, what must be the energy of the photon used to excite the hydrogen atom?

Given that the energy range of blue-light photons is 2.53-2.76 eV and that of violet-light photons is 2.76-3.10 eV.

How can Planck's constant $h$ be expressed?

In a certain photoelectric-effect experiment, the stopping potential $U_c$ is measured as a function of the incident-light frequency $\nu$, and the data lie on a straight line as shown in the figure. If the slope of this line is $k$ and its (vertical) intercept is $b$, and if the magnitude of the electron's charge is $e$.

When a large number of He$^+$ ions are in the excited state $n = 4$, how many spectral lines are emitted due to their transitions?

According to Bohr's theory of atomic structure, the energy-level diagram of the helium ion (He$^+$) is shown in the figure.

How many of the emitted spectral lines will be able to cause the photoelectric effect in potassium metal whose work function is 2.25 eV?

As shown in the figure, a group of hydrogen atoms are in the excited state $n = 3$. When they spontaneously transition to lower energy levels.

What is the work function of the metal?

The energy-level diagram of the hydrogen atom is shown. A group of hydrogen atoms in the $n = 4$ level make transitions down to $n = 2$, emitting light of a certain frequency. When this light is used to irradiate a metal plate, the photoelectric effect occurs and the maximum initial kinetic energy of the emitted photoelectrons is measured to be 2.10 eV.

How many of the emitted spectral frequencies are energetic enough to trigger the photoelectric effect in tungsten?

The diagram shows the work functions of several metals alongside the hydrogen atom's energy-level diagram. A large number of hydrogen atoms are in the $n = 4$ level and transition down to lower levels.

If a muon is moving at 0.990$c$ relative to the earth, what will an observer on earth measure its mean lifetime to be?

High-energy subatomic particles coming from space interact with atoms in the earth's upper atmosphere, in some cases producing unstable particles called muons. A muon decays into other particles with a mean lifetime of 2.20 $\mu$s = 2.20 $\times 10^{-6}$ s as measured in a reference frame in which it is at rest.

How much time does the trip take, as measured by an observer on the ground?

An airplane flies from San Francisco to New York (about 4800 km, or 4.80 $\times 10^6$ m) at a steady speed of 300 m/s (about 670 mi/h).

How far apart does the spaceship crew measure them to be?

Observers $O_1$ and $O_2$ in figure are 56.4 m apart on the earth.

What is the magnitude of the momentum of each photon?

A laser pointer with a power output of 5.00 mW emits red light ($\lambda = 650$ nm).

Find the maximum kinetic energy

While conducting a photoelectric-effect experiment with light of a certain frequency, you find that a reverse potential difference of 1.25 V is required to reduce the current to zero.

Determine the work function $\phi$ for this material and the implied value of Planck's constant $h$.

For a particular cathode material in a photoelectric-effect experiment, you measure stopping potentials $V_0 = 1.0$ V for light of wavelength $\lambda = 600$ nm, 2.0 V for 400 nm, and 3.0 V for 300 nm.

Find the photon's frequency, magnitude of momentum, and energy.

A photon of green light has a wavelength of 520 nm.

How much energy (in joules and electron volts) does it deliver to the receptor cells?

The human eye is most sensitive to green light of wavelength 505 nm. Experiments have found that when people are kept in a dark room until their eyes adapt to the darkness, a single photon of green light will trigger receptor cells in the rods of the retina.

How many photons per second does the source emit?

A $75\ \mathrm{W}$ light source consumes $75\ \mathrm{W}$ of electrical power. Assume all this energy goes into emitted light of wavelength $600\ \mathrm{nm}$.

What is the maximum speed of the photoelectrons emitted from this surface?

A clean nickel surface is exposed to light of wavelength $235\ \mathrm{nm}$.

What is the maximum kinetic energy of the photoelectrons when light of wavelength $300.0\ \mathrm{nm}$ falls on the same surface?

When ultraviolet light with a wavelength of $400.0\ \mathrm{nm}$ falls on a certain metal surface, the maximum kinetic energy of the emitted photoelectrons is measured to be $1.10\ \mathrm{eV}$.

If light with wavelength $190\,\mathrm{nm}$ falls on potassium, find the speed of these electrons.

The photoelectric work function of potassium is $2.3\ \mathrm{eV}$.

What must be the angle between the direction of propagation of the incident and scattered photons if the speed of the electron immediately after the collision is $8.90	imes10^{6} \ \mathrm{m/s}$?

A photon with wavelength $\lambda = 0.1385\ \mathrm{nm}$ scatters from an electron that is initially at rest.

What must the wavelength of the incident photon be if it is to undergo a $10.0\%$ change in wavelength as a result of the scattering?

A photon scatters in the backward direction ($\phi = 180^\circ$) from a free proton that is initially at rest.

How much energy must each pulse deliver to the blemish?

A pulsed dye laser emits light of wavelength $585\ \mathrm{nm}$ in $450\ \mu\mathrm{s}$ pulses. Because this wavelength is strongly absorbed by hemoglobin in the blood, the method is especially effective for removing various blood-related blemishes, such as port-wine-colored birthmarks. To estimate the power required for such laser surgery, model the blood as having the same specific heat and heat of vaporization as water (4190 J kg$^{-1}$ K$^{-1}$, 2.256 \times10$^6$ J kg$^{-1}$). Suppose that each pulse must remove $2.0\ \mu\mathrm{g}$ of blood by evaporating it, starting at $33^\circ\mathrm{C}$.

If the photon scatters in the backward direction, what is the magnitude of the linear momentum of the electron just after the collision with the photon?

A photon with wavelength $\lambda = 0.0980\ \mathrm{nm}$ is incident on an electron that is initially at rest.

If the photon scatters at an angle of $60.0^\circ$ from its original direction, what are the magnitude of the linear momentum of the electron just after it collides with the photon?

A photon with wavelength $\lambda = 0.1050\ \mathrm{nm}$ is incident on an electron that is initially at rest.

What is the kinetic energy of the electron after the collision?

A photon with wavelength $0.1100\ \mathrm{nm}$ collides with a free electron that is initially at rest. After the collision the wavelength is $0.1132\ \mathrm{nm}$.

What will be the maximum speed of the photoelectrons produced as they leave this material's surface?

While analyzing smoke detector designs that rely on the photoelectric effect, you are evaluating surfaces made from each of the materials listed in Table 38.1. One particular application uses ultraviolet light with wavelength $270\ \mathrm{nm}$.

At what wavelength does the sun emit most strongly?

To a good approximation, the sun's surface is a blackbody with a surface temperature of $5800\ \mathrm{K}$.

What is the uncertainty in energy of that excited state?

A sodium atom in one of the states labeled “Lowest excited levels” remains in that state, on average, for $1.6\times10^{-8}\,\mathrm{s}$ before it makes a transition to the ground state, emitting a photon with wavelength $589.0\,\mathrm{nm}$ and energy $2.105\,\mathrm{eV}$.

What is its de Broglie wavelength?

An alpha particle $(m = 6.64	imes10^{-27}\,\mathrm{kg})$ emitted in the radioactive decay of uranium-238 has an energy of $4.20\,\mathrm{MeV}$.

How wide is the slit?

A beam of electrons is accelerated from rest through a potential difference of $0.100\ \mathrm{kV}$ and then passes through a thin slit. When viewed far from the slit, the diffracted beam shows its first diffraction minima at $\pm14.6^\circ$ from the original direction of the beam.

What is the kinetic energy (in electron volts) of each neutron in the beam?

A beam of neutrons that all have the same energy scatters from atoms that have a spacing of $0.0910\ \mathrm{nm}$ in the surface plane of a crystal. The $m=1$ intensity maximum occurs when the angle $	heta$ is $28.6^\circ$.

What is the distance of closest approach of the alpha particle to the center of the nucleus?

A $4.78\ \mathrm{MeV}$ alpha particle from a $^{226}\mathrm{Ra}$ decay makes a head-on collision with a uranium nucleus. A uranium nucleus has 92 protons. Assume that the uranium nucleus remains at rest and that the distance of closest approach is much greater than the radius of the uranium nucleus.

Find its ground-state energy.

A positronium atom consists of a positron and an electron. In a Bohr-like model, the two particles rotate in circles about their common center of mass.

For what wavelength does the spectral emittance of the bulb peak?

A $100\ \mathrm{W}$ incandescent light bulb has a cylindrical tungsten filament $30.0\ \mathrm{cm}$ long, $0.40\ \mathrm{mm}$ in diameter, and an emissivity of $0.26$.

What is the ratio of the peak-intensity wavelength of the hot star to the peak-intensity wavelength of the cool star?

Two stars, both of which behave like ideal blackbodies, radiate the same total energy per second. The cooler one has a surface temperature $T$ and a diameter $3.0$ times that of the hotter star.

What is the ground-level energy (in electron volts)?

The negative muon has a charge equal to that of an electron but a mass that is 207 times as great. Consider a hydrogenlike atom consisting of a proton and a muon.

What was the wavelength \lambda of the photon?

A hydrogen atom in an excited bound state labeled with principal quantum number n = 3 absorbs a photon that has wavelength \lambda. The atom is ionized and the electron has kinetic energy 8.00\,\mathrm{eV} after it has left the atom.

If each hydrogen atom were initially in its ground level, what would be the maximum kinetic energy in electron volts of these photo-electrons?

A sample of hydrogen atoms is irradiated with light with wavelength 85.5\,\mathrm{nm}, and electrons are observed leaving the gas.

If Betelgeuse were to radiate all of its energy at the peak-intensity wavelength, how many photons per second would it radiate?

The star Betelgeuse has a surface temperature of 3000\,\mathrm{K} and is 600 times the diameter of our sun. Assume that it radiates like an ideal blackbody.

How long will it take this sphere to radiate 12.0\,\mathrm{MJ} of energy at constant temperature?

Light from an ideal spherical blackbody 15.0\,\mathrm{cm} in diameter is analyzed by using a diffraction grating that has 3850\,\mathrm{lines/cm}. When you shine this light through the grating, you observe that the peak-intensity wavelength forms a first-order bright fringe at \pm 14.4^{\circ} from the central bright fringe.

How long does it take for the cavity to radiate 100\,\mathrm{J} of energy through the hole?

A large cavity that has a very small hole and is maintained at a temperature T is a good approximation to an ideal radiator or blackbody. Radiation can pass into or out of the cavity only through the hole. The cavity is a perfect absorber, since any radiation incident on the hole becomes trapped inside the cavity. Such a cavity at 400^{\circ}\mathrm{C} has a hole with area 4.00\,\mathrm{mm^2}.

Through what potential difference were the electrons accelerated?

A beam of electrons is accelerated from rest and then passes through a pair of identical thin slits that are 1.25\,\mathrm{nm} apart. You observe that the first double-slit interference dark fringe occurs at \pm 18.0^{\circ} from the original direction of the beam when viewed on a distant screen.

At what angle \theta does the m = 1 maximum occur when a beam of 4.50\,\mathrm{keV} electrons is used instead?

For x rays with wavelength 0.0300\,\mathrm{nm}, the m = 1 intensity maximum for a crystal occurs when the angle \theta in figure is 35.8^{\circ}. Assume that the electrons also scatter from the atoms in the surface plane of this same crystal.

What is the kinetic energy of this electron after it has absorbed a photon of wavelength 72\,\mathrm{nm} and moved away from the well?

An electron is in the ground state of a square well of width L = 4.00 \times 10^{-10}\,\mathrm{m}. The depth of the well is six times the ground-state energy of an electron in an infinite well of the same width.

If the proton makes a transition from the level with energy E_1 to the level with energy E_3 by absorbing a photon, find the wavelength of the photon.

A proton is bound in a square well of width 4.0\,\mathrm{fm} = 4.0 \times 10^{-15}\,\mathrm{m}. The depth of the well is six times the ground-level energy E_{1\text{-}IDW} of the corresponding infinite well.

What is the \( l \) quantum number for this state?

A hydrogen atom is in a state that has L_z = 2\hbar. In the semiclassical vector model, the angular momentum vector \vec{L} for this state makes an angle \theta_L = 63.4^{\circ} with the +z-axis.

What is the reading of $V5$ if $\omega = 1000 \, \text{rad/s}$?

Five infinite-impedance voltmeters, calibrated to read rms values, are connected as shown in figure. Let $R = 200 \, \Omega$, $L = 0.400 \, 	ext{H}$, $C = 6.00 \, \mu	ext{F}$, and $V = 30.0 \, \text{V}$.

Use Ampere's law to estimate the average strength of the magnetic field inside the core, assuming a relative permeability of 5000.

Consider the ac adapter that bisects the power cord to your laptop computer, cell phone charger, or another electronic device.

If the input signal has the frequency resonant with this setting and voltage amplitude $100 \, \text{mV}$, what is the voltage amplitude of the output signal?

Five semicircular conducting plates, each with radius $a$, are attached to a conducting rod along their common axis such that the plates are parallel with a separation gap $g$ between adjacent plates. A similar arrangement involving five additional semicircular conducting plates is attached to a second conducting rod symmetrically intertwined, upside down, with the first arrangement such that the plates can rotate freely, as shown in firure. The two five-plate constructions, with an adjacent plate separation of $g/2$, are insulated from each other, and wire leads are attached to the separate axles. This is a common type of variable capacitor, with a capacitance proportional to the overlap angle $\theta$.

Calculate the resistance and inductance of the solenoid.

A coworker of yours was making measurements of a large solenoid that is connected to an ac voltage source. Unfortunately, she left for vacation before she completed the analysis, and your boss has asked you to finish it. You are given a graph of $1/I^2$ versus $\omega^2$ (figure), where $I$ is the current in the circuit and $\omega$ is the angular frequency of the source. A note attached to the graph says that the voltage amplitude of the source was kept constant at $12.0 \, \text{V}$.

Calculate the resistance and inductance of the solenoid.

You are analyzing an ac circuit that contains a solenoid and a capacitor in series with an ac source that has voltage amplitude $90.0 \, \text{V}$ and angular frequency $\omega$. For different capacitors in the circuit, each with known capacitance, you measure the value of the frequency $\omega_{\text{res}}$ for which the current in the circuit is a maximum. You plot your measured values on a graph of $\omega_{\text{res}}^2$ versus $1/C$ (figure). The maximum current for each value of $C$ is the same, you note, and equal to $4.50 \, \text{A}$.

If $R = 100 \, \Omega$, what inductance $L$ will “pass” frequencies higher than $10.0 \, \text{kHz}$ and block frequencies lower than $10.0\, \text{kHz}$?

The frequency response of a filter circuit is commonly specified, in decibels, as the attenuation $G = (20 \, \text{dB}) \log_{10}(V_{\text{out}} / V_{\text{in}})$, where $V_{\text{in}}$ is the input voltage amplitude and $V_{\text{out}}$ is the output voltage amplitude. This is analogous to the definition of decibels given in Eq. For the $R$-$L$ circuit shown in figure, the input signal is $v_{\text{in}}(t) = V_{\text{in}} \cos(\omega t)$.

In that case, what would be the output voltage amplitude at resonance?

Quasars, an abbreviation for quasi-stellar radio sources, are distant objects that look like stars through a telescope but that emit far more electromagnetic radiation than an entire normal galaxy of stars. The leading model for the structure of a quasar is a galaxy with a supermassive black hole at its center. In this model, the radiation is emitted by interstellar gas and dust within the galaxy as this material falls toward the black hole. The radiation is thought to emanate from a region just a few light-years in diameter. (The diffuse glow surrounding the bright quasar shown in figure is thought to be this quasar's host galaxy.) To investigate this model of quasars and to study other exotic astronomical objects, the Russian Space Agency has placed a radio telescope in a large orbit around the earth. When this telescope is 77,000 km from earth and the signals it receives are combined with signals from the ground-based telescopes of the VLBA, the resolution is that of a single radio telescope 77,000 km in diameter. We can represent the history of the tube using a “spacetime” diagram, as shown in figure. Events 1 and 2 correspond, respectively, to the right and left ends of the tube at time $t = 0$, while events 3 and 4 correspond to the right and left ends of the tube at time $t = T$. The totality of events corresponding to positions on the tube when it is lit correspond to the yellow region on the diagram. The tube is observed from the window of a rocket train passing the station from left to right at speed $v$. The frame $S'$ is fixed with respect to the train such that the $x'$-axis coincides with the $x$-axis of frame $S'$, and such that event 1 occurs at the origin $(x', t') = (0, 0)$.We use the product $ct$ rather than $t$ on the vertical axis of our figure so that both axes have the dimension of distance.
