A ship uses a sonar system (figure) to locate underwater objects.

How many decibels does the sound intensity level drop?

Consider an idealized bird (treated as a point source) that emits constant sound power, with intensity obeying the inverse-square law (figure).You move twice the distance from the bird.

At what distances from the wall could you stand and hear no sound at all?

A directional loudspeaker directs a sound wave of wavelength \lambda at a wall (figure).

Find the wavelengths of the waves in front of the siren.

A police car's siren emits a sinusoidal wave with frequency f_S = 300 \, \mathrm{Hz}. The speed of sound is 340 \, \mathrm{m/s} and the air is still. And it is moving at 30 \, \mathrm{m/s}.

What frequency does the listener hear?

A listener L is at rest and the siren is moving away from L at 30 \, \mathrm{m/s}.

What frequency does the listener hear?

The siren is at rest and the listener is moving away from it at 30 \, \mathrm{m/s}.

What frequency does the listener hear?

The siren is moving away from the listener with a speed of 45 \, \mathrm{m/s} relative to the air, and the listener is moving toward the siren with a speed of 15 \, \mathrm{m/s} relative to the air.

What frequency does the driver hear reflected from the warehouse?

The police car is moving toward a warehouse at 30 \, \mathrm{m/s}.

How long will you hear the sonic boom?

An airplane is flying at Mach 1.75 at an altitude of 8000 \, \mathrm{m}, where the speed of sound is 320 \, \mathrm{m/s}.The plane passes directly overhead.

Calculate the total force it exerts on each wall.

An aluminum cylinder 10 \, \mathrm{cm} long, with a cross-sectional area of 20 \, \mathrm{cm^2}, is used as a spacer between two steel walls. At 17.2^\circ \mathrm{C} it just slips between the walls. It warms to 22.3^\circ \mathrm{C}, assuming that the walls are perfectly rigid and a constant distance apart.

What is the rate of heat flow into the cooler?

A Styrofoam cooler (figure) has total wall area (including the lid) of 0.80 \, \mathrm{m^2} and wall thickness 2.0 \, \mathrm{cm}. It is filled with ice, water, and cans of Omni-Cola, all at 0^\circ \mathrm{C}.The temperature of the outside wall is 30^\circ \mathrm{C}.

Find the total rate of heat flow through the bars.

A steel bar 10.0 \, \mathrm{cm} long is welded end to end to a copper bar 20.0 \, \mathrm{cm} long. Each bar has a square cross section, 2.00 \, \mathrm{cm} on a side. The free end of the steel bar is kept at 100^\circ \mathrm{C} by placing it in contact with steam, and the free end of the copper bar is kept at 0^\circ \mathrm{C} by placing it in contact with ice. Both bars are perfectly insulated on their sides.

What is the total heat current in the two bars?

A steel bar 10.0 \, \mathrm{cm} long is welded end to end to a copper bar 20.0 \, \mathrm{cm} long. Each bar has a square cross section, 2.00 \, \mathrm{cm} on a side.Suppose the two bars are separated. One end of each bar is kept at 100^\circ \mathrm{C} and the other end of each bar is kept at 0^\circ \mathrm{C}.

What is the final temperature of the compressed gas?

In an automobile engine, a mixture of air and vaporized gasoline is compressed in the cylinders before being ignited. A typical engine has a compression ratio of 9.00 to 1; that is, the gas in the cylinders is compressed to \frac{1}{9.00} of its original volume (figure). The intake and exhaust valves are closed during the compression, so the quantity of gas is constant.Its initial temperature is 27^\circ \mathrm{C} and the initial and final pressures are 1.00 \, \text{atm} and 21.7 \, \text{atm}, respectively.

Find the heat added during this process.

Figure shows a pV-diagram for a cyclic process in which the initial and final states of some thermodynamic system are the same. The state of the system starts at point a and proceeds counterclockwise in the pV-diagram to point b, then back to a; the total work is W = -500 J.

Find the total heat added in process acd.

The pV-diagram of figure shows a series of thermodynamic processes. In process ab, 150 J of heat is added to the system; in process bd, 600 J of heat is added.

How much work does the gas do during the compression?

The compression ratio of a diesel engine is 15.0 to 1; that is, air in a cylinder is compressed to \frac{1}{15.0} of its initial volume (figure).The initial volume of the cylinder is 1.00 L = 1.00 \times 10^{-3} m^3.Use the values C_V = 20.8 J/mol\cdot K and \gamma = 1.400 for air.

How much gasoline is burned in each cycle?

A gasoline truck engine takes in 10,000 J of heat and delivers 2000 J of mechanical work per cycle. The heat is obtained by burning gasoline with heat of combustion L_c = 5.0 \times 10^4 J/g.

What is its efficiency?

A Carnot engine takes 2000 J of heat from a reservoir at 500 K, does some work, and discards some heat to a reservoir at 350 K.

What is the entropy change in this free-expansion process?

A partition divides a thermally insulated box into two compartments, each of volume $V$ (figure). Initially, one compartment contains $n$ moles of an ideal gas at temperature $T$, and the other compartment is evacuated. We break the partition and the gas expands, filling both compartments.

What is the plane's ground speed?

Cleveland is \(300\,\mathrm{miles}\) east of Chicago. A plane leaves Chicago flying due east at \(500\,\mathrm{mph}\). The pilot forgot to check the weather and doesn't know that the wind is blowing to the south at \(50\,\mathrm{mph}\)

Determine student A's velocity.

The position-versus-time graph of figure represents the motion of two students on roller blades.

How many miles east of Chicago will they meet for lunch?

Bob leaves home in Chicago at 9:00 A.M. and travels east at a steady 60 mph. Susan, 400 miles to the east in Pittsburgh, leaves at the same time and travels west at a steady 40 mph.

How far does the racer move during the first 3.0 s?

Figure shows the velocity-versus-time graph of a drag racer.

Where is the particle's turning point?

Figure is the velocity graph for a particle that starts at \( x_i = 30 \, \text{m} \) at time \( t_i = 0 \, \text{s} \).

What is the total distance traveled?

A rocket sled accelerates at \( 50 \, \text{m/s}^2 \) for 5.0 s, coasts for 3.0 s, then deploys a braking parachute and decelerates at \( 3.0 \, \text{m/s}^2 \) until coming to a halt.

Where will Tommy tackle Fred?

Fred catches the football while standing directly on the goal line. He immediately starts running forward with an acceleration of \( 6 \, \text{ft/s}^2 \). At the moment the catch is made, Tommy is 20 yards away and heading directly toward Fred with a steady speed of \( 15 \, \text{ft/s} \). Neither deviates from a straight-ahead path.

How long does the rock take to fall to the ground?

A rock is released from rest at the top of a 100-m-tall building.

How high does it go?

The springbok, an antelope found in Africa, gets its name from its remarkable jumping ability. When startled, a springbok will leap straight up into the air—a maneuver called a ``pronk.'' A springbok goes into a crouch to perform a pronk. It then extends its legs forcefully, accelerating at 35 m/s^2 for 0.70 m as its legs straighten. Legs fully extended, it leaves the ground and rises into the air.

Find an expression for the particle's acceleration \(a_s\).

A particle's velocity is given by \(v_s = [10 - (t - 5)^2]\,\mathrm{m/s}\), where \(t\) is in\( \mathrm{s} \).

What is the particle's velocity at t = 8\ \mathrm{s}?

Figure\ shows\ the\ acceleration\ graph\ for\ a\ particle\ with\ an\ initial\ velocity\ of\ 10\ \mathrm{m/s}.

How far has the sled traveled when the second rocket burns out?

A rocket sled accelerates along a long, horizontal rail. Starting from rest, two rockets burn for \(10\,\mathrm{s}\), providing a constant acceleration. One rocket then burns out, halving the acceleration, but the other burns for an additional \(5\,\mathrm{s}\) to boost the sled's speed to \(625\,\mathrm{m/s}\).

What is the bird's net displacement?

A bird flies \(100\,\mathrm{m}\) due east from a tree, then \(200\,\mathrm{m}\) northwest (that is, \(45^\circ\) north of west).

What is Carolyn's net displacement?

Carolyn drives her car north at \(30\,\mathrm{km/h}\) for \(1\,\mathrm{hour}\), east at \(60\,\mathrm{km/h}\) for \(2\,\mathrm{hours}\), then north at \(50\,\mathrm{km/h}\) for \(1\,\mathrm{hour}\).

Determine the car's speed and direction of motion.

Figure shows a car's velocity vector \(\vec{v}\).

Write the rabbit's velocity in terms of components and unit vectors.

A rabbit, escaping a fox, runs \(40.0^\circ\) north of west at \(10.0\,\mathrm{m/s}\). A coordinate system is established with the positive \(x\)-axis to the east and the positive \(y\)-axis to the north.

How long does it take to reach Cleveland?

A wiser pilot flying from Chicago to Cleveland on the same day plots a course that will take her directly to Cleveland.

How far does the car land from the base of the cliff?

A stunt man drives a car off a \(10.0\,\mathrm{m}\)-high cliff at a speed of \(20.0\,\mathrm{m/s}\).

How far does this frog leap?

Frogs, with their long, strong legs, are excellent jumpers. And thanks to the good folks of Calaveras County, California, who have a jumping frog contest every year in honor of a Mark Twain story, we have very good data on how far a determined frog can jump. High-speed cameras show that a good jumper goes into a crouch, then rapidly extends his legs by typically \(15\,\mathrm{cm}\) during a \(42\,\mathrm{ms}\) push off, leaving the ground at a \(30^\circ\) angle.

Evaluate \(\Delta\theta\).

One day when you come into lab, you see a spring-loaded wheel that can launch a ball straight up. To do so, you place the ball in a cup on the rim of the wheel, turn the wheel to stretch the spring, then release. The wheel rotates through an angle \(\Delta\theta\), then hits a stop when the cup is level with the axle and pointing straight up. The cup stops, but the ball flies out and keeps going. You're told that the wheel has been designed to have constant angular acceleration as it rotates through \(\Delta\theta\). The lab assignment is first to measure the wheel's angular acceleration. Then the lab instructor is going to place a target at height \(h\) above the point where the ball is launched. Your task will be to launch the ball so that it just barely hits the target. You'll lose points if the ball doesn't reach the target or if it slams into the target. You've determined that the wheel's diameter is \(62\,\mathrm{cm}\), its angular acceleration is \(200\,\mathrm{rad/s^2}\), the mass of the ball is \(25\,\mathrm{g}\), and the instructor places the target \(190\,\mathrm{cm}\) above the launch point.

What force does the femur exert on the kneecap in this position?

Your kneecap (patella) is attached by a tendon to your quadriceps muscle. This tendon pulls at a \(10^\circ\) angle relative to the femur, the bone of your upper leg. The patella is also attached to your lower leg (tibia) by a tendon that pulls parallel to the leg. To balance these forces, the lower end of your femur pushes outward on the patella. Bending your knee increases the tension in the tendons, and both have a tension of \(60\,\mathrm{N}\) when the knee is bent to make a \(70^\circ\) angle between the upper and lower leg.

What is its speed after \(5.0\,\mathrm{s}\)?

A \(1500\,\mathrm{kg}\) car is pulled by a tow truck. The tension in the tow rope is \(2500\,\mathrm{N}\), and a \(200\,\mathrm{N}\) friction force opposes the motion. The car starts from rest.

What maximum altitude does the rocket reach?

A \(500\,\mathrm{g}\) model rocket with a weight of \(4.90\,\mathrm{N}\) is launched straight up. The small rocket motor burns for \(5.00\,\mathrm{s}\) and has a steady thrust of \(20.0\,\mathrm{N}\). Ignore the mass loss of the burned fuel.

How far will the box slide before coming to rest?

Carol pushes a \(50\,\mathrm{kg}\) wood box across a wood floor at a steady speed of \(2.0\,\mathrm{m/s}\). And she stops pushing.

At what angle will the file cabinet begin to slide?

A \(50\,\mathrm{kg}\) steel file cabinet is in the back of a dump truck. The truck's bed, also made of steel, is slowly tilted.

At what speed does the magnitude of the drag equal the magnitude of the rolling friction?

The profile of a typical \(1500\,\mathrm{kg}\) passenger car, as seen from the front, is \(1.6\,\mathrm{m}\) wide and \(1.4\,\mathrm{m}\) high. Aerodynamic body shaping gives a drag coefficient of \(0.35\).

What is the maximum acceleration the truck can have without the box slipping?

A \(100\,\mathrm{kg}\) box of dimensions \(50\,\mathrm{cm} \times 50\,\mathrm{cm} \times 50\,\mathrm{cm}\) is in the back of a flatbed truck. The coefficients of friction between the box and the bed of the truck are \(\mu_s = 0.40\) and \(\mu_k = 0.20\).

What is the maximum velocity of a \(500\,\mathrm{g}\) object?

Force \(F_x = c \sin(\pi t / T)\), where \(c\) and \(T\) are constants, is applied to an object of mass \(m\) that moves on a horizontal, frictionless surface. The object is at rest at the origin at \(t = 0\). \(c = 2.5\,\mathrm{N}\) and \(T = 1.0\,\mathrm{s}\).

What is the maximum magnitude \(\vec{F}_T\) can have without the crate sliding?

You and a friend have just loaded a \(200\,\mathrm{kg}\) crate filled with priceless art objects into the back of a \(2000\,\mathrm{kg}\) truck. As you press down on the accelerator, force \(\vec{F}_{\mathrm{surface\ on\ truck}}\) propels the truck forward. To keep things simple, call this just \(\vec{F}_T\). The static and kinetic coefficients of friction between the crate and the bed of the truck are \(0.80\) and \(0.30\). Rolling friction of the truck is negligible.

What is the proper angle?

Serious fractures of the leg often need a stretching force to keep contracting leg muscles from forcing the broken bones together too hard. This is done using *traction*, an arrangement of a rope, a weight, and pulleys as shown in figure. The rope must make the same angle on both sides of the pulley so that the net force on the leg is horizontal, but the angle can be adjusted to control the amount of traction. The doctor has specified \(50\,\mathrm{N}\) of traction for this patient with a \(4.2\,\mathrm{kg}\) hanging mass.

What is the stagehand's acceleration?

A \(200\,\mathrm{kg}\) set used in a play is stored in the loft above the stage. The rope holding the set passes up and over a pulley, then is tied backstage. The director tells a \(100\,\mathrm{kg}\) stagehand to lower the set. When he unties the rope, the set falls and the unfortunate man is hoisted into the loft.

What is the safe's speed when it hits the truck?

Bank robbers have pushed a \(1000\,\mathrm{kg}\) safe to a second-story floor-to-ceiling window. They plan to break the window, then lower the safe \(3.0\,\mathrm{m}\) to their truck. Not being too clever, they stack up \(500\,\mathrm{kg}\) of furniture, tie a rope between the safe and the furniture, and place the rope over a pulley. Then they push the safe out the window. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the furniture and the floor is \(0.50\).

By how much has it been deflected sideways?

A small rocket for gathering weather data has a mass of \(30\,\mathrm{kg}\) and generates \(1500\,\mathrm{N}\) of thrust. On a windy day, the wind exerts a \(20\,\mathrm{N}\) horizontal force on the rocket.The rocket is launched straight up. It reaches a height of \(1.0\,\mathrm{km}\). Because the rocket goes much higher than this, assume there's no significant mass loss during the first \(1.0\,\mathrm{km}\) of flight.

How many revolutions per minute (\(\mathrm{rpm}\)) does the cart make?

An energetic father places his \(20\,\mathrm{kg}\) child on a \(5.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) cart to which a \(2.0\,\mathrm{m}\)-long rope is attached. He then holds the end of the rope and spins the cart and child around in a circle, keeping the rope parallel to the ground.The tension in the rope is \(100\,\mathrm{N}\). Rolling friction between the cart's wheels and the ground is negligible.

What is the maximum speed?

A \(1500\,\mathrm{kg}\) car can make a left turn around a curve of radius \(50\,\mathrm{m}\) on a level (unbanked) road without sliding.

At what speed \(v_0\) can a car take this curve without assistance from friction?

A highway curve of radius \(70\,\mathrm{m}\) is banked at a \(15^\circ\) angle.

What is the maximum angular speed, in \(\mathrm{rpm}\), with which he can swing the rock?

A Stone Age hunter places a \(1.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) rock in a sling and swings it in a horizontal circle around his head on a \(1.0\,\mathrm{m}\)-long vine. The vine breaks at a tension of \(200\,\mathrm{N}\).

What minimum speed \(v_{\min}\) must the ball maintain to remain at a constant height \(h\)?

A small ball of mass \(m\) rolls in a horizontal circle around the inside of the inverted cone shown in figure. The walls of the cone make an angle \(\theta\) with a horizontal plane. The coefficient of static friction between the ball and the cone is \(\mu_s\); rolling friction is negligible.

What is the *average* force of the bat on the ball?

A \(150\,\mathrm{g}\) baseball is thrown with a speed of \(20\,\mathrm{m/s}\). It is hit straight back toward the pitcher at a speed of \(40\,\mathrm{m/s}\). The interaction force between the ball and the bat is shown in figure.

How high does the ball bounce?

A \(100\,\mathrm{g}\) rubber ball is dropped from a height of \(2.00\,\mathrm{m}\) onto a hard floor. Figure shows the force that the floor exerts on the ball.

What is the speed of the \(500\,\mathrm{g}\) glider after the collision?

A \(250\,\mathrm{g}\) air-track glider is pushed across a level track toward a \(500\,\mathrm{g}\) glider that is at rest. Figure shows a position-versus-time graph of the \(250\,\mathrm{g}\) glider as recorded by a motion detector. Best-fit lines have been found.

What is the cart's speed just after Bob jumps on?

Bob sees a stationary cart \(8.0\,\mathrm{m}\) in front of him. He decides to run to the cart as fast as he can, jump on, and roll down the street. Bob has a mass of \(75\,\mathrm{kg}\) and the cart's mass is \(25\,\mathrm{kg}\). Bob accelerates at a steady \(1.0\,\mathrm{m/s^2}\).

What is the recoil speed of the rifle?

A \(10\,\mathrm{g}\) bullet is fired from a \(3.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) rifle with a speed of \(500\,\mathrm{m/s}\).

What are the atomic masses of the ejected fragment?

A \({}^{238}\mathrm{U}\) uranium nucleus is radioactive. It spontaneously disintegrates into a small fragment that is ejected with a measured speed of \(1.50 \times 10^7\,\mathrm{m/s}\) and a \daughter nucleus\ that recoils with a measured speed of \(2.56 \times 10^5\,\mathrm{m/s}\).

What are the speed of the falcon (now holding the pigeon) immediately after impact?

Peregrine falcons often grab their prey from above while both falcon and prey are in flight. A \(0.80\,\mathrm{kg}\) falcon, flying at \(18\,\mathrm{m/s}\), swoops down at a \(45^\circ\) angle from behind a \(0.36\,\mathrm{kg}\) pigeon flying horizontally at \(9.0\,\mathrm{m/s}\).

What are the speed of the third fragment?

A \(10.0\,\mathrm{g}\) projectile is traveling east at \(2.0\,\mathrm{m/s}\) when it suddenly explodes into three pieces. A \(3.0\,\mathrm{g}\) fragment is shot due west at \(10\,\mathrm{m/s}\) while another \(3.0\,\mathrm{g}\) fragment travels \(40^\circ\) north of east at \(12\,\mathrm{m/s}\).

How high does the pebble go?

Bob uses a slingshot to shoot a \20\,\mathrm{g}\) pebble straight up with a speed of \(25\,\mathrm{m/s}\).

Calculate rock's speed just before it hits the ground.

The \(1.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) rock shown in figure is released from rest. Use both Amber's and Bill's perspectives.

What is her speed at the bottom?

Christine runs forward with her sled at \(2.0\,\mathrm{m/s}\). She hops onto the sled at the top of a \(5.0\,\mathrm{m}\)-high, very slippery slope.

What was the speed of the bullet?

A \(10\,\mathrm{g}\) bullet is fired into a \(1200\,\mathrm{g}\) wood block hanging from a \(150\,\mathrm{cm}\)-long string. The bullet embeds itself into the block, and the block then swings out to an angle of \(40^\circ\).

When does the block slip?

Figure shows a spring attached to a \(2.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) block. The other end of the spring is pulled by a motorized toy train that moves forward at \(5.0\,\mathrm{cm/s}\). The spring constant is \(50\,\mathrm{N/m}\), and the coefficient of static friction between the block and the surface is \(0.60\). The spring is at its equilibrium length at \(t=0\,\mathrm{s}\) when the train starts to move.

What is the ball's speed as it leaves the barrel?

A spring-loaded toy gun launches a \(10\,\mathrm{g}\) plastic ball. The spring, with spring constant \(10\,\mathrm{N/m}\), is compressed by \(10\,\mathrm{cm}\) as the ball is pushed into the barrel. When the trigger is pulled, the spring is released and shoots the ball back out. Assume friction is negligible.

What is the length of the compressed spring?

A spring of length \(L_0\) and spring constant \(k\) is standing on one end. A block of mass \(m\) is placed on the spring, compressing it.

What are the velocities of the \(1.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) block as they fly apart?

A spring with spring constant \(2000\,\mathrm{N/m}\) is sandwiched between a \(1.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) block and a \(2.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) block on a frictionless table. The blocks are pushed together to compress the spring by \(10\,\mathrm{cm}\), then released.

To what angle does the ball rebound?

A \(200\,\mathrm{g}\) steel ball hangs on a \(1.0\,\mathrm{m}\)-long string. The ball is pulled sideways so that the string is at a \(45^\circ\) angle, then released. At the very bottom of its swing the ball strikes a \(500\,\mathrm{g}\) steel paperweight that is resting on a frictionless table.

How much work does the tension do?

A rope inclined upward at a \(45^\circ\) angle pulls a suitcase through the airport. The tension in the rope is \(20\,\mathrm{N}\). The suitcase is pulled \(100\,\mathrm{m}\).

What is the rocket's speed at a height of \(500\,\mathrm{m}\)?

A \(150{,}000\,\mathrm{kg}\) rocket is launched straight up. The rocket motor generates a thrust of \(4.0 \times 10^6\,\mathrm{N}\). Ignore air resistance and any slight mass loss.

What is the car's speed after traveling \(200\,\mathrm{m}\)?

A \(1500\,\mathrm{kg}\) car accelerates from rest. Figure shows the net force on the car (propulsion force minus any drag forces) as it travels from \(x=0\,\mathrm{m}\) to \(x=200\,\mathrm{m}\).

What is his speed at the bottom?

A \(70\,\mathrm{kg}\) skier is gliding at \(2.0\,\mathrm{m/s}\) when he starts down a very slippery \(50\,\mathrm{m}\)-long, \(10^\circ\) slope.

What is the cube's launch speed, as it leaves the spring?

The pincube machine was an ill-fated predecessor of the pinball machine. A \(100\,\mathrm{g}\) cube is launched by pulling a spring back \(20\,\mathrm{cm}\) and releasing it. The spring constant is \(20\,\mathrm{N/m}\) and the surface is frictionless.

How much power is being supplied by the hand or motor pulling the rope?

A \(5.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) box is attached to one end of a spring with spring constant \(80\,\mathrm{N/m}\). The other end of the spring is anchored to a wall. Initially the box is at rest at the spring's equilibrium position. A rope with a constant tension of \(100\,\mathrm{N}\) then pulls the box away from the wall. The coefficient of friction between the box and the floor is \(0.30\).The box has moved \(50\,\mathrm{cm}\).

What is the speed of the \(2.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) ball?

A \(500\,\mathrm{g}\) ball and a \(2.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) ball are connected by a massless \(50\,\mathrm{cm}\)-long rod. They rotate about the center of mass at \(40\,\mathrm{rpm}\).

Find the tangential acceleration of the rod.

Find the center of mass of a thin, uniform rod of length \(L\) and mass \(M\). Use this result. A \(1.60\,\mathrm{m}\)-long rod rotates about its center of mass with an angular acceleration of \(6.0\,\mathrm{rad/s^2}\).

At what angular velocity does the widget have \(100\,\mathrm{mJ}\) of rotational energy?

Students participating in an engineering project design the triangular widget seen in figure. The three masses, held together by lightweight plastic rods, rotate in the plane of the page about an axle passing through the right-angle corner.

What is the speed of the tip of the rod as it hits the wall?

A \(1.0\,\mathrm{m}\)-long, \(200\,\mathrm{g}\) rod is hinged at one end and connected to a wall. It is held out horizontally, then released.

Find the moment of inertia of a circular disk.

A disk of radius \(R\) and mass \(M\) that rotates on an axis passing through its center.

How much torque does Luis exert on the nut?

Luis uses a \(20\,\mathrm{cm}\)-long wrench to turn a nut. The wrench handle is tilted \(30^\circ\) above the horizontal, and Luis pulls straight down on the end with a force of \(100\,\mathrm{N}\).

What is the gravitational torque about the support?

The \(4.00\,\mathrm{m}\)-long, \(500\,\mathrm{kg}\) steel beam shown in figure is supported \(1.20\,\mathrm{m}\) from the right end.

What is the structure's angular velocity after \(30\,\mathrm{s}\)?

Far out in space, a \(100{,}000\,\mathrm{kg}\) rocket and a \(200{,}000\,\mathrm{kg}\) rocket are docked at opposite ends of a motionless \(90\,\mathrm{m}\)-long connecting tunnel. The tunnel is rigid and its mass is much less than that of either rocket. The rockets start their engines simultaneously, each generating \(50{,}000\,\mathrm{N}\) of thrust in opposite directions.

On start-up,how long does it take the propeller to reach \(200\,\mathrm{rpm}\)?

The engine in a small airplane is specified to have a torque of \(60\,\mathrm{N\,m}\). This engine drives a \(2.0\,\mathrm{m}\)-long, \(40\,\mathrm{kg}\) propeller.

What is the initial angular acceleration of the disk when the pin is removed?

Figure shows a piece of a large machine. A \(10.0\,\mathrm{cm}\)-diameter, \(5.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) disk turns on an axle. A vertical cable attached to the edge of the disk exerts a \(100\,\mathrm{N}\) force but, initially, a pin keeps the disk from rotating.

How long does it take to reach the floor?

A \(2.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) bucket is attached to a massless string that is wrapped around a \(1.0\,\mathrm{kg}\), \(4.0\,\mathrm{cm}\)-diameter cylinder, as shown in figure. The cylinder rotates on an axle through the center. The bucket is released from rest \(1.0\,\mathrm{m}\) above the floor.

What is the magnitude of \(\vec{F}_{\mathrm{elbow}}\)?

Figure shows the forces acting on our simplified model of the forearm. The biceps pulls the forearm up against the upper arm at the elbow, so the force \(\vec{F}_{\mathrm{elbow}}\) on the forearm at the elbow—a force due to the upper arm—is a downward force.

What would be the earth's speed as it crashed?

Suppose the earth suddenly came to a halt and ceased revolving around the sun. The gravitational force would then pull it directly into the sun.

What is the minimum value of \(\mu_s\)?

A \(3.0\,\mathrm{m}\)-long ladder leans against a frictionless wall at an angle of \(60^\circ\). The coefficient of static friction with the ground, that prevents the ladder from slipping.

What is the tallest can of food.

A typical can of food is \(7.5\,\mathrm{cm}\) in diameter. The can rest on a \(30^\circ\) incline without falling over.

What is the rotation frequency after the expansion?

Two equal masses are at the ends of a massless \(50\,\mathrm{cm}\)-long rod. The rod spins at \(2.0\,\mathrm{rev/s}\) about an axis through its midpoint. Suddenly, a compressed gas expands the rod out to a length of \(160\,\mathrm{cm}\).

What is the final angular velocity of the combined system?

A \(20\,\mathrm{cm}\)-diameter, \(2.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) solid disk is rotating at \(200\,\mathrm{rpm}\). A \(20\,\mathrm{cm}\)-diameter, \(1.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) circular loop is dropped straight down onto the rotating disk. Friction causes the loop to accelerate until it is riding on the disk.

What was the speed of the bullet?

A \(2.0\,\mathrm{kg}\) block hangs from the end of a \(1.5\,\mathrm{kg}\), \(1.0\,\mathrm{m}\)-long rod, together forming a pendulum that swings from a frictionless pivot at the top end of the rod. A \(10\,\mathrm{g}\) bullet is fired horizontally into the block, where it sticks, causing the pendulum to swing out to a \(30^\circ\) angle.

What speed does the rocket need?

A 1000\ \mathrm{kg} rocket is fired straight away from the surface of the earth. The rocket need to escape from the gravitational pull of the earth and never return. Assume a nonrotating earth.

By what percentage would your answer be in error if you used a flat-earth approximation?

A less-than-successful inventor wants to launch small satellites into orbit by launching them straight up from the surface of the earth at very high speed.

How far apart are the two stars?

Astronomers discover a binary star system with a period of \(90\,\mathrm{days}\). Both stars have a mass twice that of the sun.

At what times during the first cycle does the mass pass through \(x=20\,\mathrm{cm}\)?

Figure shows a liquid-detecting prism device that might be used inside a washing machine. Thus a large signal from the light sensor indicates the absence of liquid in the reservoir.

How long after the animal emits a wave is its reflection detected?

What mass \( m \) must be hung from this end of the string to produce one loop?

When you walk with a cup of coffee (diameter \( 8\,\mathrm{cm} \)) at just the right pace of about one step per second, the coffee sloshes higher and higher in your cup until eventually it starts to spill over the top, figure.

What is the spring constant of the C--O bond?

Carbon dioxide is a linear molecule. The carbon--oxygen bonds in this molecule act very much like springs. Figure shows one possible way the oxygen atoms in this molecule can oscillate: the oxygen atoms oscillate symmetrically in and out, while the central carbon atom remains at rest. Hence each oxygen atom acts like a simple harmonic oscillator with a mass equal to the mass of an oxygen atom. It is observed that this oscillation occurs at a frequency \( f = 2.83 \times 10^{13}\,\mathrm{Hz} \).

Dtermine the wavelengths of the resonant vibrations of such a string with one end fixed and the other free.

A string can have a free end if that end is attached to a ring that can slide without friction on a vertical pole (figure).

How far from the bank should a trout fisherman stand (figure) so trout won't be frightened by his voice?

For any type of wave that reaches a boundary beyond which its speed is increased, there is a maximum incident angle if there is to be a transmitted refracted wave. This maximum incident angle \( \theta_{i\mathrm{M}} \) corresponds to an angle of refraction equal to \( 90^{\circ} \). If \( \theta_i > \theta_{i\mathrm{M}} \), all the wave is reflected at the boundary and none is refracted, because refraction would correspond to \( \sin \theta_r > 1 \) (where \( \theta_r \) is the angle of refraction), which is impossible. This phenomenon is referred to as total internal reflection.His voice is \( 1.8\,\mathrm{m} \ above the ground.The speed of sound is about \( 343\,\mathrm{m/s} \) in air and \( 1440\,\mathrm{m/s} \) in water.

What is the fundamental frequency of this horn?

The alpenhorn (figure) was once used to send signals from one Alpine village to another. While driving behind a car traveling at \( 3.00\,\mathrm{m/s} \), you notice that one of the car's tires has a small hemispherical bump on its rim as shown in figure. The radii of the car's tires are \( 0.300\,\mathrm{m} \).

What is the total energy stored in the system when the spring is stretched?

A \( 0.250\,\mathrm{kg} \) block resting on a frictionless, horizontal surface is attached to a spring whose force constant is \( 83.8\,\mathrm{N/m} \) as in figure. A horizontal force \( \vec{F} \) causes the spring to stretch a distance of \( 5.46\,\mathrm{cm} \) from its equilibrium position.

By what percentage does the period differ from the period of a simple pendulum \( 1.00\,\mathrm{m} \) long?

A very light rigid rod of length \( 0.500\,\mathrm{m} \) extends straight out from one end of a meterstick. The combination is suspended from a pivot at the upper end of the rod as shown in figure. The combination is then pulled out by a small angle and released.

What is the torsion constant of the attached spring?

A watch balance wheel (figure) has a period of oscillation of \( 0.250\,\mathrm{s} \). The wheel is constructed so that its mass of \( 20.0\,\mathrm{g} \) is concentrated around a rim of radius \( 0.500\,\mathrm{cm} \).

Determine this period.

A small ball of mass \( M \) is attached to the end of a uniform rod of equal mass \( M \) and length \( L \) that is pivoted at the top (figure). \( L = 2.00\,\mathrm{m} \).

For this motion, find the maximum acceleration.

An object attached to a spring vibrates with simple harmonic motion as described by Figure.

What maximum amplitude of oscillation can the system have?

A large block \( P \) attached to a light spring executes horizontal, simple harmonic motion as it slides across a frictionless surface with a frequency \( f = 1.50\,\mathrm{Hz} \). Block \( B \) rests on it as shown in figure, and the coefficient of static friction between the two is \( \mu_s = 0.600 \).The block \( B \) is not to slip.

Find the angular frequency.

A horizontal plank of mass \( 5.00\,\mathrm{kg} \) and length \( 2.00\,\mathrm{m} \) is pivoted at one end. The plank's other end is supported by a spring of force constant \( 100\,\mathrm{N/m} \) (figure).The plank is displaced by a small angle \( \theta \) from its horizontal equilibrium position and released.The plank moves with simple harmonic motion.

Find the frequency of vibration of the system for small values of the amplitude (small \( \theta \)).

A pendulum of length \( L \) and mass \( M \) has a spring of force constant \( k \) connected to it at a distance \( h \) below its point of suspension (figure). Assume the vertical suspension rod of length \( L \) is rigid, but ignore its mass.

Determine the period of the motion.

A light balloon filled with helium of density \( 0.179\,\mathrm{kg/m^3} \) is tied to a light string of length \( L = 3.00\,\mathrm{m} \). The string is tied to the ground forming an inverted simple pendulum (figure).The balloon is displaced slightly from equilibrium as in figure and released.Take the density of air to be \( 1.20\,\mathrm{kg/m^3} \).Assume the air applies a buoyant force on the balloon but does not otherwise affect its motion.

What is the highest possible value of the angular frequency of oscillation of the object?

One end of a light spring with force constant \( k = 100\,\mathrm{N/m} \) is attached to a vertical wall. A light string is tied to the other end of the horizontal spring. As shown in figure, the string changes from horizontal to vertical as it passes over a pulley of mass \( M \) in the shape of a solid disk of radius \( R = 2.00\,\mathrm{cm} \). The pulley is free to turn on a fixed, smooth axle. The vertical section of the string supports an object of mass \( m = 200\,\mathrm{g} \). The string does not slip at its contact with the pulley. The object is pulled downward a small distance and released.The pulley radius is doubled to \( R = 4.00\,\mathrm{cm} \).

How far apart are the objects when the spring is fully stretched for the first time?

An object of mass \( m_1 = 9.00\,\mathrm{kg} \) is in equilibrium when connected to a light spring of constant \( k = 100\,\mathrm{N/m} \) that is fastened to a wall as shown in figure. A second object, \( m_2 = 7.00\,\mathrm{kg} \), is slowly pushed up against \( m_1 \), compressing the spring by the amount \( A = 0.200\,\mathrm{m} \) (see figure). The system is then released, and both objects start moving to the right on the frictionless surface.

Find the period of oscillation.

A block of mass \( M \) is connected to a spring of mass \( m \) and oscillates in simple harmonic motion on a frictionless, horizontal track (figure). The force constant of the spring is \( k \), and the equilibrium length is \( \ell \). Assume all portions of the spring oscillate in phase and the velocity of a segment of the spring of length \( dx \) is proportional to the distance \( x \) from the fixed end; that is, \( v_x = (x/\ell)v \). Also, notice that the mass of a segment of the spring is \( dm = (m/\ell)dx \).

What is the period of the pendulum?

A light, cubical container of volume \( a^3 \) is initially filled with a liquid of mass density \( \rho \) as shown in figure. The cube is initially supported by a light string to form a simple pendulum of length \( L_i \), measured from the center of mass of the filled container, where \( L_i \gg a \). The liquid is allowed to flow from the bottom of the container at a constant rate \( dM/dt \). At any time \( t \), the level of the liquid in the container is \( h \) and the length of the pendulum is \( L \) (measured relative to the instantaneous center of mass) as shown in figure.The liquid completely runs out of the container.

How many detection stations are necessary to locate the focus unambiguously?

In an earthquake, both S (transverse) and P (longitudinal) waves propagate from the focus of the earthquake. The focus is in the ground radially below the epicenter on the surface (figure). Assume the waves move in straight lines through uniform material. The S waves travel through the Earth more slowly than the P waves (at about \( 5\,\mathrm{km/s} \) versus \( 8\,\mathrm{km/s} \)).

Determine the maximum transverse acceleration of an element of the string.

The string shown in figure is driven at a frequency of \( 5.00\,\mathrm{Hz} \). The amplitude of the motion is \( A = 12.0\,\mathrm{cm} \), and the wave speed is \( v = 20.0\,\mathrm{m/s} \). Furthermore, the wave is such that \( y = 0 \) at \( x = 0 \) and \( t = 0 \).

What is the wave speed?

Tension is maintained in a string as in figure. The observed wave speed is \( v = 24.0\,\mathrm{m/s} \) when the suspended mass is \( m = 3.00\,\mathrm{kg} \).The suspended mass is \( m = 2.00\,\mathrm{kg} \).

What should be the mass of the object suspended from the string?

A light string with a mass per unit length of \( 8.00\,\mathrm{g/m} \) has its ends tied to two walls separated by a distance equal to three-fourths the length of the string (figure). An object of mass \( m \) is suspended from the center of the string, putting a tension in the string.The wave speed is to be \( 60.0\,\mathrm{m/s} \).

Through what angle does the block rotate in the time interval during which a transverse wave travels along the string from the center of the circle to the block?

A block of mass \( M = 0.450\,\mathrm{kg} \) is attached to one end of a cord of mass \( 0.003\,20\,\mathrm{kg} \); the other end of the cord is attached to a fixed point. The block rotates with constant angular speed in a circle on a frictionless, horizontal table as shown in figure.

Determine the tension in the chain in terms of \( \mu \) and \( v_0 \).

If a loop of chain is spun at high speed, it can roll along the ground like a circular hoop without collapsing. Consider a chain of uniform linear mass density \( \mu \) whose center of mass travels to the right at a high speed \( v_0 \) as shown in figure.Assume the weight of an individual link is negligible compared to the tension.

What speed is $B$ traveling at?

Spaceship $A$ moves away from Earth at a speed of $0.800c$. Spaceship $B$ pursues at a speed of $0.900c$ relative to Earth. Observers on Earth see $B$ overtaking $A$ at a relative speed of $0.100c$.As seen by the crew of spaceship $B$, spaceship $B$ is overtaking spaceship $A$ at a certain speed.

What is the length of $L_1 as measured by the observer?

A box is cubical with sides of proper lengths $L_1 = L_2 = L_3$, as shown in Figure, when viewed in its own rest frame. If this block moves parallel to one of its edges with a speed of $0.80c$ past an observer.

According to Ed, how fast is the ball moving?

Owen and Dina are at rest in frame $S'$, which is moving with a speed of $0.600c$ with respect to frame $S$. They play a game of catch while Ed, at rest in frame $S$, watches the action (figure). Owen throws the ball to Dina with a speed of $0.800c$ (according to Owen) and their separation (measured in $S'$) is equal to $1.80 \times 10^{12}m$.

What is the total travel time of the pulse as measured by observers in the spacecraft?

An observer in a coasting spacecraft moves toward a mirror at speed $v$ relative to the reference frame labeled by S in Figure. The mirror is stationary with respect to S. A light pulse emitted by the spacecraft travels toward the mirror and is reflected back to the spacecraft. The spacecraft is a distance $d$ from the mirror (as measured by observers in S) at the moment the light pulse leaves the spacecraft.

What is the orientation angle in a reference frame moving with the rod?

An observer moving at a speed of $0.995c$ relative to a rod (figure) measures its length to be $2.00m$ and sees its length to be oriented at $30.0^{\circ}$ with respect to its direction of motion.

Determine the value of $\Delta \lambda = \lambda'' - \lambda$.

A photon having wavelength $\lambda$ scatters off a free electron at A (figure), producing a second photon having wavelength $\lambda'$. This photon then scatters off another free electron at B, producing a third photon having wavelength $\lambda''$ and moving in a direction directly opposite the original photon as shown in the figure.

Determine the temperature of the blackbody.

Figure shows the spectrum of light emitted by a firefly. A blackbody would emit radiation peaked at the same frequency.

What is the shortest possible wavelength in the Balmer series?

The Balmer series for the hydrogen atom corresponds to electronic transitions that terminate in the state with quantum number $n = 2$ as shown in Figure. Consider the spectral line of shortest wavelength corresponding to a transition shown in the figure.

Find the angle the ray makes with the normal to $M_2$ after it is reflected from both mirrors.

Two mirrors make an angle of $120^{\circ}$ with each other, as in figure. A ray is incident on mirror $M_1$ at an angle of $65^{\circ}$ to the normal.

How does the answer for $\theta_3$ change?

A light ray of wavelength $589$ nm (produced by a sodium lamp) traveling through air is incident on a smooth, flat slab of crown glass at an angle $\theta_1$ of $30.0^{\circ}$ to the normal, as sketched in figure. The ray enters water below the slab instead of the air.

What is the value of $\Delta y$, the amount by which the violet light is displaced vertically?

A beam of light is incident on a prism of a certain glass at an angle of $\theta_1 = 30.0^{\circ}$, as shown in figure. The index of refraction of the glass for violet light is $1.80$.

Find the angle of refraction $\theta_2$.

A ray of light travels from air into another medium, making an angle of $\theta_1 = 45.0^{\circ}$ with the normal as in Figure.The second medium is water.

Determine the distance the reflected light beam travels before striking mirror 2.

The two mirrors in figure meet at a right angle. The beam of light in the vertical plane $P$ strikes mirror 1 as shown.

What is the angle $\theta_2$?

Two plane mirrors are at an angle of $\theta_1 = 50.0^{\circ}$ with each other as in the side view shown in figure. A horizontal ray is incident on mirror 1.The outgoing reflected ray make with the surface of mirror 2.

At which of these points does part of the ray enter the air?

Figure shows a light ray traveling in a slab of crown glass surrounded by air. The ray is incident on the right surface at an angle of $55^{\circ}$ with the normal and then reflects from points $A$, $B$, and $C$.

Use the expression $$\frac{h}{d} = \sqrt{\frac{n^2 - 1}{4 - n^2}}$$ to find the height of the container.

A person looking into an empty container is able to see the far edge of the container's bottom, as shown in figure. The height of the container is $h$, and its width is $d$. When the container is completely filled with a fluid of index of refraction $n$ and viewed from the same angle, the person can see the center of a coin at the middle of the container's bottom, as shown in figure. Assuming the container has a width of $8.00\ \text{cm}$ and is filled with water.

Calculate the time required for the light to pass through the glass block.

A ray of light strikes a flat, $2.00\ \text{cm}$-thick block of glass ($n = 1.50$) at an angle of $30.0^{\circ}$ with respect to the normal (Figure).

Determine the angles $\theta'$.

The light beam shown in figure makes an angle of $20.0^{\circ}$ with the normal line $NN'$ in the linseed oil. (The refractive index for linseed oil is $1.48$.)

Find the index of refraction of the prism.

A laser beam is incident on a $45^{\circ}-45^{\circ}-90^{\circ}$ prism perpendicular to one of its faces, as shown in Figure. The transmitted beam that exits the hypotenuse of the prism makes an angle of $\theta = 15.0^{\circ}$ with the direction of the incident beam.

Find the angle of refraction \( \theta_2 \) of the light ray leaving the block at \( P \).

A block of crown glass is immersed in water as in Figure. A light ray is incident on the top face at an angle of \( \theta_1 = 42.0^\circ \) with the normal and exits the block at point \( P \).

Determine the depth of the tumor.

A narrow beam of ultrasonic waves reflects off the liver tumor in Figure. The speed of the wave is \( 10.0\% \) less in the liver than in the surrounding medium.

What is the angular dispersion of visible light passing through an equilateral prism of apex angle \( 60.0^\circ \)?

The index of refraction for violet light in silica flint glass is \( 1.66 \) and that for red light is \( 1.62 \). The angle of incidence is \( 50.0^\circ \).(See figure)

Determine the angle of incidence, \( \theta_1 \).

The light beam in Figure strikes surface 2 at the critical angle.

Find the minimum diameter of the raft that would prevent the diamond from being seen.

A jewel thief hides a diamond by placing it on the bottom of a public swimming pool. He places a circular raft on the surface of the water directly above and centered over the diamond, as shown in Figure. The surface of the water is calm and the pool is \( 2.00\,\mathrm{m} \) deep.

Determine the maximum angle \( \theta \).

The angle \( \theta \) for which the light rays incident on the end of the light pipe in Figure are subject to total internal reflection along the walls of the pipe. Assume the light pipe has an index of refraction of \( 1.36 \) and the outside medium is air.

What is the maximum distance \( x \) the man can stand from the edge and still see the same boundary?

When a man stands near the edge of an empty drainage ditch of depth \( 2.80\,\mathrm{m} \), he can barely see the boundary between the opposite wall and bottom of the ditch as in Figure. The distance from his eyes to the ground is \( 1.85\,\mathrm{m} \).The drainage ditch is filled with water as in Figure.

At what value of \( n_2 \) does total internal reflection cease at point \( P \)?

As shown in Figure, a light ray is incident normal to one face of a \( 30^\circ\text{--}60^\circ\text{--}90^\circ \) block of flint glass (a prism) that is immersed in water. A substance is dissolved in the water to increase the index of refraction \( n_2 \).

Evaluate \( R \).

An optical fiber with index of refraction \( n \) and diameter \( d \) is surrounded by air. Light is sent into the fiber along its axis, as shown in Figure. Assuming the diameter of the fiber is \( 100\,\mu\mathrm{m} \) and its index of refraction is \( 1.40 \).

Determine the angle \( \phi \) made by the outgoing ray with the normal to the right face of the prism.

A light ray traveling in air is incident on one face of a right-angle prism with index of refraction \( n = 1.50 \), as shown in Figure, and the ray follows the path shown in the figure. Assumed\( \theta = 60.0^\circ \) and the base of the prism is mirrored.

Determine the index of refraction of the material.

A transparent cylinder of radius \( R = 2.00\,\mathrm{m} \) has a mirrored surface on its right half, as shown in Figure. A light ray traveling in air is incident on the left side of the cylinder. The incident light ray and the exiting light ray are parallel, and \( d = 2.00\,\mathrm{m} \).

What must the incident angle \( \theta_1 \) be?

Figure shows the path of a beam of light through several layers with different indices of refraction. The incident angle \( \theta_1 \) have total internal reflection at the surface between the medium with \( n = 1.20 \) and the medium with \( n = 1.00 \).

How long does it take the light ray to travel through the plastic?

A light ray enters a rectangular block of plastic at an angle \( \theta_1 = 45.0^\circ\) and emerges at an angle \( \theta_2 = 76.0^\circ \), as shown in Figure. The light ray enters the plastic at a point \( L = 50.0\,\mathrm{cm} \) from the bottom edge.

Determine the value of \( \theta \).

A thick piece of Lucite \( (n = 1.50) \) is has the shape of a quarter circle of radius \( R = 12.0\,\mathrm{cm} \) as shown in the side view of Figure. A light ray traveling in air parallel to the base of the Lucite is incident at a distance \( h = 6.00\,\mathrm{cm} \) above the base and emerges out of the Lucite at an angle \( \theta \) with the horizontal.

Find the height of the coin's image.

A coin \( 2.00\,\mathrm{cm} \) in diameter is embedded in a solid glass ball of radius \( 30.0\,\mathrm{cm} \) (Figure). The index of refraction of the ball is \( 1.50 \), and the coin is \( 20.0\,\mathrm{cm} \) from the surface.

How long is the fish's image?

A small fish is swimming at a depth \( d \) below the surface of a pond (Figure). The fish is \( 12\,\mathrm{cm} \) long.

Locate the image formed by the mirror and lens.

An object is placed \( 20.0\,\mathrm{cm} \) to the right of a concave mirror with focal length \( 12.0\,\mathrm{cm} \) and \( 30.0\,\mathrm{cm} \) to the left of a converging lens with focal length \( 10.0\,\mathrm{cm} \), as in Figure. The mirror is moved so that it is \( 6.00\,\mathrm{cm} \) away from the object.

What is the final image's magnification?

A periscope (Figure) is useful for viewing objects that cannot be seen directly. It can be used in submarines and when watching golf matches or parades from behind a crowd of people. Suppose the object is a distance \( p_1 \) from the upper mirror and the centers of the two flat mirrors are separated by a distance \( h \).

Determine the apparent distance of the goldfish from the wall according to an observer outside the bowl.

A goldfish is swimming inside a spherical bowl of water having an index of refraction $n = 1.333$. Suppose the goldfish is $p = 10.0$ cm from the wall of a bowl of radius $|R| = 15.0$ cm, as in Figure. Neglect the refraction of light caused by the wall of the bowl.
options: A: $9.00$ cm inside the wall of the bowl
B: $12.00$ cm inside the wall of the bowl
C: $15.00$ cm inside the wall of the bowl
D: $18.00$ cm inside the wall of the bowl

text:
Determine the focal length of the lens.

The nickel's image in Figure has twice the diameter of the nickel when the lens is $2.84$ cm from the nickel.

What is the overall magnification of the system?

Two converging lenses having focal lengths of $f_1 = 10.0$ cm and $f_2 = 20.0$ cm are placed $d = 50.0$ cm apart, as shown in Figure. The final image is to be located between the lenses, at the position $x = 31.0$ cm indicated.

Determine the range of distances for which objects can be focused on the film.

Lens $L_1$ in Figure has a focal length of $15.0$ cm and is located a fixed distance in front of the film plane of a camera. Lens $L_2$ has a focal length of $13.0$ cm, and its distance $d$ from the film plane can be varied from $5.00$ cm to $10.0$ cm.

What is the overall magnification of the image?

The object in Figure is midway between the lens and the mirror, which are separated by a distance $d = 25.0$ cm. The magnitude of the mirror's radius of curvature is $20.0$ cm, and the lens has a focal length of $-16.7$ cm.

Find the difference $\Delta x$ in the positions where each crosses the principal axis.

Two rays traveling parallel to the principal axis strike a large plano-convex lens having a refractive index of 1.60 (Figure). If the convex face is spherical, a ray near the edge does not pass through the focal point (spherical aberration occurs). Assume this face has a radius of curvature of $R = 20.0$ cm and the two rays are at distances $h_1 = 0.500$ cm and $h_2 = 12.0$ cm from the principal axis.

Locate the image of the object due to refraction at the two spherical surfaces.

To work this problem, use the fact that the image formed by the first surface becomes the object for the second surface. Figure shows a piece of glass with index of refraction $n = 1.50$ surrounded by air. The ends are hemispheres with radii $R_1 = 2.00$ cm and $R_2 = 4.00$ cm, and the centers of the hemispherical ends are separated by a distance of $d = 8.00$ cm. A point object is in air, a distance $p = 1.00$ cm from the left end of the glass.
options: A: $32.0$ cm to the right of the second surface
B: $38.0$ cm to the right of the second surface
C: $42.0$ cm to the right of the second surface
D: $32.0$ cm to the left of the second surface

text:
What is the index of refraction of the lens?

Figure shows a converging lens with radii $R_1 = 9.00$ cm and $R_2 = -11.00$ cm, in front of a concave spherical mirror of radius $R = 8.00$ cm. The focal points ($F_1$ and $F_2$) for the thin lens and the center of curvature ($C$) of the mirror are also shown. The focal points $F_1$ and $F_2$ are $5.00$ cm from the vertex of the thin lens.

Determine the focal length of the mirror.

An observer to the right of the mirror-lens combination shown in Figure sees two real images that are the same size and in the same location. One image is upright, and the other is inverted. Both images are $1.50$ times larger than the object. The lens has a focal length of $10.0$ cm. The lens and mirror are separated by $40.0$ cm.

How thick is the hair?

A pair of glass slides $10.0$ cm long and with $n = 1.52$ are separated on one end by a hair, forming a triangular wedge of air, as illustrated in Figure. When coherent light from a helium-neon laser with wavelength $633$ nm is incident on the film from above, $15.0$ dark fringes per centimeter are observed.

How much farther must the car travel from this position to encounter the next minimum in reception?

Two radio antennas separated by $d = 300$ m, as shown in Figure, simultaneously broadcast identical signals at the same wavelength. A car travels due north along a straight line at position $x = 1000$ m from the center point between the antennas, and its radio receives the signals.

Determine the distance between the doors, center to center.

A riverside warehouse has two open doors, as in Figure. Its interior is lined with a sound-absorbing material. A boat on the river sounds its horn. To person A, the sound is loud and clear. To person B, the sound is barely audible. The principal wavelength of the sound waves is $3.00$ m. Assumed person B is at the position of the first minimum.

Find the height of the cliff.

Radio waves from a star, of wavelength $250$ m, reach a radio telescope by two separate paths, as shown in Figure. One is a direct path to the receiver, which is situated on the edge of a cliff by the ocean. The second is by reflection off the water. The first minimum of destructive interference occurs when the star is $\theta = 25.0^{\circ}$ above the horizon. (Assume no phase change on reflection.)

What is the minimum anti-reflection thickness, $t$?

A lens made of glass ($n_g = 1.52$) is coated with a thin film of MgF$_2$ ($n_s = 1.38$) of thickness $t$. Visible light is incident normally on the coated lens as in Figure. The reflected light of wavelength $540$ nm (in air) be missing.

Calculate the transmitted intensity $I_f$.

Three polarizing plates whose planes are parallel are centered on a common axis. The directions of the transmission axes relative to the common vertical direction are shown in Figure. A linearly polarized beam of light with plane of polarization parallel to the vertical reference direction is incident from the left onto the first disk with intensity $I_i = 10.0$ units (arbitrary). $\theta_1 = 20.0^{\circ}$, $\theta_2 = 40.0^{\circ}$, and $\theta_3 = 60.0^{\circ}$.

Find the distance $y$ (in millimeters) to the first dark band above the mirror.

Interference effects are produced at point $P$ on a screen as a result of direct rays from a $500$-nm source and reflected rays off a mirror, as shown in Figure. The source is $L = 100$ m to the left of the screen and $h = 1.00$ cm above the mirror.

Determine the longest wavelengths that interfere destructively.

Figure shows a radio-wave transmitter and a receiver, both $h = 50.0$ m above the ground and $d = 600$ m apart. The receiver can receive signals directly from the transmitter and indirectly from signals that bounce off the ground. The ground is level between the transmitter and receiver and a $\lambda/2$ phase shift occurs upon reflection.

What focal-length eyepiece used with the Hubble mirror system would produce a magnification of $8.00 \times 10^3$?

The Hubble Space Telescope is $13.2$ m long, but has a secondary mirror that increases its effective focal length to $57.8$ m. (See Figure.) The telescope doesn't have an eyepiece because various instruments, not a human eye, record the collected light. It can, however, produce images several thousand times larger than they would appear with the unaided human eye.

What angular magnification is achieved by viewing the image of the leaf?

A leaf of length $h$ is positioned $71.0$ cm in front of a converging lens with a focal length of $39.0$ cm. An observer views the image of the leaf from a position $1.26$ m behind the lens, as shown in Figure.

Calculate the x-component of the resultant force, $F_{rx}$.

Consider three point charges at the corners of a triangle, as shown in Figure, where $q_1 = 6.00 \times 10^{-9}$ C, $q_2 = -2.00 \times 10^{-9}$ C, and $q_3 = 5.00 \times 10^{-9}$ C.

Find the force on a charge of $2.00 \times 10^{-8}$ C placed at $P$.

Charge $q_1 = 7.00 \mu$C is at the origin, and charge $q_2 = -5.00 \mu$C is on the x-axis, $0.300$ m from the origin (Figure).

What is the force constant of the spring?

A small sphere of charge $0.800 \mu$C hangs from the end of a spring as in Figure. When another small sphere of charge $-0.600 \mu$C is held beneath the first sphere as in Figure,the spring stretches by $d = 3.50$ cm from its original length and reaches a new equilibrium position with a separation between the charges of $r = 5.00$ cm.

Find the value of $k$.

A positive charge $q_1 = 2.70 \mu$C on a frictionless horizontal surface is attached to a spring of force constant $k$ as in Figure.When a charge of $q_2 = -8.60 \mu$C is placed $9.50$ cm away from the positive charge, the spring stretches by $5.00$ mm, reducing the distance between charges to $d = 9.00$ cm.

Find the magnitude of the net electric force on the $2.00 \mu$C charge.

Three point charges are located at the corners of an equilateral triangle as in Figure.

Determine the value of $Q$, modeling the blocks as charged particles.

Two identical metal blocks resting on a frictionless horizontal surface are connected by a light metal spring having constant $k = 100$ N/m and unstretched length $L_i = 0.400$ m as in Figure. A charge $Q$ is slowly placed on each block causing the spring to stretch to an equilibrium length $L = 0.500$ m as in Figure.

What is the magnitude of the charge on each sphere?

Two small metallic spheres, each of mass $m = 0.20$ g, are suspended as pendulums by light strings from a common point as shown in Figure.The spheres are given the same electric charge, and it is found that they come to equilibrium when each string is at an angle of $\theta = 5.0^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Each string has length $L = 30.0$ cm.

Find an expression for the magnitude of the electric field that enables the block to remain at rest.

A small block of mass $m$ and charge $Q$ is placed on an insulated, frictionless, inclined plane of angle $\theta$ as in Figure. An electric field is applied parallel to the incline.

Find the tension in the string.

A small sphere of charge $q = +68~\mu\mathrm{C}$ and mass $m = 5.8~\mathrm{g}$ is attached to a light string and placed in a uniform electric field $\vec{E}$ that makes an angle $\theta = 37^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. The opposite end of the string is attached to a wall and the sphere is in static equilibrium when the string is horizontal as in Figure.

What is the resultant electric field at the center of the circle?

Three identical charges ($q = -5.0~\mu\mathrm{C}$) lie along a circle of radius $2.0~\mathrm{m}$ at angles of $30^{\circ}$, $150^{\circ}$, and $270^{\circ}$, as shown in Figure.

Find the electric flux through this surface.

A uniform electric field of magnitude $E = 435$ N/C makes an angle of $\theta = 65.0^{\circ}$ with a plane surface of area $A = 3.50$ m$^2$ as in Figure.

Find the electric flux through one face of the tetrahedron.

A charge $q = +5.80 \mu$C is located at the center of a regular tetrahedron (a four-sided surface) as in Figure.

What is the net charge on the ball?
