Be sure to include an explicit plus or minus sign along with your answer.

What is the angular speed (in rad/s) of the rods when a spark jumps across the gap?

Two 0.68\,\mathrm{m}-long conducting rods are rotating at the same speed in opposite directions, and both are perpendicular to a 4.7\,\mathrm{T} magnetic field. As the drawing shows, the ends of these rods come to within 1.0\,\mathrm{mm} of each other as they rotate. Moreover, the fixed ends about which the rods are rotating are connected by a wire, so these ends are at the same electric potential. A potential difference of 4.5 \times 10^{3}\,\mathrm{V} is required to cause a 1.0\,\mathrm{mm} spark in air.

What is the peak emf of the generator?

A transformer consisting of two coils wrapped around an iron core is connected to a generator and a resistor, as shown in the drawing. There are 11 turns in the primary coil and 18 turns in the secondary coil. The peak voltage across the resistor is 67\,\mathrm{V}.

What is its magnitude in part $b$?

Parts $a$ and $b$ of the drawing show the same uniform and constant (in time) magnetic field $\vec{B}$ directed perpendicularly into the paper over a rectangular region. Outside this region, there is no field. Also shown is a rectangular coil (one turn), which lies in the plane of the paper. In part $a$ the long side of the coil (length $= L$) is just at the edge of the field region, while in part $b$ the short side (width $= W$) is just at the edge. It is known that $L/W = 3.0$. In both parts of the drawing the coil is pushed into the field with the same velocity $\vec{v}$ until it is completely within the field region. The magnitude of the average emf induced in the coil in part $a$ is $0.15$ V.

What power strikes a \( 0.75\,\mathrm{m^2} \) patch of flat land at the equator at point \( Q \)?

The power radiated by the sun is \( 3.9 \times 10^{26}\,\mathrm{W} \). The earth orbits the sun in a nearly circular orbit of radius \( 1.5 \times 10^{11}\,\mathrm{m} \). The earth’s axis of rotation is tilted by \( 27^{\circ} \) relative to the plane of the orbit, so sunlight does not strike the equator perpendicularly.

Find the measured frequency for the light from region B.

A distant galaxy is simultaneously rotating and receding from the earth. As the drawing shows, the galactic center is receding from the earth at a relative speed of \( u_G = 1.6 \times 10^6\,\mathrm{m/s} \). Relative to the center, the tangential speed is \( v_T = 0.4 \times 10^6\,\mathrm{m/s} \) for locations A and B, which are equidistant from the center. When the frequencies of the light coming from regions A and B are measured on earth, they are not the same and each is different from the emitted frequency of \( 6.200 \times 10^{14}\,\mathrm{Hz} \).

What is the intensity of the beam transmitted through the three sheets?

For each of the three sheets of polarizing material shown in the drawing, the orientation of the transmission axis is labeled relative to the vertical. The incident beam of light is unpolarized and has an intensity of 1260.0\,\mathrm{W/m^2}. \( \theta_1 = 19.0^{\circ} \), \( \theta_2 = 55.0^{\circ} \), and \( \theta_3 = 100.0^{\circ} \).

What is it when \( \theta = 25^{\circ} \)?

The drawing shows an edge-on view of the solar panels on a communications satellite. The dashed line specifies the normal to the panels. Sunlight strikes the panels at an angle \( \theta \) with respect to the normal. The solar power impinging on the panels is 2600\,\mathrm{W} when \( \theta = 65^{\circ} \).

Find the mechanical energy lost in the collision.

A 5.00\,\mathrm{g} bullet moving with an initial speed of 400\,\mathrm{m/s} is fired into and passes through a 1.00\,\mathrm{kg} block. The block, initially at rest on a frictionless horizontal surface, is connected to a spring with a spring constant of 900\,\mathrm{N/m}. The block moves 5.00\,\mathrm{cm} to the right after impact.

Determine the period of the motion.

A light balloon filled with helium of density 0.179\,\mathrm{kg/m^3} is tied to a light string of length L = 3.00\,\mathrm{m}. The string is tied to the ground, forming an "inverted" simple pendulum (Figure). The balloon is displaced slightly from equilibrium, as in Figure. Take the density of air to be 1.29\,\mathrm{kg/m^3}.

Find the coordinate position of the lowest point.

A system consists of a vertical spring with force constant \( k = 1250\,\mathrm{N/m} \), length \( L = 1.50\,\mathrm{m} \), and object of mass \( m = 5.00\,\mathrm{kg} \) attached to the end (Figure). The object is placed at the level of the point of attachment with the spring unstretched, at position \( y_i = L \), and then it is released so that it swings like a pendulum.

What is the maximum speed of the outer tip of the wing?

Figure shows a crude model of an insect wing. The mass \( m \) represents the entire mass of the wing, which pivots about the fulcrum \( F \). The spring represents the surrounding connective tissue. Motion of the wing corresponds to vibration of the spring. Suppose the mass of the wing is 0.30\,\mathrm{g} and the effective spring constant of the tissue is 4.7 \times 10^{-4}\,\mathrm{N/m}. The mass \( m \) moves up and down a distance of 2.0\,\mathrm{mm} from its position of equilibrium.

What is the ratio of the intensity heard by observer A to that heard by observer C?

A skyrocket explodes 100\,\mathrm{m} above the ground (Figure). Three observers are spaced 100\,\mathrm{m} apart, with the first (A) directly under the explosion.

At what time will the person encounter the shock wave due to the sound emitted at \( t = 0 \)?

A supersonic jet traveling at Mach 3.00 at an altitude of \( h = 20000\,\mathrm{m} \) is directly over a person at time \( t = 0 \) as shown in Figure. Assume the average speed of sound in air is 335\,\mathrm{m/s} over the path of the sound.

What minimum increase in the original length of the upper tube will again result in constructive interference?

The acoustical system shown in Figure is driven by a speaker emitting sound of frequency 756\,\mathrm{Hz}.

Determine the wavelength of the radio waves.

The ship in Figure travels along a straight line parallel to the shore and a distance \( d = 600\,\mathrm{m} \) from it. The ship’s radio receives simultaneous signals of the same frequency from antennas \( A \) and \( B \), separated by a distance \( L = 800\,\mathrm{m} \). The signals interfere constructively at point \( C \), which is equidistant from \( A \) and \( B \). The signal goes through the first minimum at point \( D \), which is directly outward from the shore from point \( B \).

What minimum vertical distance upward should the top speaker be moved to create destructive interference at point \( O \)?

Two loudspeakers are placed above and below each other, as in Figure and driven by the same source at a frequency of \( 4.50 \times 10^2\,\mathrm{Hz} \). An observer is in front of the speakers (to the right) at point \( O \), at the same distance from each speaker.

How far will the observer be from the speaker?

A pair of speakers separated by a distance \( d = 0.700\,\mathrm{m} \) are driven by the same oscillator at a frequency of 686\,\mathrm{Hz}. An observer originally positioned at one of the speakers begins to walk along a line perpendicular to the line joining the speakers as in Figure. The first relative minimum is detected in the intensity.

At what frequency must the string between the pulleys vibrate?

A 12.0\,\mathrm{kg} object hangs in equilibrium from a string with total length of \( L = 5.00\,\mathrm{m} \) and linear mass density of \( \mu = 0.001\,00\,\mathrm{kg/m} \). The string is wrapped around two light, frictionless pulleys that are separated by the distance \( d = 2.00\,\mathrm{m} \) (Figure). The string between the pulleys vibrate to form the standing-wave pattern shown in Figure.

How many loops (if any) will result if \( m \) is changed to 45\,\mathrm{kg}?

In the arrangement shown in Figure, an object of mass \( m = 5.0\,\mathrm{kg} \) hangs from a cord around a light pulley. The length of the cord between point \( P \) and the pulley is \( L = 2.0\,\mathrm{m} \).

Determine the sound level at point \( C \).

Two small loudspeakers emit sound waves of different frequencies equally in all directions. Speaker \( A \) has an output of 1.00\,\mathrm{mW}, and speaker \( B \) has an output of 1.50\,\mathrm{mW}.Assumed both speakers emit sound

What frequency is monitored by the leading ship?

Two ships are moving along a line due east (Figure). The trailing vessel has a speed relative to a land-based observation point of \( v_1 = 64.0\,\mathrm{km/h} \), and the leading ship has a speed of \( v_2 = 45.0\,\mathrm{km/h} \) relative to that point. The two ships are in a region of the ocean where the current is moving uniformly due west at \( v_{\mathrm{current}} = 10.0\,\mathrm{km/h} \). The trailing ship transmits a sonar signal at a frequency of 1200.0\,\mathrm{Hz} through the water.

How close to the sidewalk can the flowerpot fall before it is too late for a warning shouted from the window to reach the man in time?

A flowerpot is knocked off a window ledge from a height \( d = 20.0\,\mathrm{m} \) above the sidewalk as shown in Figure. It falls toward an unsuspecting man of height \( h = 1.75\,\mathrm{m} \) who is standing below. Assume the man below requires 0.300\,\mathrm{s} to respond to a warning.

Determine the highest frequencies heard by the person to the right of the speaker.

A block with a speaker bolted to it is connected to a spring having spring constant \( k = 20.0\,\mathrm{N/m} \), as shown in Figure. The total mass of the block and speaker is 5.00\,\mathrm{kg}, and the amplitude of the unit’s motion is 0.500\,\mathrm{m}.The speaker emits sound waves of frequency 440\,\mathrm{Hz}.

If the charge is uniformly distributed so that $\rho = Q/(\frac{4}{3}\pi R^3)$ and if the mass is uniformly distributed so that $c = \frac{2}{5}$, then what is the value of $g$?

The magnetic moment $\vec{\mu}$ of a spinning object with charge $Q$ and mass $M$ is proportional to its angular momentum $\vec{L}$ according to $\vec{\mu} = g(Q/2M)\vec{L}$. The dimensionless coefficient $g$ is known as the $g$-factor of the object. Consider a spherical shell with radius $R$ and uniform charge density $\sigma$ spinning with angular velocity $\omega$ around the z-axis.

$I_{CO} = 1.449 \times 10^{-46}\ kg \cdot m^2$, calculate the wavelength of the photon emitted by a $CO$ molecule in an $l=1 \to l=0$ rotational transition.

Our galaxy contains numerous molecular clouds, regions many light-years in extent in which the density is high enough and the temperature low enough for atoms to form into molecules. Most of the molecules are $H_2$, but a small fraction of the molecules are carbon monoxide ($CO$). Such a molecular cloud in the constellation Orion is shown in figure. The upper image was made with an ordinary visible-light telescope; the lower image shows the molecular cloud in Orion as imaged with a radio telescope tuned to a wavelength emitted by $CO$ in a rotational transition. The different colors in the radio image indicate regions of the cloud that are moving either toward us (blue) or away from us (red) relative to the motion of the cloud as a whole, as determined by the Doppler shift of the radiation. (Since a molecular cloud has about $10,000$ hydrogen molecules for each $CO$ molecule, it might seem more reasonable to tune a radio telescope to emissions from $H_2$ than to emissions from $CO$. Unfortunately, it turns out that the $H_2$ molecules in molecular clouds do not radiate in either the radio or visible portions of the electromagnetic spectrum.)

What is the current $I$ in that case?

The circuit shown in figure, which is called a half-wave rectifier. The triangular symbol with the flat lower edge represents a diode, such that a forward bias drives the current downward. Use a typical value for the saturation current: $I_S = 5 \times 10^{-13}\ A$. Use a temperature of $300\ K$.

The $p$ side is doped with boron atoms with density $N_A = 1.00 \times 10^{16}\ cm^{-3}$. The $n$ side is doped with arsenic atoms with density $N_D = 5.00 \times 10^{16}\ cm^{-3}$. The $n$ side depletion depth is $a_n = 55.0\ nm$. What is the $p$ side depletion depth $a_p$?

A $p$-$n$ junction includes $p$-type silicon, with donor atom density $N_D$, adjacent to $n$-type silicon, with acceptor atom density $N_A$. Near the junction, free electrons from the $n$ side have diffused into the $p$ side while free holes from the $p$ side have diffused into the $n$ side, leaving a “depletion region” of width $W$ where there are no free charge carriers. The width of the depletion region on the $n$ side is $a_n$, and the width of the depletion region on the $p$ side is $a_p$. Each depleted region has a constant charge density with magnitude equal to the corresponding donor atom density. Assume there is no net charge outside the depleted regions. Define an $x$-axis pointing from the $p$ side toward the $n$ side with the origin at the center of the junction. An electric field $\vec{E} = -E\hat{\imath}$ has developed in the depletion region, stabilizing the diffusion.

Which one of the absorbed energies corresponds to a transition to an $l=0$ state?

A colorless, odorless gas in a tank needs to be identified. The gas is nitrogen ($N_2$), carbon monoxide ($CO$), or nitric oxide ($NO$). White light is passed through a sample to obtain an absorption spectrum. Among others, the following wavelengths present dark bands on the spectrum: $\lambda = 4.2680\ \mu m, 4.2753\ \mu m, 4.2826\ \mu m, 4.2972\ \mu m$, and $4.3046\ \mu m$. These represent transitions from the lowest rotational states.

What is the distance between Nibiru and Xibalba four years after creation?

Consider the following hypothetical universe: The Nibiruvians and the Xibalbans are minuscule “flat” societies located at an angular separation of $\theta = 60^{\circ}$ on the surface of a two-dimensional spherical universe with radius $R$, as shown in figure. The radius of this universe was $R_0 = 500.0\ m$ upon its creation at time $t=0$, and it has been increasing at a constant rate of $1.00\ \mu m/s$.

How far is she from the starting point?

A cross-country skier skis $1.00\ km$ north and then $2.00\ km$ east on a horizontal snowfield.

What is the value of R does she calculate?

Three players on a reality TV show are brought to the center of a large, flat field. Each is given a meter stick, a compass, a calculator, a shovel, and (in a different order for each contestant) the following three displacements: $\vec{A}$: $72.4$ m, $32.0^{\circ}$ east of north $\vec{B}$: $57.3$ m, $36.0^{\circ}$ south of west $\vec{C}$: $17.8$ m due south. The three displacements lead to the point in the field where the keys to a new Porsche are buried. Two players start measuring immediately, but the winner first calculates where to go.

What is the value of $\vec{A} \cdot \vec{B}$?

Find the scalar product $\vec{A} \cdot \vec{B}$ of the two vectors in figure. The magnitudes of the vectors are $A = 4.00$ and $B = 5.00$.

What is the angle between the vectors?

Find the angle between the vectors $\vec{A} = 2.00\hat{i} + 3.00\hat{j} + 1.00\hat{k}$ and $\vec{B} = -4.00\hat{i} + 2.00\hat{j} - 1.00\hat{k}$

Find the vector product $\vec{C} = \vec{A} \times \vec{B}$.

Vector $\vec{A}$ has magnitude 6 units and is in the direction of the +x-axis. Vector $\vec{B}$ has magnitude 4 units and lies in the xy-plane, making an angle of $30^{\circ}$ with the +x-axis.

Find its average velocity between $t_1 = 1.0 \ \mathrm{s}$ and $t_2 = 2.0 \ \mathrm{s}$

As shown in figure, a cheetah is crouched $20 \ \mathrm{m}$ to the east of a vehicle. At time $t = 0$ the cheetah begins to run due east toward an antelope that is $50 \ \mathrm{m}$ to the east of the vehicle. During the first $2.0 \ \mathrm{s}$ of the chase, the cheetah's $x$-coordinate varies with time according to the equation $x = 20 \ \mathrm{m} + (5.0 \ \mathrm{m/s}^2)t^2$.

Where is he when his speed is $25 \ \mathrm{m/s}$?

A motorcyclist heading east through a small town accelerates at a constant $4.0 \ \mathrm{m/s}^2$ after he leaves the city limits. At time $t = 0$ he is $5.0 \ \mathrm{m}$ east of the city-limits signpost while he moves east at $15 \ \mathrm{m/s}$.

What is the officer's speed?

A motorist traveling at a constant $15 \ \mathrm{m/s}$ ($54 \ \mathrm{km/h}$, or about $34 \ \mathrm{mi/h}$) passes a school crossing where the speed limit is $10 \ \mathrm{m/s}$ ($36 \ \mathrm{km/h}$, or about $22 \ \mathrm{mi/h}$). Just as the motorist passes the school-crossing sign, a police officer on a motorcycle stopped there starts in pursuit with constant acceleration $3.0 \ \mathrm{m/s}^2$.

What are its position after $3.0 \ \mathrm{s}$?

A one-euro coin is dropped from the Leaning Tower of Pisa and falls freely from rest. Ignore air resistance and the answer is negative.

What is the ball's acceleration when it is at its maximum height?

You throw a ball vertically upward from the roof of a tall building. The ball leaves your hand at a point even with the roof railing with an upward speed of $15.0 \ \mathrm{m/s}$; the ball is then in free fall. (We ignore air resistance.) On its way back down, it just misses the railing.

Find the rover's distance from the lander at $t = 2.0 \ \mathrm{s}$.

A robotic vehicle, or rover, is exploring the surface of Mars. The stationary Mars lander is the origin of coordinates, and the surrounding Martian surface lies in the $xy$-plane. The rover, which we represent as a point, has $x$- and $y$-coordinates that vary with time: $x = 2.0 \ \mathrm{m} - (0.25 \ \mathrm{m/s}^2)t^2$ $y = (1.0 \ \mathrm{m/s})t + (0.025 \ \mathrm{m/s}^3)t^3$.

What is the motorcycle's velocity $0.50 \ \mathrm{s}$ after it leaves the edge of the cliff?

A motorcycle stunt rider rides off the edge of a cliff. Just at the edge his velocity is horizontal, with magnitude $9.0 \ \mathrm{m/s}$. Ignore air resistance.

What is your velocity relative to the truck?

You drive north on a straight two-lane road at a constant $88 \ \mathrm{km/h}$. A truck in the other lane approaches you at a constant $104 \ \mathrm{km/h}$.

If there is a $100 \ \mathrm{km/h}$ wind from west to east, what is the velocity of the airplane relative to the earth?

An airplane's compass indicates that it is headed due north, and its airspeed indicator shows that it is moving through the air at $240 \ \mathrm{km/h}$.

Find expressions for the tension in $T2$ in terms of $w$.

As shown in figure, a car engine with weight $w$ hangs from a chain that is linked at ring $O$ to two other chains, one fastened to the ceiling and the other to the wall. The weights of the ring and chains are negligible compared with the weight of the engine.

Find the tension in the cable.

A car of weight $w$ rests on a slanted ramp attached to a trailer. Only a cable running from the trailer to the car prevents the car from rolling off the ramp. (The car's brakes are off and its transmission is in neutral.)

What constant horizontal force $F_{\textrm{W}}$ does the wind exert on the iceboat?

An iceboat is at rest on a frictionless horizontal surface. Due to the blowing wind, $4.0 \, \textrm{s}$ after the iceboat is released, it is moving to the right at $6.0 \, \textrm{m/s}$ (about $22 \, \textrm{km/h}$, or $13 \, \textrm{mi/h}$). The combined mass of iceboat and rider is $200 \, \textrm{kg}$.

What is the tension $T$ in the supporting cable while the elevator is being brought to rest?

An elevator and its load have a combined mass of $800 \, \textrm{kg}$. The elevator is initially moving downward at $10.0 \, \textrm{m/s}$; it slows to a stop with constant acceleration in a distance of $25.0 \, \textrm{m}$.

While the elevator is moving downward with decreasing speed, what is the reading on the scale?

A $50.0 \, \textrm{kg}$ woman stands on a bathroom scale while riding in the elevator. The elevator is initially moving downward at $10.0 \, \textrm{m/s}$; it slows to a stop with constant acceleration in a distance of $25.0 \, \textrm{m}$.

What is its acceleration?

A toboggan loaded with students (total weight $w$) slides down a snowcovered hill that slopes at a constant angle $\alpha$. The toboggan is well waxed, so there is virtually no friction.

Find the horizontal force that the tray exerts on the carton.

You push a $1.00 \, \textrm{kg}$ food tray through the cafeteria line with a constant $9.0 \, \textrm{N}$ force. The tray pushes a $0.50 \, \textrm{kg}$ milk carton. The tray and carton slide on a horizontal surface so greasy that friction can be ignored.

Find the tension in the string.

Figure shows an air-track glider with mass $m_1$ moving on a level, frictionless air track in the physics lab. The glider is connected to a lab weight with mass $m_2$ by a light, flexible, nonstretching string that passes over a stationary, frictionless pulley.

What is the coefficient of kinetic friction?

You want to move a $500 \, \textrm{N}$ crate across a level floor. To start the crate moving, you have to pull with a $230 \, \textrm{N}$ horizontal force. Once the crate starts to move, you can keep it moving at constant velocity with only $200 \, \textrm{N}$.

How hard must you pull to keep it moving with constant velocity?

As shown in figure, suppose you move the crate by pulling upward on the rope at an angle of $30^\circ$ above the horizontal. Assume that $\mu_{\textrm{k}} = 0.40$.

If the sled makes five complete revolutions every minute, find the force $F$ exerted on it by the rope.

A sled with a mass of $25.0 \, \textrm{kg}$ rests on a horizontal sheet of essentially frictionless ice. It is attached by a $5.00 \, \textrm{m}$ rope to a post set in the ice. Once given a push, the sled revolves uniformly in a circle around the post.

Find the tension $F$ in the wire.

An inventor designs a pendulum clock using a bob with mass $m$ at the end of a thin wire of length $L$. Instead of swinging back and forth, the bob is to move in a horizontal circle at constant speed $v$, with the wire making a fixed angle $\beta$ with the vertical direction. This is called a conical pendulum because the suspending wire traces out a cone.

If the coefficient of static friction between tires and road is $\mu_{\textrm{s}}$, what is the maximum speed $v_{\textrm{max}}$ at which the driver can take the curve without sliding?

The sports car is rounding a flat, unbanked curve with radius $R$.

Find the total work done by all the forces.

A farmer hitches her tractor to a sled loaded with firewood and pulls it a distance of $20 \, \textrm{m}$ along level ground. The total weight of sled and load is $14700 \, \textrm{N}$. The tractor exerts a constant $5000 \, \textrm{N}$ force at an angle of $36.9^\circ$ above the horizontal. A $3500 \, \textrm{N}$ friction force opposes the sled's motion.

Use the work-energy theorem to find the average force the hammerhead exerts on the I-beam.

The $200 \, \textrm{kg}$ steel hammerhead of a pile driver is lifted $3.00 \, \textrm{m}$ above the top of a vertical I-beam being driven into the ground. The hammerhead is then dropped, driving the I-beam $7.4 \, \textrm{cm}$ deeper into the ground. The vertical guide rails exert a constant $60 \, \textrm{N}$ friction force on the hammerhead. Ignore the effects of the air.

Find the total work done on it during the compression.

A woman weighing $600 \, \textrm{N}$ steps on a bathroom scale that contains a stiff spring. In equilibrium, the spring is compressed $1.0 \, \textrm{cm}$ under her weight.

Find the maximum distance $d$ that the glider moves to the right if the air is turned off, so that there is kinetic friction with coefficient $\mu_{\textrm{k}} = 0.47$.

An air-track glider of mass $0.100 \, \textrm{kg}$ is attached to the end of a horizontal air track by a spring with force constant $20.0 \, \textrm{N/m}$. Initially the spring is unstretched and the glider is moving at $1.50 \, \textrm{m/s}$ to the right.

What is the work you do by exerting force $\vec{F}$? (Ignore the weight of the chains and seat.)

At a family picnic you are appointed to push your obnoxious cousin Throckmorton in a swing. His weight is $w$, the length of the chains is $R$, and you push Throcky until the chains make an angle $\theta_0$ with the vertical. To do this, you exert a varying horizontal force $\vec{F}$ that starts at zero and gradually increases just enough that Throcky and the swing move very slowly and remain very nearly in equilibrium throughout the process.

To lift herself to the top in $15.0 \, \textrm{minutes}$, what must be her average power output?

A $50.0 \, \textrm{kg}$ marathon runner runs up the stairs to the top of Chicago's $443 \, \textrm{m}$-tall Willis Tower, the second tallest building in the United States.

Find how high it goes, ignoring air resistance.

You throw a $0.145 \, \textrm{kg}$ baseball straight up, giving it an initial velocity of magnitude $20.0 \, \textrm{m/s}$.

Find the normal force that acts on him at the bottom of the curve.

Your cousin Throckmorton skateboards from rest down a curved, frictionless ramp. If we treat Throcky and his skateboard as a particle, he moves through a quarter-circle with radius $R = 3.00 \, \textrm{m}$. Throcky and his skateboard have a total mass of $25.0 \, \textrm{kg}$.

How fast is the crate moving when it reaches the bottom of the ramp?

We want to slide a $12 \, \textrm{kg}$ crate up a $2.5 \, \textrm{m}$-long ramp inclined at $30^\circ$. A worker, ignoring friction, calculates that he can do this by giving it an initial speed of $5.0 \, \textrm{m/s}$ at the bottom and letting it go. But friction is not negligible; the crate slides only $1.6 \, \textrm{m}$ up the ramp, stops, and slides back down.

What is its $x$-velocity when $x = 0.080 \, \textrm{m}$?

A glider with mass $m = 0.200 \, \textrm{kg}$ sits on a frictionless, horizontal air track, connected to a spring with force constant $k = 5.00 \, \textrm{N/m}$. You pull on the glider, stretching the spring $0.100 \, \textrm{m}$, and release it from rest. The glider moves back toward its equilibrium position ($x = 0$).

What is the necessary force constant $k$ for the spring?

A $2000 \, \textrm{kg}$ ($19600 \, \textrm{N}$) elevator with broken cables in a test rig is falling at $4.00 \, \textrm{m/s}$ when it contacts a cushioning spring at the bottom of the shaft. The spring is intended to stop the elevator, compressing $2.00 \, \textrm{m}$ as it does so. During the motion a safety clamp applies a constant $17000 \, \textrm{N}$ friction force to the elevator.

How much more work must you do to push the futon along the dogleg path than along the straight-line path?

You are rearranging your furniture and wish to move a $40.0 \, \textrm{kg}$ futon $2.50 \, \textrm{m}$ across the room. A heavy coffee table, which you don't want to move, blocks this straight-line path. Instead, you slide the futon along a dogleg path; the doglegs are $2.00 \, \textrm{m}$ and $1.50 \, \textrm{m}$ long. The coefficient of kinetic friction is $\mu_{\textrm{k}} = 0.200$.

Calculate the work done on the electron by force $\vec{F}$ during a counterclockwise trip around the square.

In a region of space the force on an electron is $\vec{F} = C x \hat{\jmath}$, where $C$ is a positive constant. The electron moves around a square loop in the $xy$-plane.

If the ball is in contact with the wall for $0.010 \, \textrm{s}$, find the average horizontal force that the wall exerts on the ball during the impact.

You throw a ball with a mass of $0.40 \, \textrm{kg}$ against a brick wall. It is moving horizontally to the left at $30 \, \textrm{m/s}$ when it hits the wall; it rebounds horizontally to the right at $20 \, \textrm{m/s}$.

Find the impulse of the average net external force, assuming a collision time $\Delta t = 0.010 \, \textrm{s}$.

A soccer ball has a mass of $0.40 \, \textrm{kg}$. Initially it is moving to the left at $20 \, \textrm{m/s}$, but then it is kicked. After the kick it is moving at $45^\circ$ upward and to the right with speed $30 \, \textrm{m/s}$.

What are the final kinetic energy of the rifle?

A marksman holds a rifle of mass $m_{\textrm{R}} = 3.00 \, \textrm{kg}$ loosely, so it can recoil freely. He fires a bullet of mass $m_{\textrm{B}} = 5.00 \, \textrm{g}$ horizontally with a velocity relative to the ground of $v_{\textrm{Bx}} = 300 \, \textrm{m/s}$.

What is the final velocity of glider A?

Two gliders with different masses move toward each other on a frictionless air track. After they collide, glider B has a final velocity of $+2.0 \, \textrm{m/s}$.

What is the final velocity of robot B?

Figure shows two battling robots on a frictionless surface. Robot A, with mass $20 \, \textrm{kg}$, initially moves at $2.0 \, \textrm{m/s}$ parallel to the $x$-axis. It collides with robot B, which has mass $12 \, \textrm{kg}$ and is initially at rest. After the collision, robot A moves at $1.0 \, \textrm{m/s}$ in a direction that makes an angle $\alpha = 30^\circ$ with its initial direction.

In terms of $h$, $m_{\textrm{B}}$, and $m_{\textrm{W}}$, what is the initial speed $v_1$ of the bullet?

Figure shows a ballistic pendulum, a simple system for measuring the speed of a bullet. A bullet of mass $m_{\textrm{B}}$ makes a completely inelastic collision with a block of wood of mass $m_{\textrm{W}}$, which is suspended like a pendulum. After the impact, the block swings up to a maximum height $h$.

What is the velocity of the wreckage just after impact?

A $1000 \, \textrm{kg}$ car traveling north at $15 \, \textrm{m/s}$ collides with a $2000 \, \textrm{kg}$ truck traveling east at $10 \, \textrm{m/s}$. The occupants, wearing seat belts, are uninjured, but the two vehicles move away from the impact point as one.

Find the final speed $v_{B2}$ of puck B.

Figure shows an elastic collision of two pucks (masses $m_A = 0.500 \, \textrm{kg}$ and $m_B = 0.300 \, \textrm{kg}$) on a frictionless air-hockey table. Puck A has an initial velocity of $4.00 \, \textrm{m/s}$ in the positive $x$-direction and a final velocity of $2.00 \, \textrm{m/s}$ in an unknown direction $\alpha$. Puck B is initially at rest.

What angle does the line $PQ$ make with the $+x$-axis at at $t=0.300 \, \mathrm{s}$?

You have finished watching a movie on Blu-ray and the disc is slowing to a stop. The disc's angular velocity at $t=0$ is $27.5 \, \mathrm{rad/s}$, and its angular acceleration is a constant $-10.0 \, \mathrm{rad/s}^2$. A line $PQ$ on the disc's surface lies along the $+x$-axis at $t=0$.

For this instant, find the magnitude of the acceleration of the discus.

An athlete whirls a discus in a circle of radius $80.0 \, \mathrm{cm}$. At a certain instant, the athlete is rotating at $10.0 \, \mathrm{rad/s}$ and the angular speed is increasing at $50.0 \, \mathrm{rad/s}^2$.

What is the maximum possible propeller radius?

You are designing an airplane propeller that is to turn at $2400 \, \mathrm{rpm}$. The forward airspeed of the plane is to be $75.0 \, \mathrm{m/s}$, and the speed of the propeller tips through the air must not exceed $270 \, \mathrm{m/s}$. (This is about $80\%$ of the speed of sound in air. If the propeller tips moved faster, they would produce a lot of noise.)

What is the body's kinetic energy if it rotates about axis 1 with angular speed $\omega = 4.0 \, \mathrm{rad/s}$?

A machine part consists of three small disks linked by lightweight struts.

Find the final speed of the cable.

We wrap a light, nonstretching cable around a solid cylinder, of mass $50 \, \mathrm{kg}$ and diameter $0.120 \, \mathrm{m}$, that rotates in frictionless bearings about a stationary horizontal axis. We pull the free end of the cable with a constant $9.0 \, \mathrm{N}$ force for a distance of $2.0 \, \mathrm{m}$; it turns the cylinder as it unwinds without slipping. The cylinder is initially at rest.

Find the magnitude of the torque he applies about the center of the fitting.

To loosen a pipe fitting, a plumber slips a piece of scrap pipe (a \"cheater\") over his wrench handle. He stands on the end of the cheater, applying his $900 \, \mathrm{N}$ weight at a point $0.80 \, \mathrm{m}$ from the center of the fitting. The wrench handle and cheater make an angle of $19^{\circ}$ with the horizontal.

Using energy considerations, find the speed $v_{\mathrm{cm}}$ of the cylinder's center of mass after it has descended a distance $h$.

A primitive yo-yo has a massless string wrapped around a solid cylinder with mass $M$ and radius $R$. You hold the free end of the string stationary and release the cylinder from rest. The string unwinds but does not slip or stretch as the cylinder descends and rotates.

What is the magnitude of the friction force on the ball?

A bowling ball of mass $M$ rolls without slipping down a ramp that is inclined at an angle $\beta$ to the horizontal. Treat the ball as a uniform solid sphere, ignoring the finger holes.

Find his final angular velocity if he pulls the dumbbells inward to his stomach.

A physics professor stands at the center of a frictionless turntable with arms outstretched and a $5.0 \, \mathrm{kg}$ dumbbell in each hand. He is set rotating about the vertical axis, making one revolution in $2.0 \, \mathrm{s}$. His moment of inertia (without the dumbbells) is $3.0 \, \mathrm{kg} \cdot \mathrm{m}^2$ with arms outstretched and $2.2 \, \mathrm{kg} \cdot \mathrm{m}^2$ with his hands at his stomach. The dumbbells are $1.0 \, \mathrm{m}$ from the axis initially and $0.20 \, \mathrm{m}$ at the end.

Derive an expression for $\omega$.

Figure shows two disks: an engine flywheel ($A$) and a clutch plate ($B$) attached to a transmission shaft. Their moments of inertia are $I_A$ and $I_B$; initially, they are rotating in the same direction with constant angular speeds $\omega_A$ and $\omega_B$, respectively. We push the disks together with forces acting along the axis, so as not to apply any torque on either disk. The disks rub against each other and eventually reach a common angular speed $\omega$.

Find the door's angular speed.

A door $1.00 \, \mathrm{m}$ wide, of mass $15 \, \mathrm{kg}$, can rotate freely about a vertical axis through its hinges. A bullet with a mass of $10 \, \mathrm{g}$ and a speed of $400 \, \mathrm{m/s}$ strikes the center of the door, in a direction perpendicular to the plane of the door, and embeds itself there.

If the gyroscope takes $4.0 \, \mathrm{s}$ for one revolution of precession, what is the angular speed of the wheel?

Figure shows a top view of a spinning, cylindrical gyroscope wheel. The pivot is at $O$, and the mass of the axle is negligible.

What is the next longest wavelength that could form a standing wave in this laser cavity?

Helium-neon lasers emit the red laser light commonly used in classroom demonstrations and supermarket checkout scanners. A helium-neon laser operates at a wavelength of precisely $632.9924 \, \mathrm{nm}$ when the spacing between the mirrors is $310.372 \, \mathrm{mm}$.

In terms of $I_0$, what is the the intensity $I_B$ at point $B$?

Two loudspeakers in a plane are $6.0 \, \mathrm{m}$ apart and in phase. They emit equal-amplitude sound waves with a wavelength of $1.0 \, \mathrm{m}$. Each speaker alone creates sound with intensity $I_0$. An observer at point $A$ is $10 \, \mathrm{m}$ in front of the plane containing the two loudspeakers and centered between them. A second observer at point $B$ is $10 \, \mathrm{m}$ directly in front of one of the speakers.

What frequency should you specify for the transmitters?

Your firm has been hired to design a system that allows airplane pilots to make instrument landings in rain or fog. You've decided to place two radio transmitters $50 \, \mathrm{m}$ apart on either side of the runway. These two transmitters will broadcast the same frequency, but out of phase with each other. This will cause a nodal line to extend straight off the end of the runway. As long as the airplane's receiver is silent, the pilot knows she's directly in line with the runway. If she drifts to one side or the other, the radio will pick up a signal and sound a warning beep. To have sufficient accuracy, the first intensity maxima need to be $60 \, \mathrm{m}$ on either side of the nodal line at a distance of $3.0 \, \mathrm{km}$.

What is the distance between the two $m = 2$ dark fringes?

Light from a helium-neon laser ($\lambda = 633\;nm$) illuminates two slits spaced $0.40\;mm$ apart. A viewing screen is $2.0\;m$ behind the slits.

How wide is the slit?

Light from a helium-neon laser ($\lambda = 633\;nm$) passes through a narrow slit and is seen on a screen $2.0\;m$ behind the slit. The first minimum in the diffraction pattern is $1.2\;cm$ from the central maximum.

What is the index of refraction of the gas at this wavelength?

A Michelson interferometer uses a helium-neon laser with wavelength $\lambda_{vac} = 633\;nm$. In one arm, the light passes through a $4.00\;cm$-thick glass cell. Initially the cell is evacuated, and the interferometer is adjusted so that the central spot is a bright fringe. The cell is then slowly filled to atmospheric pressure with a gas. As the cell fills, 43 bright-dark-bright fringe shifts are seen and counted.

How long is the streak of reflected light across the floor?

A dressing mirror on a closet door is $1.50\;m$ tall. The bottom is $0.50\;m$ above the floor. A bare lightbulb hangs $1.00\;m$ from the closet door, $2.50\;m$ above the floor.

What is the laser beam's direction of travel in the glass?

A laser beam is aimed at a $1.0\;cm$-thick sheet of glass at an angle $30^\circ$ above the glass.

What is the prism's index of refraction?

Figure shows a laser beam deflected by a $30^\circ$-$60^\circ$-$90^\circ$ prism.

What is the diameter of the circle of light seen on the water's surface from above?

A lightbulb is set in the bottom of a $3.0\;m$-deep swimming pool.

How far behind the surface of the glass does the air bubble appear to the fish?

A fish and a sailor look at each other through a $5.0\;cm$-thick glass porthole in a submarine. There happens to be an air bubble right in the center of the glass.

What is the diameter of the image on the detector?

A $4.0\;cm$-diameter flower is $200\;cm$ from the $50\;cm$-focal-length lens of a camera.

What is the magnification?

To see a flower better, a naturalist holds a $6.0\;cm$-focal-length magnifying glass $4.0\;cm$ from the flower.

What is its magnification?

A diverging lens with a focal length of $50\;cm$ is placed $100\;cm$ from a flower.

What is the radius of the lens's curved surface?

The objective lens of a microscope uses a planoconvex glass lens with the flat side facing the specimen. A real image is formed $160\;mm$ behind the lens when the lens is $8.0\;mm$ from the specimen.

What is the focal length of the lens?

A stamp collector uses a magnifying lens that sits $2.0\;cm$ above the stamp. The magnification is $4.0$.

Determine the height of the image.

A $3.0\;cm$-high object is located $20\;cm$ from a concave mirror. The mirror's radius of curvature is $80\;cm$.

What is the effective focal length of the double-lens system used in this camera?

The ``lens'' on a camera is usually a combination of two or more single lenses. Consider a camera in which light passes first through a diverging lens, with $f_1 = -120\;mm$, then a converging lens, with $f_2 = 42\;mm$, spaced $60\;mm$ apart. A reasonable definition of the effective focal length of this lens combination is the focal length of a single lens that could produce an image in the same location if placed at the midpoint of the lens combination. A $10\;cm$-tall object is $500\;mm$ from the first lens.

What is the magnitude of the net force on charge $q_3$ due to the other two charges?

Three charged particles with $q_1 = -50\;nC$, $q_2 = +50\;nC$, and $q_3 = +30\;nC$ are placed on the corners of the $5.0\;cm \times 10.0\;cm$ rectangle shown in figure.

What is the electric field strength?

What is the electric field at a point on the x-axis?

Three equal point charges $q$ are located on the y-axis at $y = 0$ and at $y = \pm d$.

Figure shows a thin, uniformly charged rod of length $L$ with total charge $Q$.

A thin ring of radius $R$ is uniformly charged with total charge $Q$.

What is a typical surface charge density on the surface of a cell wall?

The electric field strength in the cell wall of a neuron is typically $1.0 \times 10^7\;N/C$. This electric field is established because the outer surface of the cell wall is positive and the inner surface negative.

What is its speed as it collides with the positive electrode?

Two $6.0\;cm$-diameter electrodes are spaced $5.0\;mm$ apart. They are charged by transferring $1.0 \times 10^{11}$ electrons from one electrode to the other. An electron is released from rest at the surface of the negative electrode. Assume the space between the electrodes is a vacuum.

By what angle, is the electron beam deflected by these electrodes?

An electron gun creates a beam of electrons moving horizontally with a speed of $3.3 \times 10^7\;m/s$. The electrons enter a $2.0\;cm$-long gap between two parallel electrodes where the electric field is $\vec{E} = (5.0 \times 10^4\;N/C$, down).

What is its initial angular acceleration?

Two $1.0\;g$ balls are connected by a $2.0\;cm$-long insulating rod of negligible mass. One ball has a charge of $+10\;nC$, the other a charge of $-10\;nC$. The rod is held in a $1.0 \times 10^4\;N/C$ uniform electric field at an angle of $30^\circ$ with respect to the field, then released.

What force does the ion exert on the water molecule?

The water molecule H$_2$O has a permanent dipole moment of magnitude $6.2 \times 10^{-30}\;Cm$. A water molecule is located $10\;nm$ from a Na$^+$ ion in a saltwater solution.

What is the charge on the ball?

In a vacuum chamber, a proton orbits a $1.0\;cm$-diameter metal ball $1.0\;mm$ above the surface with a period of $1.0\;\mu s$.

Calculate the electric flux through a closed cylinder of length $L$ and radius $R$ that is centered along the $z$-axis.

A charge distribution with cylindrical symmetry has created the electric field $\vec{E} = E_0(r^2/r_0^2)\hat{r}$, where $E_0$ and $r_0$ are constants and where unit vector $\hat{r}$ lies in the $xy$-plane.

What is the electric field inside a uniformly charged sphere?

Figure shows a spherical Gaussian surface.

Use Gauss's law to find the electric field of an infinite plane of charge with surface charge density $(C/m^2)$ $\eta$.

Figure shows a uniformly charged plane.

An infinite slab of charge of thickness $2a$ is centered in the $xy$-plane. The charge density is $\rho = \rho_0(1 - |z|/a)$.

What initial speed must the proton have to just reach the surface of the glass?

A proton is fired from far away at a $1.0\;mm$-diameter glass sphere that has been charged to $+100\;nC$.

What minimum speed must each have when they are $100\;fm$ apart in order to escape each other?

An interaction between two elementary particles causes an electron and a positron (a positive electron) to be shot out back to back with equal speeds.

If the center electron is displaced horizontally by a small distance, what will its speed be when it is very far away?

Three electrons are spaced $1.0\;mm$ apart along a vertical line. The outer two electrons are fixed in position.

A proton with a speed of $2.0 \times 10^5\;m/s$ enters a region of space in which source charges have created an electric potential.

What is the proton's speed at $1.0\;cm$ from the sphere?

As shown in figure.

What is the percentage of muscle in this person's upper arm?

This is obviously not a picture of the actual structure, but gathering all the fat tissue together and all the muscle tissue together is a model that predicts the arm's electrical character quite well.\par A $0.87\;mA$ current is recorded when a $0.60\;V$ potential difference is applied across an upper arm having the dimensions shown in the figure.

How much energy is dissipated by the $5500\;\Omega$ resistor?

The switch in figure has been in position a for a long time. It is suddenly switched to position b for $1.0\;s$, then back to a.

A wire of radius $R$ carries current $I$.

What are the magnitude of the magnetic force on the electron?

A long wire carries a $10\;A$ current from left to right. An electron $1.0\;cm$ above the wire is traveling to the right at a speed of $1.0 \times 10^7\;m/s$.

What is the radius of its orbit?

In figure, an electron is accelerated from rest through a potential difference of $500\;V$, then injected into a uniform magnetic field. Once in the magnetic field, it completes half a revolution in $2.0\;ns$.

What current through the wire will allow the wire to ``float'' in the magnetic field?

The $0.10\;T$ uniform magnetic field of figure is horizontal, parallel to the floor. A straight segment of $1.0\;mm$-diameter copper wire, also parallel to the floor, is perpendicular to the magnetic field.

How much current is required to stretch the springs to lengths of $6.0\;cm$?

Two stiff, $50\;cm$-long, parallel wires are connected at the ends by metal springs. Each spring has an unstretched length of $5.0\;cm$ and a spring constant of $0.025\;N/m$. The wires push each other apart when a current travels around the loop.

What is the oscillation amplitude of this speaker if driven by a $100\;Hz$ oscillatory voltage from the amplifier with a peak value of $12\;V$?

A loudspeaker consists of a paper cone wrapped at the bottom with several turns of fine wire. As figure shows, this coil sits in a narrow gap between the poles of a circular magnet. To produce sound, the amplifier drives a current through the coil. The magnetic field then exerts a force on this current, pushing the cone and thus pushing the air to create a sound wave. An ideal speaker would experience only forces from the magnetic field, thus responding only to the current from the amplifier. Real speakers are balanced so as to come close to this ideal unless driven very hard. Consider a $5.5\;g$ loudspeaker cone with a $5.0\;cm$-diameter, $20$-turn coil having a resistance of $8.0\;\Omega$. There is a $0.18\;T$ field in the gap between the poles. These values are typical of the loudspeakers found in car stereo systems.

What is the potential difference between the ends of the bar?

A metal bar of length $l$ rotates with angular velocity $\omega$ about a pivot at one end of the bar. A uniform magnetic field $\vec{B}$ is perpendicular to the plane of rotation.

What force is needed to keep the wire moving?

Figure shows a circuit consisting of a flashlight bulb, rated $3.0\;V/1.5\;W$, and ideal wires with no resistance. The right wire of the circuit, which is $10\;cm$ long, is pulled at constant speed $v$ through a perpendicular magnetic field of strength $0.10\;T$.

What is the magnetic flux through the loop?

Figure is an edge view of a $10\;cm$-diameter circular loop in a uniform $0.050\;T$ magnetic field.

What is the magnetic flux through the loop?

The $1.0\;cm \times 4.0\;cm$ rectangular loop of figure is $1.0\;cm$ away from a long straight wire. The wire carries a current of $1.0\;A$.

What current will be induced?

The body is a conductor, so rapid magnetic field changes in an MRI machine can induce currents in the body. To estimate the size of these currents, and any biological hazard they might impose, consider the ``loop'' of muscle tissue shown in figure. This might be muscle circling the bone of your arm or thigh. Although muscle is not a great conductor---its resistivity is $1.5\;\Omega\;m$---we can consider it to be a conducting loop with a rather high resistance. Suppose the magnetic field along the axis of the loop drops from $1.6\;T$ to $0\;T$ in $0.30\;s$, which is about the largest possible rate of change for an MRI solenoid.

What is the current in the circuit at $t = 5.0\;\mu s$?

The switch in figure has been in position a for a long time. It is changed to position b at $t = 0\;s$.

What is the wire's initial temperature rise, in $^\circ C / min$?

Induction heating uses induced currents to heat metal objects to high temperatures for applications such as surface hardening, brazing, or even melting. To illustrate the idea, consider a copper wire formed into a $4.0\;cm \times 4.0\;cm$ square loop and placed in a magnetic field---perpendicular to the plane of the loop---that oscillates with $0.010\;T$ amplitude at a frequency of $1000\;Hz$.

What is the magnetic field strength inside the capacitor at a point $0.50\;cm$ from the axis?

A $2.0\;cm$-diameter parallel-plate capacitor with a $1.0\;mm$ spacing is being charged at the rate $0.50\;C/s$.

According to Peggy, what times do the explosions occur relative to the time that Ryan passes her?

Peggy is standing in the center of a long, flat railroad car that has firecrackers tied to both ends. The car moves past Ryan, who is standing on the ground, with velocity $v = 0.8c$. Flashes from the exploding firecrackers reach him simultaneously $1.0\;\mu s$ after the instant that Peggy passes him, and he later finds burn marks on the track $300\;m$ to either side of where he had been standing.

What value of $\Delta V$ will allow the electron to pass through the plates without deflection?

An electron is fired between two parallel-plate electrodes that are $5.0\;mm$ apart and $3.0\;cm$ long. A $3.0\;cm$-wide, $1.0\;mT$ magnetic field overlaps the electrodes and is perpendicular to the electric field. When $\Delta V = 0\;V$, the electron is deflected by $2.0\;mm$ as it passes between the plates.

What is the distance of closest approach to the nucleus?

An alpha particle is shot with a speed of $2.0 \times 10^7\;m/s$ directly toward the nucleus of a gold atom.

With what kinetic energy was the beta particle ejected from the $12.4\;fm$-diameter nucleus?

The cesium isotope $^{137}$Cs, with $Z=55$, is radioactive and decays by beta decay. A beta particle is observed in the laboratory with a kinetic energy of $300\;keV$.

What is the wavelength of the photon emitted in this quantum jump?

Fluorescence is the absorption of light at one wavelength followed by emission at a longer wavelength. If $10^6$ particles are detected, how many are expected to be found in the region $x \geq 1\;nm$?

A particle is described by the wave function $\psi(x) = \begin{cases} 0 & x < 0 \\ c e^{-x/L} & x \geq 0 \end{cases}$ where $L = 1\;nm$.

According to the rocket scientists, what angle does the electric field make with the axis of the rocket?

What are the fields measured by an earthbound scientist?

A rocket zooms past the earth at $v = 2.0 \times 10^6\;m/s$. Scientists on the rocket have created the electric and magnetic fields shown in figure.

Figure shows a simple one-dimensional model of the potential-energy well of an alpha particle in a nucleus with $A \approx 235$. The $15$ $fm$ width of this one-dimensional potential-energy well is the diameter of the nucleus. Further, to keep the model simple, the Coulomb barrier has been modeled as a $20$-$fm$-wide, $30$-$MeV$-high rectangular potential-energy barrier.

Use figure with $h = 3.0$ $m$ to estimate the radius $R$ of the Earth.

Believe it or not, you can estimate the radius of the Earth without having to go into space. If you have ever been on the shore of a large lake, you may have noticed that you cannot see the beaches, piers, or rocks at water level across the lake on the opposite shore. The lake seems to bulge out between you and the opposite shore--a good clue that the Earth is round. Suppose you climb a stepladder and discover that when your eyes are $10$ $ft$ ($3.0$ $m$) above the water, you can just see the rocks at water level on the opposite shore. From a map, you estimate the distance to the opposite shore as $d \approx 6.1$ $km$.

Express the Earth--Sun distance in $ly$.

An astronomical unit ($AU$) is equal to the average distance from Earth to the Sun, about $92.9 \times 10^6$ $mi$. A parsec ($pc$) is the distance at which a length of $1$ $AU$ would subtend an angle of exactly $1''$. A light-year ($ly$) is the distance that light, traveling through a vacuum with a speed of $186000$ $mi/s$, would cover in $1.0$ $year$.

At what time does the layer's depth reach $5.0\ \text{m}$?

Figure shows a general situation in which a stream of people attempt to escape through an exit door that turns out to be locked. The people move toward the door at speed $v_s = 3.50\ \text{m/s}$, are each $d = 0.25\ \text{m}$ in depth, and are separated by $L = 1.75\ \text{m}$. The arrangement in figure occurs at time $t = 0$.

If the separation is twice that amount, what is the speed of the shock wave?

An abrupt slowdown in concentrated traffic can travel as a pulse, termed a shock wave, along the line of cars, either downstream (in the traffic direction) or upstream, or it can be stationary. Figure shows a uniformly spaced line of cars moving at speed $v = 25.0\ m/s$ toward a uniformly spaced line of slow cars moving at speed $v_s = 5.00\ m/s$. Assume that each faster car adds length $L = 12.0\ m$ (car length plus buffer zone) to the line of slow cars when it joins the line, and assume it slows abruptly at the last instant.

What must be the magnitude of the resulting constant deceleration if a collision is to be just avoided?

When a high-speed passenger train traveling at $161\ km/h$ rounds a bend, the engineer is shocked to see that a locomotive has improperly entered onto the track from a siding and is a distance $D = 676\ m$ ahead. The locomotive is moving at $29.0\ km/h$. The engineer of the high-speed train immediately applies the brakes.

If the pilot does not change the airplane's heading, at what time $t$ does the plane strike the ground?

A pilot flies horizontally at $1300\ km/h$, at height $h = 35\ m$ above initially level ground. However, at time $t = 0$, the pilot begins to fly over ground sloping upward at angle $\theta = 4.3^\circ$.

What should be the time delay of the onset of green at intersection 3 relative to that at intersection 2 to keep the platoon moving smoothly?

Figure shows part of a street where traffic flow is to be controlled to allow a platoon of cars to move smoothly along the street. Suppose that the platoon leaders have just reached intersection 2, where the green appeared when they were distance $d$ from the intersection. They continue to travel at a certain speed $v_p$ (the speed limit) to reach intersection 3, where the green appears when they are distance $d$ from it. The intersections are separated by distances $D_{23}$ and $D_{12}$.

How far is it moved vertically?

In figure, a heavy piece of machinery is raised by sliding it a distance $d = 12.5\ m$ along a plank oriented at angle $\theta = 20.0^\circ$ to the horizontal.

What is the angle (relative to the positive direction of the superimposed $x$ axis) of an ant's displacement from the nest (find it in the figure) if the ant enters the trail at point A?

Typical backyard ants often create a network of chemical trails for guidance. Extending outward from the nest, a trail branches (bifurcates) repeatedly, with $60^\circ$ between the branches. If a roaming ant chances upon a trail, it can tell the way to the nest at any branch point: If it is moving away from the nest, it has two choices of path requiring a small turn in its travel direction, either $30^\circ$ leftward or $30^\circ$ rightward. If it is moving toward the nest, it has only one such choice. Figure shows a typical ant trail, with lettered straight sections of $2.0\ cm$ length and symmetric bifurcation of $60^\circ$. Path $v$ is parallel to the $y$ axis.

What is the magnitude of the net displacement $\vec{AB}$ if the strike-slip is $22.0\ m$ and the dip-slip is $17.0\ m$?

Rock faults are ruptures along which opposite faces of rock have slid past each other. In figure, points $A$ and $B$ coincided before the rock in the foreground slid down to the right. The net displacement $\vec{AB}$ is along the plane of the fault. The horizontal component of $\vec{AB}$ is the strike-slip $AC$. The component of $\vec{AB}$ that is directed down the plane of the fault is the dip-slip $AD$.

What is the angle (relative to the floor) of the displacement of $P$?

A wheel with a radius of $45.0\ cm$ rolls without slipping along a horizontal floor. At time $t_1$, the dot $P$ painted on the rim of the wheel is at the point of contact between the wheel and the floor. At a later time $t_2$, the wheel has rolled through one-half of a revolution.

Consider the average velocities of the squirrel from point $A$ to each of the other three points. Of them, what is the magnitude of the one with the least magnitude?

Figure gives the path of a squirrel moving about on level ground, from point $A$ (at time $t = 0$), to points $B$ (at $t = 5.00\ min$), $C$ (at $t = 10.0\ min$), and finally $D$ (at $t = 15.0\ min$).

How high was the release point?

A certain airplane has a speed of $290.0\ km/h$ and is diving at an angle of $\theta = 30.0^\circ$ below the horizontal when the pilot releases a radar decoy. The horizontal distance between the release point and the point where the decoy strikes the ground is $d = 700\ m$.

Find the maximum height $H$ reached above the ground.

In figure, a stone is projected at a cliff of height $h$ with an initial speed of $42.0\ m/s$ directed at angle $\theta_0 = 60.0^\circ$ above the horizontal. The stone strikes at $A$, $5.50\ s$ after launching.

How far above the release point does the ball hit the wall?

You throw a ball toward a wall at speed $25.0\ m/s$ and at angle $\theta_0 = 40.0^\circ$ above the horizontal. The wall is distance $d = 22.0\ m$ from the release point of the ball.

What is the angle relative to the horizontal of the velocity at which the ball is thrown?

In figure, a ball is thrown leftward from the left edge of the roof, at height $h$ above the ground. The ball hits the ground $1.50\ s$ later, at distance $d = 25.0\ m$ from the building and at angle $\theta = 60.0^\circ$ with the horizontal.

If $\phi = 36.0^\circ$ and $d = 0.900\ m$, what launch angle $\theta_0$ is required for the drop to be at the top of the parabolic path when it reaches the insect?

Upon spotting an insect on a twig overhanging water, an archer fish squirts water drops at the insect to knock it into the water. Although the fish sees the insect along a straight-line path at angle $\phi$ and distance $d$, a drop must be launched at a different angle $\theta_0$ if its parabolic path is to intersect the insect.

How far from the cannon should the net's center have been positioned (neglect air drag)?

In 1939 or 1940, Emanuel Zacchini took his humancannonball act to an extreme: After being shot from a cannon, he soared over three Ferris wheels and into a net. Assume that he is launched with a speed of $26.5\ m/s$ and at an angle of $53.0^\circ$.

When it lands, what is the angle of its displacement from the launch point?

In figure, a ball is launched with a velocity of magnitude $10.0\ m/s$, at an angle of $50.0^\circ$ to the horizontal. The launch point is at the base of a ramp of horizontal length $d_1 = 6.00\ m$ and height $d_2 = 3.60\ m$. A plateau is located at the top of the ramp.

What is the magnitude of the ball's initial velocity?

In figure, a ball is thrown up onto a roof, landing $4.00\ s$ later at height $h = 20.0\ m$ above the release level. The ball's path just before landing is angled at $\theta = 60.0^\circ$ with the roof.

How far below the launch level does the skier land?

A skilled skier knows to jump upward before reaching a downward slope. Consider a jump in which the launch speed is $v_0 = 10\ m/s$, the launch angle is $\theta_0 = 11.3^\circ$, the initial course is approximately flat, and the steeper track has a slope of $9.0^\circ$. Figure shows a prejump that allows the skier to land on the top portion of the steeper track. Figure 4-42b shows a jump at the edge of the steeper track. In figure, the skier lands at approximately the launch level.

How high is the wall?

In figure, a baseball is hit at a height $h = 1.00\ m$ and then caught at the same height. It travels alongside a wall, moving up past the top of the wall $1.00\ s$ after it is hit and then down past the top of the wall $4.00\ s$ later, at distance $D = 50.0\ m$ farther along the wall.

In unit-vector notation, what is the velocity of the motorist with respect to the police car?

Two highways intersect as shown in figure. At the instant shown, a police car $P$ is distance $d_P = 800\ m$ from the intersection and moving at speed $v_P = 80\ km/h$. Motorist $M$ is distance $d_M = 600\ m$ from the intersection and moving at speed $v_M = 60\ km/h$.

What is the value of $v_{0y}$?

In figure, a sled moves in the negative $x$ direction at constant speed $v_s$ while a ball of ice is shot from the sled with a velocity $\vec{v}_0 = v_{0x}\hat{i} + v_{0y}\hat{j}$ relative to the sled. When the ball lands, its horizontal displacement $\Delta x_{bg}$ relative to the ground (from its launch position to its landing position) is measured. Figure 4-48b gives $\Delta x_{bg}$ as a function of $v_s$. Assume the ball lands at approximately its launch height.

Find the magnitude of the airplane's displacement during this period.

A radar station detects an airplane approaching directly from the east. At first observation, the airplane is at distance $d_1 = 360\ m$ from the station and at angle $\theta_1 = 40^\circ$ above the horizon. The airplane is tracked through an angular change $\Delta\theta = 123^\circ$ in the vertical east$-$west plane; its distance is then $d_2 = 790\ m$.

At what initial speed must the basketball player in figure throw the ball, at angle $\theta_0 = 55^\circ$ above the horizontal, to make the foul shot?

The horizontal distances are $d_1 = 1.0\ ft$ and $d_2 = 14\ ft$, and the heights are $h_1 = 7.0\ ft$ and $h_2 = 10\ ft$.

At what initial speed would a bomb have to be ejected, at angle $\theta_0 = 35^\circ$ to the horizontal, from the vent at $A$ in order to fall at the foot of the volcano at $B$, at vertical distance $h = 3.30\ km$ and horizontal distance $d = 9.40\ km$? Ignore, for the moment, the effect of air on the bomb's travel.

During volcanic eruptions, chunks of solid rock can be blasted out of the volcano; these projectiles are called volcanic bombs. Figure shows a cross section of Mt. Fuji, in Japan.

At what height on the wall does the lump hit?

In figure, a lump of wet putty moves in uniform circular motion as it rides at a radius of $20.0\ cm$ on the rim of a wheel rotating counterclockwise with a period of $5.00\ ms$. The lump then happens to fly off the rim at the 5 o'clock position (as if on a clock face). It leaves the rim at a height of $h = 1.20\ m$ from the floor and at a distance $d = 2.50\ m$ from a wall.

At what rate does the speed of the ball change relative to the cab floor?

In figure, a ball is shot directly upward from the ground with an initial speed of $v_0 = 7.00\ m/s$. Simultaneously, a construction elevator cab begins to move upward from the ground with a constant speed of $v_c = 3.00\ m/s$.

What is the asteroid's acceleration as a magnitude relative to the positive direction of the $x$ axis?

Three astronauts, propelled by jet backpacks, push and guide a $120\ kg$ asteroid toward a processing dock, exerting the forces shown in figure, with $F_1 = 32\ N$, $F_2 = 55\ N$, $F_3 = 41\ N$, $\theta_1 = 30^\circ$, and $\theta_3 = 60^\circ$.

What is the magnitude of Betty's force $\vec{F}_B$?

In a two-dimensional tug-of-war, Alex, Betty, and Charles pull horizontally on an automobile tire at the angles shown in the overhead view of figure. The tire remains stationary in spite of the three pulls. Alex pulls with force $\vec{F}_A$ of magnitude $220\ N$, and Charles pulls with force $\vec{F}_C$ of magnitude $170\ N$. Note that the direction of $\vec{F}_C$ is not given.

What is the mass of disk $C$?

Figure shows an arrangement in which four disks are suspended by cords. The longer, top cord loops over a frictionless pulley and pulls with a force of magnitude $98\ N$ on the wall to which it is attached. The tensions in the three shorter cords are $T_1 = 58.8\ N$, $T_2 = 49.0\ N$, and $T_3 = 9.8\ N$.

What is the ratio of the tension in each tibia (forepart of a leg) to the insect's weight?

Some insects can walk below a thin rod (such as a twig) by hanging from it. Suppose that such an insect has mass $m$ and hangs from a horizontal rod as shown in figure, with angle $\theta = 40^\circ$. Its legs are all under the same tension, and the leg sections nearest the body are horizontal.

What is the magnitude of the force on the crate from the ramp?

In figure, a crate of mass $m = 100\ kg$ is pushed at constant speed up a frictionless ramp ($\theta = 30.0^\circ$) by a horizontal force $\vec{F}$.

What is direction (relative to positive $x$) of the force on the barge from the water?

In earlier days, horses pulled barges down canals in the manner shown in figure. Suppose the horse pulls on the rope with a force of $7900\ N$ at an angle of $\theta = 18^\circ$ to the direction of motion of the barge, which is headed straight along the positive direction of an $x$ axis. The mass of the barge is $9500\ kg$, and the magnitude of its acceleration is $0.12\ m/s^2$.

Find the magnitude of the force on link 4 from link 5.

In figure, a chain consisting of five links, each of mass $0.100\ kg$, is lifted vertically with constant acceleration of magnitude $a = 2.50\ m/s^2$.

What is the magnitude of the normal force on the box from the floor?

In figure, elevator cabs $A$ and $B$ are connected by a short cable and can be pulled upward or lowered by the cable above cab $A$. Cab $A$ has mass $1700\ kg$; cab $B$ has mass $1300\ kg$. A $12.0\ kg$ box of catnip lies on the floor of cab $A$. The tension in the cable connecting the cabs is $1.91 \times 10^4\ N$.

What is the phase constant (positve) for the harmonic oscillator with the position function $x(t)$ given in figure if the position function has the form $x = x_m \cos(\omega t + \phi)$?

The vertical axis scale is set by $x_s = 6.0\ cm$.

At what frequency does the block oscillate with both springs attached?

As shown in figure, two springs are attached to a block that can oscillate over a frictionless floor. If the left spring is removed, the block oscillates at a frequency of $30\ Hz$. If, instead, the spring on the right is removed, the block oscillates at a frequency of $45\ Hz$.

What is the phase constant (positive) for the harmonic oscillator with the velocity function $v(t)$ given in figure if the position function $x(t)$ has the form $x = x_m \cos(\omega t + \phi)$?

The vertical axis scale is set by $v_s = 4.0\ cm/s$.

What is the phase constant (positive) of the SHM if the position function $x(t)$ is in the general form $x = x_m \cos(\omega t + \phi)$?

Figure a is a partial graph of the position function $x(t)$ for a simple harmonic oscillator with an angular frequency of $1.20\ rad/s$; Figure b is a partial graph of the corresponding velocity function $v(t)$. The vertical axis scales are set by $x_s = 5.0\ cm$ and $v_s = 5.0\ cm/s$.

What is the value of $d$?

Figure shows block 1 of mass $0.200\ kg$ sliding to the right over a frictionless elevated surface at a speed of $8.00\ m/s$. The block undergoes an elastic collision with stationary block 2, which is attached to a spring of spring constant $1208.5\ N/m$. (Assume that the spring does not affect the collision.) After the collision, block 2 oscillates in SHM with a period of $0.140\ s$, and block 1 slides off the opposite end of the elevated surface, landing a distance $d$ from the base of that surface after falling height $h = 4.90\ m$.

What is the frequency of the oscillations?

In figure, two springs are joined and connected to a block of mass $0.245\ kg$ that is set oscillating over a frictionless floor. The springs each have spring constant $k = 6430\ N/m$.

If the block is pulled slightly down the incline and released, what is the period of the resulting oscillations?

In figure, a block weighing $14.0\ N$, which can slide without friction on an incline at angle $\theta = 40.0^\circ$, is connected to the top of the incline by a massless spring of unstretched length $0.450\ m$ and spring constant $120\ N/m$.

What amplitude of simple harmonic motion of the spring$-$blocks system puts the smaller block on the verge of slipping over the larger block?

In figure, two blocks ($m = 1.8\ kg$ and $M = 10\ kg$) and a spring ($k = 200\ N/m$) are arranged on a horizontal, frictionless surface. The coefficient of static friction between the two blocks is $0.40$.

What is the spring constant?

Figure shows the kinetic energy $K$ of a simple harmonic oscillator versus its position $x$. The vertical axis scale is set by $K_s = 4.0\ J$.

Assuming the compression of the spring is negligible until the bullet is embedded, determine the amplitude of the resulting simple harmonic motion.

In figure, a block of mass $M = 5.4\ kg$, at rest on a horizontal frictionless table, is attached to a rigid support by a spring of constant $k = 6000\ N/m$. A bullet of mass $m = 9.5\ g$ and velocity $\vec{v}$ of magnitude $630\ m/s$ strikes and is embedded in the block.

What is the amplitude of the SHM after the collision?

In figure, block 2 of mass $2.0\ kg$ oscillates on the end of a spring in SHM with a period of $20\ ms$. The block's position is given by $x = (1.0\ cm) \cos(\omega t + \pi/2)$. Block 1 of mass $4.0\ kg$ slides toward block 2 with a velocity of magnitude $6.0\ m/s$, directed along the spring's length. The two blocks undergo a completely inelastic collision at time $t = 5.0\ ms$. (The duration of the collision is much less than the period of motion.)

Calculate the period of oscillation.

In figure, the pendulum consists of a uniform disk with radius $r = 10.0\ cm$ and mass $500\ g$ attached to a uniform rod with length $L = 500\ mm$ and mass $270\ g$.

What is the pendulum's period of oscillation about a pin inserted through point $A$ at the center of the horizontal stick?

A physical pendulum consists of two $1\ m$-long sticks joined together as shown in figure.

What is the period of the resulting simple harmonic motion?

In figure, a physical pendulum consists of a uniform solid disk (of radius $R = 2.35\ cm$) supported in a vertical plane by a pivot located a distance $d = 1.75\ cm$ from the center of the disk. The disk is displaced by a small angle and released.

For what value of $r$ does that minimum occur? There is a line of points around the block's center for which the period of swinging has the same minimum value.

A rectangular block, with face lengths $a = 35\ cm$ and $b = 45\ cm$, is to be suspended on a thin horizontal rod running through a narrow hole in the block. The block is then to be set swinging about the rod like a pendulum, through small angles so that it is in SHM. Figure shows one possible position of the hole, at distance $r$ from the block's center, along a line connecting the center with a corner.

What is that least period?

In figure, a stick of length $L = 1.85\ m$ oscillates as a physical pendulum.

If the cube is rotated $3^\circ$ and released, what is the period of the resulting SHM?

The $3.00\ kg$ cube in figure has edge lengths $d = 6.00\ cm$ and is mounted on an axle through its center. A spring ($k = 1200\ N/m$) connects the cube's upper corner to a rigid wall. Initially the spring is at its rest length.

What is the period of the small oscillations that result when the rod is rotated slightly and released?

In the overhead view of figure, a long uniform rod of mass $0.600\ kg$ is free to rotate in a horizontal plane about a vertical axis through its center. A spring with force constant $k = 1850\ N/m$ is connected horizontally between one end of the rod and a fixed wall. When the rod is in equilibrium, it is parallel to the wall.

What is the rotational inertia of the plate about its center of mass?

In figure, a metal plate is mounted on an axle through its center of mass. A spring with $k = 2000\ N/m$ connects a wall with a point on the rim a distance $r = 2.5\ cm$ from the center of mass. Initially the spring is at its rest length. If the plate is rotated by $7^\circ$ and released, it rotates about the axle in SHM, with its angular position given by figure. The horizontal axis scale is set by $t_s = 20\ ms$.

What is the torsion constant of the spring if the period of oscillation has been decreased by $0.500\ s$?

In figure, a $2.50\ kg$ disk of diameter $D = 42.0\ cm$ is supported by a rod of length $L = 76.0\ cm$ and negligible mass that is pivoted at its end. With the torsion spring connected, the rod is vertical at equilibrium.

Assuming that the cable obeys Hooke's law, find the amplitude of the resulting oscillations of the remaining two cars.

In figure, three $10000\ kg$ ore cars are held at rest on a mine railway using a cable that is parallel to the rails, which are inclined at angle $\theta = 30^\circ$. The cable stretches $15\ cm$ just before the coupling between the two lower cars breaks, detaching the lowest car.

Assuming that the wheel is a hoop of mass $m$ and radius $R$, What is $\omega$ if $r = R$?

A wheel is free to rotate about its fixed axle. A spring is attached to one of its spokes a distance $r$ from the axle, as shown in figure.

What is the magnitude of the radial acceleration of a particle in the corresponding uniform circular motion?

Figure gives the position $x(t)$ of a block oscillating in SHM on the end of a spring ($t_s = 40.0\ ms$).

What is the length of the pendulum?

Figure shows the kinetic energy $K$ of a simple pendulum versus its angle $\theta$ from the vertical. The vertical axis scale is set by $K_s = 10.0\ mJ$. The pendulum bob has mass $0.200\ kg$.

What is the maximum kinetic energy?

A simple harmonic oscillator consists of a $0.50\ kg$ block attached to a spring. The block slides back and forth along a straight line on a frictionless surface with equilibrium point $x = 0$. At $t = 0$ the block is at $x = 0$ and moving in the positive $x$ direction. A graph of the magnitude of the net force $\vec{F}$ on the block as a function of its position is shown in figure. The vertical scale is set by $F_s = 75.0\ N$.

If the pendulum is to have a period of $2.000$ s for small oscillations at a place where $g = 9.800$ m/s$^2$, what must be the rod length $L$ to the nearest tenth of a millimeter?

A grandfather clock has a pendulum that consists of a thin brass disk of radius $r = 15.00$ cm and mass $1.000$ kg that is attached to a long thin rod of negligible mass. The pendulum swings freely about an axis perpendicular to the rod and through the end of the rod opposite the disk, as shown in figure.

What is the phase constant (positive) for SMH with $a(t)$ given in figure if the position function $x(t)$ has the form $x = x_m \cos(\omega t + \phi)$ and $a_s = 4.0$ m/s$^2$?

As shown in figure.

What is the maximum angular speed $d\theta/dt$ of the disk?

A torsion pendulum consists of a metal disk with a wire running through its center and soldered in place. The wire is mounted vertically on clamps and pulled taut. Figure gives the magnitude $\tau$ of the torque needed to rotate the disk about its center (and thus twist the wire) versus the rotation angle $\theta$. If the system is released from rest when the spring is stretched by $0.250$ m, find the rotational kinetic energy of the cylinder as it passes through the equilibrium position.

In figure, a solid cylinder attached to a horizontal spring ($k = 3.00$ N/m) rolls without slipping along a horizontal surface.

What is its maximum kinetic energy?

The block slides on a frictionless surface, with equilibrium point \(x = 0\) and amplitude \(0.20\,\mathrm{m}\). A graph of the block's velocity \(v\) as a function of time \(t\) is shown in figure.
